SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: INTRODUCTION

On the 9th September 1991, I introduced a draft of a Bill to establish mechanisms to protect endangered species and to redress the processes in the bush that are threatening the extinction of a large number of our uniquely Australian plants and animals.
The intent of introducing the Bill in draft form was to give the parliament and the community sufficient time to consider the contents of the proposed legislation.

This legislation and the necessary government and community support structures are absolutely vital if we are to begin the long process of protecting and restoring the great biological diversity on this continent which has contributed greatly to our material, spiritual and cultural well being.
The draft Bill has been circulating in the community for some 6 months.
During that time, over 3,000 copies of my accompanying speech and over 2,000 copies of the draft Bill have been distributed.

I am heartened and gratified at the level of interest expressed in what this Bill hopes to achieve. We have received over one hundred submissions from conservation and farmer organisations, and many letters of support.
As a result of this consultation I have made a number of substantial amendments to the draft Bill. These changes will be discussed later in this address.

But first, I think it is important to reiterate some of the reasons for introducing such legislation into the parliament at this time, and to remind Senators of the context in which the Australian Democrats see such legislation.

According to the United Nations Environment Program, "Estimates of the number of living species on Earth vary from 5 million to 30 million, of which only 1.4 million have been identified and classified. . .

They state that "though there is no precise estimate of the number of species that have been lost,. . . experts believe that 25 percent of the Earth's total biological diversity is at risk of extinction during the next 20 to 30 years. . .

This current problem applies as much to Australia as anywhere else. In the past 200 years, since the settlement of this continent by Europeans, Australia is known to have lost 30 large and visible animals and 100 plants.

Professor Harry Recher from the University of New England notes that "Most Australians view the continent as vast, unspoiled and underpopulated. Yet in historical times, no other continent has experienced the massive changes in the distribution and abundance of such a large proportion of its vertebrate fauna as has Australia.
Many people think that the great extinctions of our wildlife and their habitats occurred in the very early days of European settlement and that damage has all but stopped.
This view could not be further from the truth. The rates of extinction on this continent are as rapid now as they were at any time in the past.

The historical evidence is that most extinctions occurred in Australia within 20 or 30 years of an area being settled. We are still colonising areas, and this same pattern is set to be repeated, particularly in the south-west and north-west of the continent as settlement of these regions intensifies.
Traditional conservation methods have not dealt with the problem of species and habitat loss adequately. This has been recognised by the IUCN when it states:

"The best way to slow the loss of biodiversity is through diverse, coordinated, and participatory programs that attack the problem at its roots, builds support among wide-ranging institutions and individuals, draws on the best modern science, and establishes biodiversity conservation in its rightful place as a basic prerequisite of development policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: This statement provided the thinking on which the structure of this Bill is based.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have in this Bill is not just legislation to protect an endangered species, but wide ranging programs to protect species, populations of threatened species, and the ecological communities on which they depend for their continued survival and evolutionary development.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A 5 STEP PLAN TO SAVE OUR BIODIVERSITY

SPEECH.PARA: In my speech introduced with the draft Bill, I announced a 5 point plan that I believe can and should be adopted to reverse the threatening processes in our natural and rural environments. The Threatened Species Bill is one important part of this plan.
What we had in Australia 200 years ago was an ecological balance. That balance has been disrupted by the massive modifications brought about by European Australians since then.

The more we move away from that balance, the less stable our environment and the greater the chance of major environmental problems occurring. This suggested five point plan is about beginning to redress the causes of the disruption of that original balance and to help the continent to establish a new balance.
Extinction occurs at the level of populations and not at the level of species. It is a symptom of larger problems with the way we manage our environment in an unsustainable manner.
Because of this, conservation strategies must focus on managing for population viability. Fragmented, one off solutions to environmental management have failed. We need a new approach.
The Australian Democrats 5 point plan for protecting the life support systems on which our society and economy is based consists of:
* increased funding for threatened species;
* increased funding for Landcare groups;
* increased funding for biological research;
* better management of renewable natural resources; and finally
* federal legislation to protect endangered species.
The Federal Government proudly boasts an Endangered Species Program, and provided funding of $5 million this year.
This represents 0.005% of the Federal budget. The Federal Government's current funding for endangered species represents about 31 cents a year for each Australian.

The current Labor Government spent more on landscaping the grounds around Parliament House, than they have spent on saving species in Australia in the past three years. And even the $5 million budget is about to be slashed by 20 per cent.

As a nation, we were able to plan a 25 year Snowy Mountains Scheme to help improve our economic wellbeing, but it appears a far simpler task of providing funding certainty to repair our natural environment cannot be done. That of course is a nonsense—the problem in not the inability to provide certainty, it is the lack of political will to do so.

Australia must prepare, in consultation with conservation, industry, farm, fishing and forestry groups, a 200 year Australian conservation plan, which contains action plans, and funding targets for a least the first 10 years.
The 200 year plan must integrate the management of all extinction threatening processes:
* the loss of habitat;
* protecting endangered species, populations and ecological communities, and;
* controlling the numbers, type and range of many feral animals.
By 1994-95 funding for this threatened species program should reach $100 million per annum:
* $40 million should be for habitat protection;
* $30 million should be to ensure the survival of species, and;
* $30 million should be for the control of feral animals and introduced plants.
The existing Landcare program is an excellent initiative of the government, in that it encourages local communities to become directly involved in the conservation of their local environment.
However the funding of Landcare is not adequate to meet the task.
CSIRO for example, claims that "since European settlement some 52 per cent of Australia's agricultural and pastoral lands have been degraded and are now in need of reclamation.
The current program should be expanded and restructured. Funding levels for this program should commence at $90 million in 1991-92 and increase to $170 million by 1993-94.

This proposal has received a deal of comment from the community, particularly as people are now beginning to recognise after the massive problems with the blue-green algae infestation in the Darling and Murray Rivers, that our catchments are under great stress and in urgent need of repair.

As a result of these submissions, the Australian Democrats will soon be calling for comment on processes that should be put into place to help our rural landholders improve the ecological health of our catchments.

It is critical to the management of our natural environment that we know what it consists of and how species interact with each other. Without the basic information about the environment which we inhabit, it is impossible to plan an ecologically sustainable future.
However the level of funding given to this task at present is so inadequate that the work will not be completed until the year 3000!
This is clearly ridiculous and the government should set a priority to have the data base of all known flora and fauna completed in time for the bicentenary of Federation in 2001.
This can be achieved with funding of a paltry $24 million per annum, providing such funding is guaranteed for the next 10 years.
The Government should get serious about the long term management of our natural resources through proper research, monitoring and setting sustainable catch/harvest limits on our renewable resources.
This is not occurring at present and they are simply depleting our environmental capital to hold up a poorly managed economy.

The Government should abandon its proposed Resource Security legislation. Instead it should be placing a real price on the value of our publicly owned renewable resources, such as the timber in our native forests, and allow plantation forestry to become economically viable.
At the moment it is actually subsidising an inefficient and environmentally destructive industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Step 5: Legislation to protect endangered species

SPEECH.PARA: Step 5 is the legislative component of the programs just suggested, which can be implemented by the Federal Government supporting a Bill to protect endangered species and their habitats.
This legislation which is proposed in this Threatened Species Bill gives the Federal Government power to protect threatened species and their habitats.

It encourages the States and Territories to establish their own Threatened Species legislation, and provides for Commonwealth financial assistance to do so. It also gives the Federal government overriding powers to protect species if the States fail to take appropriate action.

The draft Bill which was circulated for public comment in September last year has had a number of substantial amendments. The major amendments relate to addressing the financial impact that this legislation is likely to have on rural landholders, and on the structure and administrative processes in implementing the legislation.
The objectives of the Threatened Species Bill are to redress the fundamental problems facing Australia in the continuing loss of its biodiversity.
The Bill identifies six objectives which address this problem. They are to:
(a) ensure that threatened species, populations and ecological communities can survive and flourish;
(b) ensure that threatened species, populations and ecological communities retain their genetic diversity and potential for evolutionary development in their natural habitat;
(c) prevent further species, populations and ecological communities from becoming endangered;
(d) encourage the States by way of resources and financial incentives, to introduce complimentary threatened species legislation;
(e) provide programs-
(i) of community education in the conservation of flora and fauna; and
(ii) to encourage co-operative management of flora and fauna between government authorities, corporations, landholders, community groups and individuals; and
(f) assist other nations and negotiate international treaties to protect the biological heritage of humankind.
We, the Australian Democrats, believe that government alone cannot achieve the conservation of biodiversity. The community must be involved in all aspects of planning, development and implementation.

Therefore, we have developed structures and processes in this Bill which facilitate community co-operation and involvement, not only in the listing of threatened species, but also in the management of plans to protect them.

A Commonwealth Threatened Species Management Committee is established which is to have a major influence in the management of threatened species. This Committee comprises three government appointed officers, two people representing conservation organisations, two people representing rural interests and two people representing the scientific community.

The responsibilities of the Management Committee include overseeing the preparation of a Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy, managing the Threatened Species Conservation Fund, and recommending to the Minister the signing of Species Recovery Plans and Threatening Process Action Plans. These will be discussed in more detail in a moment.

In recognition of the role Australia should play in maintaining global biodiversity this Bill establishes an Australian International Threatened Species Advisory Committee. The purpose of this second Committee is to give guidance to Australian representatives on international agencies and to assist international bodies in the implementation of international treaties relating to the protection and conservation of threatened species. It will not play a role in the protection of Australia's threatened species, which is the responsibility of the Commonwealth Threatened Species Management Committee.

To help the Management Committee deal with the purely scientific aspects of protecting threatened species, and to assist the Minister in determining whether to list a species, population or ecological community, a Scientific Advisory Panel is established to make purely scientific judgements and recommendations concerning the listing of threatened species.
The Bill also ensures the on-going function of the Endangered Species Unit (to be renamed the Threatened Species Unit) within the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

It is felt that the specialist nature of threatened species recovery warrants the continued functioning of a separate unit within the ANPWS. The Unit is to provide administrative resources to the Commonwealth Threatened Species Management Committee, the Australian International Threatened Species Advisory Committee and the Scientific Advisory Panel.

I am confident that this Bill will take species conservation out of the hands of the bureaucracy and place it firmly in the care of the people who have the greatest interest in conserving our native species, namely the landholders of Australia, conservation groups and the scientific community. These groups will provide an appropriate and comprehensive level of protection to Australia's threatened species.
Threatened Species Action Plans

PARA.EMPHASIS: The purpose of the Bill is to identify and then implement programs to protect threatened species, populations and ecological communities.

SPEECH.PARA: To do this four distinct mechanisms are proposed: A Threatened Species Conservation Strategy; Action Plans (to remove threats to species); Recovery Plans (to help protect species in the wild); and Habitat Management Agreements (to help landholders help the recovery process).
Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy is to ensure the survival and evolutionary development in the wild of all species, populations and ecological communities, and to promote the importance of conserving biodiversity through a community education program.
Recovery Plans

The purpose of a Species Recovery Plan is to devise specific strategies to protect and conserve a threatened species, population or ecological community. A Recovery Plan must state what has to be done to ensure the recovery of that species, population or ecological community to a position of viability in the wild.

For example, a recovery plan may be developed for the bilby which identifies the bilby's recovery range and actions to take to protect the recovery range. Each plan will also provide estimates of costs, the time period of each plan, and the assistance and compensation to be given to landholders.
Action Plans
Threatening Process Action Plans are to be developed to identify and reverse the processes which pose a threat to biodiversity.

The difference between Recovery Plans and Action Plans is that Recovery Plans are species, population and community specific, whereas Action Plans are aimed at redressing more widespread processes that are causing species to become threatened.
Two examples of threatening processes are the impacts of feral animals such as foxes, cats and rabbits, and the clearing of native vegetation.
Without such Action Plans, activities which threaten biodiversity will continue to accelerate and Recovery Plans will simply represent islands in an ever rising sea of threatening processes.
The Commonwealth Threatened Species Management Committee will have to prioritise Action Plans within the financial constraints imposed on them by their budget allocations.
Those Plans that are likely to positively affect the largest number of species in the shortest available time should receive the highest priority.
Habitat Management Agreements
The Bill provides for Habitat Management Agreements which are vehicles to encourage landholders to assist in the implementation of Recovery Plans and Action Plans.

The Agreements are to include provisions for assistance and compensation to landholders, and incentives for one or more persons or public authorities to enter into Habitat Management Agreements. I will describe these in a moment.
Funding

A Threatened Species Conservation Corporation and Fund are also established. The Corporation's purpose is to raise money from the private sector to help finance the conservation measures provided for in this Bill. The fund will consist of money raised by the Corporation, money appropriated by Parliament, penalties payable in respect of offences against this Bill and fees payable in respect of applications for a permit to interfere. I will discuss this permit procedure later on.

As I discussed earlier, funding for threatened species conservation is abysmally low. The Democrats have developed a 10 year budget for the funding of the Commonwealth Threatened Species Conservation Strategy which we believe will provide funding levels commensurate with the importance of conserving our unique biodiversity. According to this budget, in 1992-93 a total of $50 million should be allocated to the Strategy. By 1994-95 the total amount should be upgraded to $100 million.

We believe that Australians will readily support the expenditure of $50 million of public funds in the first year to implement the provisions of this Bill if they are satisfied that the money will help protect our precious and irreplaceable Australian wildlife.
Three dollars a year for each Australian to save and repair our natural heritage is, in our opinion, a deposit on the heritage we leave to our children.

The Democrats believe that individual landholders should be provided with appropriate levels of compensation and assistance to carry out species conservation measures on behalf of the Australian community.

The draft Bill made provision for compensation to landholders where Interim and Permanent Conservation Orders are established. However, the limited extent of this compensation was strongly criticised by landholder groups, such as the National Farmers Federation, the United Farmers & Stockowners of South Australia, and the Tasmanian Farmers & Graziers Association.
We have given serious consideration to their criticisms and have, on balance, found them to be valid.

We have therefore, substantially amended the draft and now include provisions for full compensation to landholders where any action taken under this Bill would have an adverse financial impact on the legitimate existing use of a landholders property.

For example, if a landholder was asked to destock a portion of the property to protect a threatened habitat, then the landholder could legitimately claim compensation for the loss of productive capacity from that part of the property, even though the land would still remain in his or her ownership and management.

It was put to me strongly, and I fully respect the argument, that if a landholder's property happens to include threatened species, it is not exclusively that landholder's responsibility that the species is now threatened.

It is therefore a breach of natural justice to require that landholder to suffer a financial loss to preserve a species on behalf of the entire Australian community. It is a national responsibility to protect threatened species, and landholders who are asked or required to assist in their protection should receive full compensation for interference with their economic production.

Landholders will be compensated for any financial loss suffered as a natural, direct and reasonable consequence of the making of an Interim or Permanent Conservation Order. The amount by which the value of the land will be increased or decreased will be taken into account by the Minister in deciding the landholder's entitlement. The compensation may be given in the form of a payment of money or provision of labour, goods or other services. In addition, any costs associated with a claim for compensation will be met.
In addition, landholders who enter into voluntary Habitat Management Agreements will be eligible for financial or other assistance in three areas:
* the management of land, threatened species, populations or ecological communities on or visiting their land;
* the restoration or regeneration of native vegetation on their land; and
* research in relation to the preservation, enhancement or management of threatened species, populations or ecological communities on or visiting their land.

We feel sure that this Bill has improved the financial protection and assistance provided to landholders and that no individual landholder will be financially disadvantaged by any component of this Bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Permit to Interfere, Environmental Impact Assessment and Licence to Interfere

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill recognises that there will inevitably be situations where actions need to be taken which have a minor impact on threatened species. It therefore provides for a `permit to interfere' with threatened species. The Director of the Threatened Species Unit will only issue permits if he or she is satisfied that the proposed action will not impede the recovery, threaten the extinction, or significantly affect the habitat of Australia's threatened species, populations or ecological communities.

If a person breaches the permit or if the Director has not rejected an application for a permit outright, the Bill requires the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement. The intent of this section is to require an EIS for new developments that might have a major impact on a species. Where the Minister finds the EIS acceptable, he or she may issue a `licence to interfere'. The developer must enter into an assurity or bond arrangement whereby the impacts of any approved interference must be properly rehabilitated.

Where a species is threatened and a prompt response to its conservation is essential, the Bill provides for the making of Interim Conservation Orders by the Minister to conserve the critical habitat of a listed or nominated species, population or ecological community.
Where appropriate, the Interim Conservation Order will be succeeded by a Permanent Conservation Order.

Both Orders will manage, regulate or prohibit activities both inside and outside the recovery range where such activities are likely to adversely affect the survival of the threatened species. Again, compensation mechanisms have been provided for.

A range of measures are provided to involve the community in the conservation of threatened species. These include education programs, financial assistance to the Threatened Species Network, taxation incentives to landholders who become involved in programs to conserve biodiversity, and assistance to community organisations to establish and maintain Local Action Plans aimed at conserving locally important species, populations and remnant ecological communities.

The importance of community involvement in species conservation cannot be overemphasised. This component of the Bill will help to nurture an ethic of conservation that is already growing in the Australian community. However, it cannot be overemphasised that the community goodwill needs to be matched by adequate financial and technical support.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commonwealth Powers to Protect Threatened Species

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill requires the Commonwealth to fully exercise its constitutional powers to protect threatened species, populations and ecological communities. The Bill imposes controls on the activities of Commonwealth government agencies, on Australian citizens operating outside of Australia and its territories, on activities within Commonwealth Territories and on foreign and trading corporations.

The Bill encourages the States and Territories to enact threatened species legislation. In addition, where State and Territory governments are developing appropriate legislation, or actively fulfilling their obligations under such legislation, the Commonwealth may provide financial and technical assistance.

However, where State or Territory governments have made insufficient progress towards the conservation of threatened species, this Bill allows the Commonwealth to take action to secure their conservation.
In addition, the Bill seeks to strengthen the Commonwealth Government's constitutional powers in relation to international agreements and conventions on the protection of biodiversity.

Schedule Three lists the international agreements and conventions relevant to the Act, which is to include the Convention for the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), the Convention on Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (the Bonn Convention), the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance (the RAMSAR Convention), the China-Australia Agreement for the Protection of Migratory Birds and their Environment (CAMBA), the Japan-Australia Agreement for the Protection of Migratory Birds in danger of extinction and their Environment (JAMBA), the Convention for the Protection of the Natural Resources and Environment of the South Pacific Region (the SPREP Convention) and the Convention on Conservation of Nature in the South Pacific (the APIA Convention).
The Threatened Species Bill recognises and provides enabling legislation for these international agreements and conventions.
CONCLUSION

Species extinction is irreversible. Our present generation is witnessing an alarming rate of species extinction and habitat loss both in Australia and overseas. Determined and enlightened government and community action is required to stem and reverse this loss, both for the sake of future generations and for the preservation of ecological integrity on which we all depend.

The current system of conservation reserves in Australia is inadequate to conserve the full range of species existing in Australia today. Management for conservation and development, that is ecologically sustainable development, must be adopted across all industry sectors in order to provide full protection to threatened species. This Bill recognises that, as an island continent, Australia is one interconnected system. It also recognises that the processes that threaten native species do not respect institutional jurisdictions. It therefore provides mechanisms to protect all threatened species, populations and ecological communities across the continent.

Global warming poses new and unprecedented threats to biodiversity. The diversity of life on our planet is a result of highly complex interactions between biological, physical and climatic processes. Over many tens of thousands of years, climates have changed quite dramatically, however, the pace of change has been sufficiently slow to allow species to adapt. We are now faced with the prospect of an accelerated greenhouse effect. Uncertainty exists only about the speed and scale of change. Scientists have warned that the rate may be too fast to allow species to adapt. Climate zones are likely to move, leaving whole ecological communities to the mercy of weather patterns to which they have not adapted. Without the adoption of effective precautionary action, massive increases in species extinction are likely. To hedge against this alarming prospect, the government must act now to set in train processes which protect our most threatened species.

Future generations of Australians are relying on this government to take a bold step and to conserve a part of our heritage that once lost can never be replaced. The loss of any species due to human action or inaction diminishes our humanness. I urge you all to give your serious consideration to this Bill which we, the Democrats, believe will provide a strong and effective role for the Commonwealth in the protection of Australia's threatened species. Future generations will thank you for doing so.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill now before the Senate seeks to implement three initiatives announced in the One Nation statement. First of all, all recipients of family allowance, as of 2 April 1992, will receive a one-off lump sum payment. This payment will be $125 for families with one child, $175 for families with two children, $200 for families with three children, $225 for those with four children, and $250 for those with five or more children. This one-off payment will cost $317m.

PARA.TAB: Second, the rate of family allowance supplement and the family allowance supplement component of pensions and benefits will increase by $6 a fortnight. This increase will be implemented on 3 April for pensioner and beneficiary families and 16 April for low income working families. The increase will be indexed for inflation when the Government introduces legislation to integrate family payments. This initiative will cost $50m this financial year and upwards of $250m for each subsequent financial year.

Third, from 20 March 1992, the Government will abolish the waiting period for rent assistance for all pensioners and beneficiaries apart from those aged under 18 years who are not married and have no dependent children. The decision will cost $15m this financial year and between $34m and $50m for each of the three subsequent financial years.

Before I comment briefly on these three initiatives, I would like to reiterate the Opposition's support for this Bill. As Dr Hewson pointed out so clearly and succinctly in his reply to the One Nation statement, Australian families are suffering greatly as a result of Mr Keating's deliberately engineered recession. There are 920,000 people who are officially unemployed in Australia, while another half a million people are unable to get the hours of work that they want. One in three young people cannot find work. Over the past year, the number of families where the chief breadwinner is unemployed has risen by 40 per cent to 262,000. There are now 218,000 Australian children living in families in which no-one has a job. I should repeat the figure because it is alarming—218,000 Australian children living in families in which no-one has a job. That is a 40 per cent increase on the figure just a year ago. They are damning figures for this Government.

In this setting of personal hardship, it would be niggardly for the Opposition not to support these changes, which will, to an extent, alleviate the financial hardship currently being felt by hundreds of thousands of Australian families. In spite of the coalition's support for these measures, we have a number of concerns which need to be put on the record.

The special family allowance bonus will be paid to all family allowance recipients, irrespective of income. As such, it verges on a regressive payment. A family with one child and an annual income of $62,000 will receive the same $125 one-off bonus as a family with one child and no income will receive. Likewise, a family with five children and an income of $74,000 will receive the same $250 one-off payment as a family with five children and little or no income will receive.

This one-off payment could never be described as an efficient means of targeting government assistance to the most needy in the community. It is quite the opposite, in fact. Families who will remain virtually unaffected by the current recession and enjoy a relatively high standard of living will receive a one-off windfall from the Government in early April. Those families who have been able to shield themselves, relatively, from the effects of this recession will get this as well. Whether these families will spend the windfall payment on necessities and not luxuries is highly debatable. The question must be asked: how much of this $317m of taxpayer's money will be spent by higher income families on luxury purchases and entertainment?

A significant proportion of this handout will go to families that do not have a dire need for it. Analysis of the 1986 ABS income distribution survey, with subsequent income updates in line with the CPI, reveals that there are some 700,000 Australian families with incomes over $40,000 a year receiving family allowance. This includes some 100,000 families with incomes over $60,000 a year. The survey reveals that some 530,000 families have incomes under $20,000 a year, while 790,000 families have incomes between $20,000 and $40,000 a year.

It must be pointed out that the Department of Social Security does not release its own figures on family allowance recipients broken down according to income. The figures from which I have quoted show that 35 per cent, or over one-third, of families receiving family allowance have incomes in excess of $40,000 a year. A significant amount of money could have been saved by targeting this payment to families in greatest financial need. Even in the case of lower income families, who in the main will be able to put this payment to very good use, such as paying off bills and buying necessities for their children, it will not mean an ongoing improvement in their standard of living. To an extent it may minimally alleviate the hardship for a short time. However, once the one-off payment has been spent, these lower income families will again face the harrowing task of paying bills and dealing with a constant flow of demands on their limited resources.

With the $317m the Government is spending on this initiative it could have given over $5 to every family allowance family for a full year; better still, it could have targeted this assistance to lower income families and provided them with a substantial and sustained increase in their overall standard of living. Only last November the Government introduced an assets test for family allowance, claiming the need to target assistance to families who are most in need. But now, in the run-up to both the Wills by-election and a Victorian State election, and with the knowledge that Fightback has captured the support of what is called middle Australia, the Government has opted for a one-off across the board payment to all family allowance recipients. Mr Keating's self-styled prescription for social justice, which is evident in his decision, is most identifiable in the One Nation decision to exclude four million people, or nearly half of Australia's taxpayers, with incomes under $20,700 a year from the Government's tax cuts.

A final point needs to be made about this one-off family allowance payment. Because of its arbitrary nature, it discriminates against needy families who are not eligible for family allowance on 2 April 1992. For example, in the 1990-91 Budget the Government announced that from 1 January 1993 the family allowance would not automatically stop when a child turned 16 but would be paid until the completion of the student's secondary schooling. As this initiative will not commence until 1 January 1993, these families will not benefit from the one-off payment on 2 April 1992, even though they have already been earmarked for family allowance in the 1990-91 Budget and are just as needy as those families who will benefit. Presumably the Government's 1990-91 Budget decision to extend family allowance to school students aged 16 to 18 is based upon its own recognition of the large increase in school retention rates. However, by arbitrarily applying this one-off payment to eligible families at 2 April and not applying it to secondary school Austudy recipients, the Government is in effect choosing to ignore the increased costs being borne by families due to the large rise in school retention rates during the current recession.

The Government's one-off payment, irrespective of income, has to be compared with the targeted increase in family allowance outlined in Fightback. Rather than a one-off payment of between $125 and $250, a coalition government will double family allowance for families with incomes under $30,000—not a one-off payment; a doubling of family allowance to enable a sustained increased in standard of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —To enable you to pay for the GST, you mean.

—Low income families with two children will receive an ongoing increase in family allowance of $40 a fortnight, while low income families with four children will receive an ongoing increase of over $86 a fortnight. Families with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 a year will receive an ongoing 50 per cent increase in family allowance, or $20 a fortnight for those with two children, and $43 a fortnight for those with four children. Families with incomes over $40,000 a year will receive a 6 per cent increase in family allowance.

PARA.TAB: To respond to the interjection from Senator McMullan on the other side, who said that this would help us pay for the GST: families on low incomes have been paying a whopping increase in wholesale sales tax since Labor has been in government and there has been no compensation for that at all.

Unlike Labor's one-off payment, the increases in family allowance contained in Fightback are targeting low income families. Unlike Labor's one-off payment, Fightback will mean a sustained improvement in the ongoing standard of living of Australian families.

I do not want to spend a lot of time talking about the $6 a fortnight increase in the family allowance supplement contained in this Bill. As I said earlier, the coalition supports this initiative as it will help to alleviate some of the hardship faced by families in the current recession. However, unlike the one-off family allowance payment, it is targeted at lower income families and will mean an ongoing increase in their standard of living. For these reasons it is welcomed by the Opposition.

It must be pointed out, however, that this Government does not have a mortgage on compassion for low income families. Far from it. Fightback provides for a 6 per cent increase in the family allowance supplement. It also provides an 8 per cent increase in all pensions, including the sole parent pension, and a 6 per cent increase in all other benefits, including Jobsearch allowance and Newstart allowance. Fightback also provides a $300 increase in the dependent spouse rebate for one income families with children who have an income under $75,000 a year.

In addition, and unlike Labor, the coalition's tax cuts quite deliberately and unashamedly favour low income earners. Under a coalition government, 95 per cent of taxpayers will pay tax at the marginal rate of 30c or lower. The coalition is offering the largest tax cuts in this country's history. Under the coalition's tax regime a person earning up to $75,000 a year will face a lower marginal rate of tax than now applies to those earning just $20,701 a year.

In stark contrast, the Government's tax cuts announced in last week's One Nation statement did not even apply to the vast majority of families who receive the family allowance supplement. Mr Keating's tax cuts will apply only to people who earn more than $20,701 a year, and I presume that, if Labor stays in government—which it will not—wholesale sales tax will keep increasing.

Will Labor tell us all the things in the supermarket on which wholesale sales tax is increasing? I can think of one thing, without naming it, which is used very frequently, and is bought in supermarkets and in pharmacies, which has increased, I think, by $1.57 to $7.00 because of a wholesale sales tax increase from 20 to 30 per cent. Do not tell the public about those things, Senator McMullan.

The Labor Government has deserted its traditional heartland. It is giving to low income earners in one hand by increasing the family allowance supplement but taking from the other hand by excluding these very same people from its proposed tax cuts.

The third initiative in this Bill is the abolition of rent assistance waiting periods for all beneficiaries, excluding people under 18 who are unmarried and without dependants. The coalition supports the initiative, given the fact that there is little hope of finding work in the foreseeable future.

A couple of points need to be made about the abolition of rent assistance waiting periods. It needs to be remembered that only in the last Budget the Government decided to reduce these waiting periods from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. That was only in the last Budget. By now abolishing waiting periods altogether, the Government is in effect admitting that at the time of the last Budget it underestimated the financial hardship faced by people caught up in the recession. I suppose that some people in the bureaucracy believed Mr Keating's repeated promise that we would somehow come out of this recession; the J-curve would come into effect; that he would bring home the bacon; that there was just a bit of effervescence in the glass and everything would be okay. Even Mr Keating's own bureaucrats began to believe the myths that he was putting forward.

Secondly, it must be pointed out that the relaxation of rent assistance waiting periods proposed in this Bill does not appear to be a temporary initiative to alleviate the extra hardship resulting from the recession. This is a disturbing phenomenon. For a number of years both the Government and the Opposition have considered it appropriate for rent assistance to be available as soon as a person became eligible for a benefit. This thinking has been based on a common concern that making rental assistance a de facto benefit would merely increase the incentive for people to rely on welfare.

In a deep recession such as this, I do not believe that such an argument is as relevant because it is virtually impossible for people to switch back and forth between employment and welfare benefits at will. In fact, it is very difficult for people to get employment at all. However, the apparent permanency of this decision to abolish rent assistance waiting periods does indicate a significant change-around in the Government's policy. I think that the Minister should confirm or deny that the Government intends to return to its previous policy once this long running recession is over.

It is of concern to me that the benefits given, in the first part of the Bill especially, are not targeted more effectively. I believe that the Australian public will see the One Nation policy for what it is: a sham and a vote buying exercise, rather than a realistic vision for turning this country around and ensuring that those people who are now unemployed have more hope in the future and that the one in three young Australians currently unemployed have a hope for their young adulthood and their later life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill contains the mechanism for the introduction of the three social security measures announced as part of the Government's One Nation package: the one-off payment of a family allowance bonus to all those families presently eligible for family allowance; an increase in the child amounts paid to certain pensioners, beneficiaries and families receiving family allowance supplement; and the abolition of rent assistance waiting periods for most social security recipients.

PARA.TAB: I want to explore these three separate measures in some detail. However, firstly, I want to look at the more general social justice implications of the One Nation package. This package is really a most disappointing one for those people in this country who have borne the brunt of Paul Keating's recession and who are now unemployed or trying to survive on very low incomes. Perhaps the best that can be said for the One Nation package is that it has marginally more to offer the low and middle income earners in particular than does the Opposition's Fightback package.

This is really the great tragedy of the standard of the political and economic debate in this country at the moment. We have finally come down to some sort of contest—an auction, if you like—between two packages that are not much more than the same tired old economic theories tarted up, wrapped up in fancy packaging, trying to look like something new.

Essentially, both the Government and the Opposition's packages really fail to come to grips with the basic issue facing us today; that is, how can we pull ourselves out of the present recession by pursuing both sustainable economic development and greater social justice? It is this latter point about social justice that I particularly want to take up in the context of this Bill.

While there may be room for debate about the comparative merits of some other aspects of the packages, one thing is pretty clear: genuine social justice for those Australians and their families relying on social security payments or other sources of low income is well and truly on the bottom of both the Government's and the Opposition's agendas.

As Geoffrey Baker observed in the Age earlier this week: . . . both the Government and the Opposition have wept crocodile tears over Australia's poor—and structured their economic packages to maximise the votes of the relatively affluent majority rather than to seriously improve the relative position of the poor minority.

SPEECH.PARA: So Australians concerned about social equity in income distribution are really facing a choice between the lesser of two evils.

The fact of the matter is that Australia's poor will not find much to celebrate in either the Fightback or the One Nation packages. The former is a blueprint for putting the coalition's scorched earth economic policies into practice, while One Nation is an exercise in political survival—long on rhetoric and populist appeal, short on the real courage needed to change economic direction and to place our first priority on getting this country as close as we possibly can to genuinely full employment.

PARA.TAB: I now turn back to the specific measures that are dealt with in this legislation. Firstly, I refer to that one-off payment. The Government proposes to pay a one-off bonus to every family eligible for family allowance on 2 April. The bonus payment ranges from $125 for a family with one child up to $250 for a family with five or more children. Although the bonus will undoubtedly be welcomed by the families receiving it, this is really a somewhat bizarre move by the Government. It comes wrapped up in the guise of a social justice measure, but one can only ask: what is the real purpose? Is it a bribe? Is it a bit of pork-barrelling? Does it have anything to do with a by-election that seems to be rapidly approaching? Is it tokenism of the worst kind, or maybe an off-beat attempt to stimulate the economy?

Its political appeal is obvious, and I for one do not begrudge families what is really pretty minimal assistance, no matter how cynically it has been engineered. But the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) have presented this measure not only as one being useful to people with dependent children, but also as one providing an immediate boost or kick-start to consumer spending.It is rather difficult to see how this claim can be seriously upheld.

For a start, the additional $300m is a mere drop in the ocean of consumer spending. In addition, many of these families will not use the payment to buy consumer goods, despite the urging of the Government. They are far more likely to use it to pay off the debts that they have been accumulating. If they are able to afford to spend this payment, the real risk is that this money will go on imported goods. If the Government is really expecting the payment to stimulate the economy, the least it could do is urge families to use the payment only to purchase Australian goods. As it stands, the $377m boost will, as Ken Davidson put it in the Age last week, `hardly cause a ripple on total consumer spending'.

There is a further problem with this bonus and that is that, yet again, many farm families will be missing out. Because of the inequitable way the assets test on family allowance operates, there will be many well-off city families who will be receiving this bonus while families earning very low incomes, in particular farming families, will be excluded. The problem continues to be the failure of the Government to address an equity problem inherent in the family allowance assets test; that is, the continuing exclusion of the family home, but not the family farm, from the test.

As I have urged and argued in this chamber again and again, this exclusion means that city families could own a home of any value, worth any amount, and have many hundreds of thousands of dollars in non-productive assets before they would be caught by the assets test.

Senator Patterson has already highlighted a number of other inequitable problems that this supposed targeting of this particular benefit will cause. For example, a family with one child living in Melbourne could have a family home worth $200,000 or $300,000, they could have another $20,000 worth of assets and an annual income of $62,000. No problem; they are eligible for family allowance and therefore they will receive a bonus payment of $125 a week upwards, depending on the number of children.Our problem is that a farm family with an income of only $10,000 will be cut out, while a city family earning $62,000 will be able to receive this payment.

I believe that the way in which this payment is being made demonstrates very clearly this Government's inability to come to grips with the structural problems of poverty. Yes, families are going to be assisted, but where is the help for those families on very low incomes who have no children? Where is the help for the single people trying to survive on minimal incomes? We certainly welcome the increases in family allowance supplement, the boost for funding for welfare agencies and a reduction in rent assistance waiting periods. We have been calling for such measures for some time. But these are somewhat hollow gestures in the context of a package that accepts around 8 per cent unemployment for at least the next four years.

With that long term prospect in mind, what does the package do by way of addressing the structural problems of poverty? The short answer is absolutely nothing. Here was a chance to tackle some of those structural problems. For example, the Government could have increased the amount people on pensions and benefits are permitted to earn before losing their entitlement to payment. It could have reinstated young people's incomes back up to the adult level to help them survive. It could have reduced or removed all existing waiting periods for income support, which are constantly causing so much poverty and putting so much pressure on welfare agencies. But the Government has not gone for genuine social justice for the victims of its recession; instead, it has gone for the easy option, the social justice gimmick—the money, not the structural box.

Before I move on to rent assistance waiting periods, I refer to farm families. There are two ways that we can now make sure that this package will go to those needy farm families. We can either look again at removing the tools of trade from the family allowance assets test or—and this will help only some of those children in need, but at least it will help some—we can link the payment not only to the family allowance but also to those children who are currently being assisted under the isolated children's scheme. They are two amendments that we will be pursuing when this Bill moves into the committee stage.

Turning to rent assistance, the move by the Government to abolish the waiting period for rent assistance for most pensioners and beneficiaries is a most welcome one. It is long overdue, but it is gratifying to see the Government finally acknowledging the hardship and suffering that these waiting periods have been causing. The Democrats are particularly pleased to see this move because we have been calling for the abolition or substantial reduction of social security waiting periods for many years. Over the past two years we have continually moved amendments to social security legislation to give effect to the reductions in waiting periods, only to see those amendments opposed by both the Government and the Opposition. It is quite clear that waiting periods cause considerable and unnecessary hardship and that the sole rationale for their existence is to cut costs rather than relieve the suffering of those people who are forced, through no fault of their own, to turn to the Government for income support.

I am very pleased to hear Senator Patterson also supporting this measure. It has been most unfortunate that in the past the Liberals seemed determined to see these reductions as some sort of subsidy to the private rental market. I find this quite strange once I look through the Fightback package. The Opposition's desire is actually to reduce the public housing sector, and I wonder where it thinks low income earners are going to live. This view also very conveniently ignores the fact that housing costs consume the highest proportion of low income earners' incomes, especially if they are renting in the private rental market.

Data collected by the national housing strategy clearly pinpoints the enormous stresses that housing costs place on many low income families, particularly in times of recession when the breadwinner is unemployed. The strategy's data indicates that about 10 per cent of all households in this country are suffering from very severe housing related stress and that many people are paying out up to 50 per cent of their income on rent. I highlight one big problem with rent assistance, and that is that it is not going to be available to those under 18; they have been left out yet again. I ask the Government why, when this age group has been one of the hardest hit sectors of the community, with one in three unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak only briefly on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill because I spoke on the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last Wednesday. This legislation implements that part of the Prime Minister's statement designed to help families kick-start the economy. It contains three elements. The first is a one-off family allowance payment of $125 per child; the second is a $3 increase in the family allowance supplement and the third is the abolition of all rental assistance waiting periods for social security recipients except those waiting periods which apply to single beneficiaries without dependent children who are aged below 18 years.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition agrees entirely with these measures. However, it seems that this is meant to be the Government's answer to the Fightback package. If that is the answer to the Fightback package in relation to families, it certainly is not enough. I will give a brief description of what the Fightback package does for families, as opposed to what the Prime Minister's package does for families, particularly low-income families.

Firstly, the Government does nothing in relation to tax cuts for people who are on $20,700. A person on that income is paying over $49 and does not get 1c back. The poorest in the community do not get a tax cut; they get not a cent back under this Prime Minister's package. Under the Opposition, someone on $20,000 a year would get $814 back. Taxpayers would not be paying the present 20c in the dollar; they would be paying 16.2c above the initial tax-free amount. Secondly, petrol excise would be abolished and the 15 per cent GST would be applied. So there would be a saving of 18c or 19c for every litre of petrol a family used. There is nothing about a reduction in the price of petrol in the Prime Minister's statement.

Under the Opposition, the dependent spouse rebate would be worth an additional $300; there is nothing like that in the Government's statement. Indeed, the dependent spouse rebate under the Government would not go up at all. Under the Opposition, the family allowance will be doubled. There is nothing comparable in the Prime Minister's statement except a one-off payment. Senator Lees is quite right; that one-off payment, no doubt, will be used to pay off the odd debt. Under the Opposition, there will be a 6 per cent increase in the family allowance supplement. Under the Government, it will increase by $3 a week. Under the Opposition the increased family allowance will not only be paid to the poor; part of it will be paid to families on incomes of up to $40,000. The Government does nothing for the poor.

There is nothing in the Prime Minister's statement at all about superannuation incentives. We will abolish the tax on lump sums and there will be many incentives for those on low incomes to take out superannuation. People under 35 buying their first home can dip into their superannuation fund for that purpose to the tune of 75 per cent. Under the Opposition, $2,000 will be given to low income earners to help them buy their first home and 50 per cent of the home's valuation will be not be subject to the GST. There is nothing at all in the Government's statement for home buyers. Under the Opposition, that group can save up to $2,000 tax free. There is nothing at all like that in the Government's statement.

As far as health goes, we all know that under the Government the problems with Medicare will continue. Nothing is being done about it at all. Under the Opposition, the waiting lists will go. Health costs will be zero rated, so there will be no GST on them. If income earners on $20,000 choose to take out private health cover, they will get a $300 tax credit. There are nearly two million contributors to private health funds, people who put priority on private health cover. They will get a tax credit.

There is no comparison at all between the two policies for low income earners. Our policy will give them a tremendous boost. Under the Government's policy all they get is a one-off payment for family allowance and an additional $3 a week in the family allowance supplement. That will not kick-start the economy. All it will do is allow the people to pay off their debts a little more. Even though we support the measure thoroughly, we say the Government has not gone nearly far enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill, of course, follows last Wednesday's One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is an attempt to match the vision and breadth of the coalition's Fightback package and, needless to say, an attempt which falls hopelessly short of the mark.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will, in fact, have very little impact on the veteran community and highlights the fact that Paul Keating's title for his statement, One Nation, is a complete misnomer. The discriminatory approach which has been taken with respect to low income Australians has already been well canvassed by my colleagues and by me. The statement provides no tax relief to nearly two million women on low incomes or to the nearly half a million Australians aged 65 and over on low incomes, a substantial number of whom are veterans and war widows. Veterans or war widows would search the One Nation statement in vain for any measures directly concerning them. There are none.

The question must therefore be asked: where do veterans fit into Mr Keating's concept of one nation, of a country, in his own words, civilised enough to take care of those in need? Surely such a nation can also be civilised enough to properly recognise those who fought to defend its interests. But such recognition is not to be found in the One Nation statement or in the Bill before us. I do not think it can be any coincidence that at the same time as the Prime Minister was launching his statement he was attacking Britain and pushing a republican agenda. He was keen to divert and deflect attention from an inadequate statement and instead to embroil Australia in a debate on republicanism.

No-one disputes Australia's status as an independent country with an increasing focus on the South East Asian region. But veterans and war widows have rightly expressed anger at the insensitive, provocative and most unstatesmanlike manner in which the Prime Minister was seeking to make that point.

The Bill before us will increase the add-on payable to a service pensioner in respect of each child by $6 a fortnight. This increase will take effect from 16 April 1992. While I welcome such an increase for those who will benefit, it is interesting to look at how many are affected. As at 30 June last year, approximately 2,100 veterans were receiving an additional pension for children. In a veteran population of several hundred thousand, a little more than 2,000 gain an increase in pension of $6 a fortnight as part of a measure not devised to benefit veterans, in particular, being more a consequence of a general increase in family allowance supplement.

So if no account has been taken of the veteran community in the One Nation statement, as reflected in the paucity of the Bill before us, what account has been taken of veterans in the coalition's Fightback package? I can assure the veteran community that in the measures contained in the Fightback package the coalition has recognised the special standing of veterans in our community and the debt our nation owes to those who fought for our country.

The need for a package as broad in its scope as Fightback is plain.Australia is currently experiencing the worst recession in 60 years. The impact is being felt in all areas of the community, including the veteran community. For example, in 1990-91 the number of veterans applying for a service pension actually increased over the previous year for the first time since 1983-84. This reflects the increasingly difficult circumstances faced by self-funded retired veterans in a time of national recession.

There has never been a greater need than now for a positive program to turn around Australia's economic fortunes, and the coalition's Fightback package is just such a program. It contains plans for tax reform, incentives for business to employ again and many other measures to rebuild Australia.

As I have said, the interests of veterans are an important element of the package. For instance, an important concern for veterans is the cost of living. It is stated in the Fightback! document that the cost of living increase due to the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax will be a one-off 4.4 per cent. This has been shown by the Government's own analysis to be a conservative estimate. The Government estimates that one-off increase to be only 3.9 per cent.

But the important question for repatriation pensioners is: do the compensation proposals put forward by the coalition package ensure that they are not financially disadvantaged as a result of the introduction of a goods and services tax? The answer is yes. When we were framing our package, a particular concern of the coalition was to ensure that veteran pensioners be more than compensated for the one-off increase in the cost of living. Thus, rather than simply increasing all allowances and pensions by 4.4 per cent, we will be increasing them by 6 per cent and 8 per cent respectively. This means that all service pensions, disability pensions and war widow pensions will be increased by 8 per cent.

For a full service pensioner this will be an increase of more than $600 a year. For a TPI pensioner the increase will be more that $1,100 a year and for a veteran receiving 100 per cent of the general rate, the increase will be $435 a year. War widows will have their pensions increased by $678 a year. Veterans on part service pensions and earning non-pension incomes will have their part pension indexed by 8 per cent and will receive a GST tax credit. This will ensure that, after taking into account non-pension incomes, they are fully compensated for the price impact of the GST.

An important concern for retired veterans is protection of the savings they have accumulated for their retirement. The Fightback package ensures protection of such savings by granting a one-off payment to veterans over 60 and earning less than $30,000. I might add that that is not restricted only to veterans over 60; it will be for all Australians.

Under the present tax system, TPI veterans and certain other ex-service personnel are not required to pay wholesale sales tax on non-luxury cars and essential spare parts. The coalition is mindful of this special recognition of veterans, and consistent with the coalition's philosophy of at least maintaining present veterans' entitlements and, where possible, enhancing them, this special recognition will be continued after the introduction of the coalition's Fightback package. TPI veterans will not be required to pay GST on new cars or essential spare parts, in line with the eligibility conditions currently in operation.

Veterans, like many Australians, will benefit from the new tax free savings scheme. Many veterans and their families will be able to earn up to $2,000 in interest on new savings tax free. Veterans who currently do not qualify for any repatriation health benefits will welcome the decision of the coalition to extend the pharmaceutical benefits card to all those aged 65 and over who are currently not receiving any Government concessions and whose incomes are less that $40,000 a year if single and $50,000 a year for a married veteran couple.

Service pensioners will also further benefit from a number of other measures. For instance, the coalition will maintain the current pension indexation arrangements and make the assets test fairer. Service pensioners who wish to remain in the work force beyond the age of 60 and who qualify for the service pension and agree to defer it will receive a bigger pension as a result, at the rate of an extra 8 per cent for each year of deferment. The income and assets test limits applying to service pensions will be reviewed on a regular basis to ensure that pensioners are encouraged to earn additional income to supplement their pension without losing benefits.

Also contained in the Fightback package are commitments to reform in two important areas of the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. The first is the reform of the repatriation artificial limb and appliance centres, or RALACs. Reviews of the provision of artificial limbs and appliances pointed to serious shortcomings in the efficiency of RALACs and the difficulties facing private manufactures. The coalition believes that positive action must be taken by the Government both for the veteran population and the community generally. The coalition is committed to operating RALACs on a commercial basis with no restrictions on the number of private manufacturers.

Veterans will benefit from better quality and more efficient supply of artificial limbs and appliances. Veterans can be assured that RALACs will continue to be operated by the Commonwealth and that they will still be able to attend the RALACs if they wish to. Of course, limbs and appliances will continue to be available to veterans free of charge.

The second significant reform to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio in Fightback concerns the claims system. The effectiveness and fairness of the claims system is a matter of great concern to veterans and war widows everywhere. The Government concedes that the system is not operating nearly as well as it should and admits that it has no real solutions. One has only to look at the extraordinarily high percentages of Repatriation Commission decisions overturned by the Veterans' Review Board. In Western Australia, for instance, the Veterans' Review Board in 1990-91 overturned 72 per cent of Repatriation Commission's disability assessment decisions—obviously totally unacceptable. The Department concedes that the real problems lie at the first level of the determining system.

The coalition proposes to reform the system, with a central change being to include more ex-service input into the decision making processes. We believe that if veterans and war widows feel that they have had a fair hearing at the first level and that the system that is confronting them is not unnecessarily legalistic and adversarial, then the Government will be more nearly fulfilling its charter of a commitment to a caring and generous approach in addressing veterans' needs. Importantly, the coalition will discuss at all stages with the veterans' community any changes to be made to the claims system. Veteran input is essential if the changes are to be made in a sensible and timely manner.

As I have gone about the country speaking to veterans about the coalition's proposals, and in reading correspondence coming into my office, I have found the overwhelming sentiment to be one of support. Veterans know that the Fightback package offers a real and credible program for dealing with the problems confronting Australia. They also know that the coalition has been particularly sensitive to veterans' concerns. Through deliberately generous increases in pensions and allowances, tax credits for non-pension income, protection of retirement savings and an improved claims system the coalition has reaffirmed its longstanding commitment to the veterans of Australia.

In its management of the Veterans' Affairs portfolio the Government is going to have to demonstrate greater imagination than it is currently showing if it is to meet the increasingly diverse needs of veterans; just as, if Australia is to emerge from the recession as a country with a sound future for our young and the capacity to care properly for our aged, the Prime Minister is going to have to demonstrate a good deal more imagination and vision than was contained in the One Nation statement.

The legislation before us today will be passed by the Parliament. However, the path to prosperity for the people of Australia, including those who fought to protect our freedom, is to be found in the Fightback package, a package which will be fully implemented by the incoming coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, particularly as it relates to the family allowance statement in One Nation. For many years, as the Senate will know, I have been fighting for justice for the family. While I welcome the belated recognition by the Government of the heavy burden which the recession has imposed on families, the One Nation statement and this resulting Bill falls far short of providing social justice. Indeed, the statement is not about social justice. In the words of the Government, it is about kick-starting the economy.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a statement made by the Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, in the House of Representatives during Question Time on 2 March, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the sorts of reasons why we use the family allowance as an ideal way of targeting social security benefit moneys in terms of kick-starting this economy.

So this package is not about the delivery of social justice; it is about getting the economy kick-started. Clearly, that is beneficial—nobody is arguing about that. It is clear that if the money is paid out in family allowances and in family allowance supplements it will be spent and it will be a boost to the economy.

PARA.TAB: What we really need to focus upon is the fact that the family, and particularly the one-income family, has shouldered an undue portion of the burden of this recession. What are the facts? Before I go into the detail of the Bill, let us take a look at the facts. I will enumerate 10 facts.

The first one is that, for an average family, family allowances are worth only two-thirds of their original value. Mr Acting Deputy President, bear in mind the fact that when the family allowance was introduced in 1976 it was done with money which the Government saved from abolishing the tax rebate system. In other words, in most families, it was simply out of the hip pocket and into the purse.

Since then, successive governments have been purloining, stealing, from the purses of Australian mothers. Currently, from the purse of a mother of four, the Government is stealing $50 per fortnight which was put in there in 1976 because of the abolition of the tax rebate scheme.

Fact two is that the weighted average minimum award rate of pay for full time adult employees has fallen in real terms by $60 per week in the last six years. Fact three is that two-thirds of those forced out of the paid labour force recently have been women, many of whom were there because of financial pressure on the family. Now, because of the recession, they are being forced out. My State alone has had a drop in the labour force of 8,100 people in the last three months; 5,300 of them have been women.

Fact four is that job creation has not helped people on unemployment benefits. These jobs have largely been taken up by others. Fact five is that changes in 1992 to parent contributions, school fees, university charges and book costs have all placed additional burdens on parents and students.

Fact six is that there are 5,000 fewer jobs for young people—15- to 19-year-olds—in Tasmania now than there were in January 1990. This is a drop of 25 per cent and is a further burden on the family. Fact seven is that the Government is no nearer to recognising the economic value of housework, which five years ago was calculated as being worth $150 billion a year.

Fact eight is that thousands of families have been forced to relinquish private health insurance because they cannot afford the premiums. In 1984, 54 per cent of Tasmanians were covered. Now the percentage is only 48 per cent. Fact nine is that the family allowance supplement is touted as a help to families, but only one in eight Tasmanian families who receive family allowances are eligible to receive this payment. Fact 10 is that the latest ABS figures show that since September 1991 the recession, as I indicated before, has put 8,100 people out of work, out of the labour force, 1,800 of them in the last month.

That is the background to this Bill. If we are talking about social justice, should those facts not have been considered? The Government is not talking about social justice; it is talking about kick-starting the economy. I am not criticising the Government for that; that is important. I agree with the Government that getting the money into the hands of families will mean money being expended. However, we should not lose sight of the issues of social justice and both vertical and horizontal equity in these areas.

Families have experienced difficulty in coping with the burden of the recession, due in part to the fact that family allowances are on average now worth only two-thirds of their original value. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows the loss per fortnight experienced by families as a result of the decrease in value of the family allowance payments.
Leave granted.
