TALK.START.PARA: —This table shows that, were the Government to have allocated a one-off payment on the basis of social justice rather than necessarily kick-starting the economy, those with more children would not have been so unfairly treated. For example, under the provisions of this Bill the mother of two children will get $175 whereas, based on existing proportions, the payment should have been $250; for three children, instead of $200 the payment should have been $375; and for four children, instead of $225 the payment should have been $542, on the basis of existing proportions. If one is talking about justice and equity, one must remember that it is not the Government's money but somebody else's, on the basis of the tax rebate for children being abolished; that is, it is money belonging to the families.

PARA.TAB: So I say that the fight for the recognition of the rights of the Australian family must continue, until full economic and social justice is achieved and there has been an official recognition of the economic value of the work of the home-maker. We have seen that many of the mothers who have been forced into the paid work force have, because of the recession, been forced out of the paid work force. Where is the net to catch the problems there? Who is going to pay the bills? I accept, acknowledge and agree with the increase in the family allowance supplement. But, as I indicated, only one in eight Tasmanian families is eligible for that. And there are a whole range of families, particularly one-income families, who are finding the struggle almost impossible. That is an issue which must be faced up to by the Government and by the Opposition.

It is all very well to say that the majority of families now are not one-income families. That may or may not be the case at any given time. But at some time most families go through a period when they have to rely on one income. That is what we have to have a look at. That is of concern not only to those families but to every family now. It is of concern to my shop assistants union members. The older ones know that their sons and daughters will go through a period in which their families will have to rely on one income. The younger members of my union in the shops know that they at some stage, although they are now working, will have to go through a period when their family will have to rely on one income.
What has been the percentage change in real disposable income for different types of families on certain taxable incomes? The differences have been quite significant. Let

SPEECH.PARA: me talk about families on incomes of around $30,000. Honourable senators might think that families on incomes of around $30,000 should be able to cope reasonably well. But they are not coping, particularly if they are renting or have a mortgage repayment. And what has happened to those in real terms? I will give that information at some other stage. I have commissioned other research on this matter. But I will now show honourable senators what has happened in terms of the percentage change in real disposable income between 1982-83 and 1989-90 for different family types on a family taxable income of $30,000 per annum on one income and on two incomes.

PARA.TAB: The result for families on one income is on this graph which I have here. Look at it—it is down. Let us look at what has happened for the same family receiving two incomes. Disposable income has increased. What is the Government going to do about that? Is that not of concern to it? Is it not of concern to the Government that, when families go through a period when they have to be on one income, they will suffer a substantial decline in real disposable income? Is that fair? Is that equitable? Is it indeed sensible in the circumstances when there are more people in and seeking paid work than there are jobs available? That will always be the case. We can have all the rhetoric we like. The Government can say how many spare time jobs it has created. But it does not look at the number of full time jobs it has knocked off. One can say what one likes; but unless we look at this problem we will have further pressure on the labour force.

We must be sensible about it. If we cannot be equitable about it, we can at least be sensible about it when talking about employment, because this affects the question of employment as well. I seek leave to incorporate this chart in Hansard.

At some future date we can have a look at a one-income family with four children. We will see the same pattern in what has happened when a family is on one income. It is below the line. PARA.TAB: Finally, I do welcome the belated recognition by the Government of the heavy burden which the recession has placed on families. I do welcome the focus on this issue. It is important. That the Government has decided to do that is to be acknowledged, and I am prepared to stand here and acknowledge it.
I notice that the Opposition has an amendment which says:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate notes that the Government's family allowance proposal is little more than a one-off electoral gimmick—albeit a very costly one—which pales into insignificance when compared to the Coalition's `Fightback' proposal for substantial and permanent increases.

I am prepared to see what the Government does in the Budget before I go along with that assessment. I hope that it is not a one-off electoral gimmick. I am not one to suggest motivations which are not stated or obvious and apparent. Therefore, I am not prepared to go along with it.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, I am not convinced that the coalition's Fightback proposal properly compensates families at various levels for what they will lose on the swings. I fear, from what I have seen, that the compensation proposals in the Fightback package are predicated on an unjustly low base. The Opposition really needs to have a look at that. I support the Bill into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is important because it at least recognises the plight of some millions in the community who are suffering as a result of the recession, and to the extent that we can do anything to alleviate the plight of families in particular, and those who are out of the work force in general, any action ought to be commended.

PARA.TAB: I do not quite understand Senator Harradine's logic in saying that he will suspend judgment until after the Budget, because that Budget, as we know, is another six months away. We are talking about families being in severe financial difficulties right now, and we are being asked to pass judgment on a Bill which will reflect what the Government is doing for them over the next six months.

All we know is that the Government in the area of family allowances is throwing $125 at most families. If that is not an election gimmick, I do not know what is. The timing is exquisite, being in the lead-up to the Wills by-election. It goes completely against what the Government is always talking about in the area of social security, namely targeting. What shows the height of cynicism is that, when we look at the people who are most in need, as reflected by the demands placed on the voluntary agencies, we see that they are being given a derisory $2m to tide them over during this financial year. That is probably not much more than the cost of postage when this cold, heartless, callous Prime Minister starts sending off cheques in the lead-up to the by-election.

To put it in perspective, $317m is going in a one-off electoral bribe and $2m is going to the agencies which are by far best placed to target assistance to the families requiring it. There is simply nothing in this payment to indicate that it will be directed in any way towards demand stimulus, or paying off debts, or consumer spending. As Senator Lees said, it will probably go first towards paying off debts. However, if it is available to people with incomes of around $65,000 to $75,000—as it is; people with five children and an income of $74,000 are entitled to this payment of $250—what do they do with it? At that level they really do not need it. It does not make a great difference to someone on $74,000. Maybe they could buy another hub-cap for Paul's Mercedes, but other than that it is a purely token and unnecessary payment at that level.

For those people at the bottom end it could make a much greater difference but, again, it is not going to do much more than tide them over for a week or two. So it is utterly regressive, which of course goes against all the rhetoric of the Labor Party. It is a one-off gimmick which does not address the ongoing financial difficulties of something like 1.9 million families who currently receive family allowance, nor does it target those who are most in need—those who require emergency relief and various other forms of emergency assistance, as identified by the voluntary agencies. Instead, they get the ultimate in tokenism, not even enough, I would have thought, to tide them over for a week. That is really the calibre of this sort of bribe. I think it is little more than a disgrace.

Senator McMullan and his cohorts are keen to talk about `a fistful of dollars'. Well, this is hardly a fingernail's worth but it is certainly in the same mould. To pretend in any way that this will do anything to alleviate any level of poverty is fanciful in the extreme.

When we look at what the Government has proposed in its `One Job', Paul's job, `Two Nations', rich and poor, statement, we find that something like half the taxpayers in this country will receive no benefit at all. Certainly, those who are on incomes of less than $20,700, which used to be what the Labor Party regarded as its traditional constituency, are getting nothing at all by way of tax cuts.

What sort of explanation do we get from people like Senator Button and Senator Richardson? When we boil it all down the answer is, `Look, they got a pretty good run during the eighties and that's it'. Translated, that means,`They've had it too good for too long. There are no more votes there. Let's move on to the middle classes and see whether we can pick up a few there. We'll throw this sort of money—$250—at families with incomes of $74,000'.

I would have thought that that is obscene—to use a term much favoured by the former Prime Minister—because in no way does it try to alleviate the problems faced by low income earners. It basically ignores them. It is nothing more than a pitch at Wills in the short term and, in the longer term, at the majority of the voters, as the Government sees them,

SPEECH.PARA: the people being crushed by Labor's economic policies, the people who had never even contemplated unemployment—white collar workers—quite frequently now suddenly find themselves redundant and with virtually no future. They are the sort of people that Labor is desperate to get back into the game. As a result we get this totally untargeted and totally unjustified payment being made.

PARA.TAB: Having said all that, I want to make it clear that we are certainly in the business of providing substantial and permanent increases in family allowances. That is why the Fightback package specifically provides a doubling of family allowance payments to families with incomes below $30,000 and, for those families with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000, a 50 per cent increase. Above that figure, the increase will be 6 per cent, which will be more than the inflationary impact of 4.4 per cent.

Therefore, in every respect we have targeted increases in family assistance to those people who most need them. On the other hand, the Labor Party has gone precisely in the opposite direction. I would hope that when members of the Labor Party are alone with their consciences and wonder what their Party philosophy is all about, they will at least have some second thoughts about how they ought to approach this in the next Budget and beyond and look at what market they are really into. The polls might tell us one thing, but I can assure honourable senators that even middle to high income earners expect some compassion from government and do recognise that the most vulnerable are those on low incomes. Those people will not comprehend why the Government is throwing its money around in this fashion.

An amount of $317m, which could have been more effective if spent in almost any other way in the social security system, is instead simply going to be thrown up in the air in effect—the ultimate in non-targeting, the ultimate in transience. As a result, of course, this will be long forgotten beyond the by-election in Wills. But, no doubt, the Government hopes that it will have some sort of psychological effect there; that people getting a cheque in the mail in the lead-up to the by-election will somehow be grateful. Well, I do not think that they are so gullible.

In terms of the $3 per week increase, again no-one would gainsay the proposition that people on low incomes are in need of assistance through the social security system. Of course, we could make it $3, $6 or $9 a week; it really would not matter. If the Government is not going to fund it, at the end of the day it has to come from somewhere, so there will be increased taxes paid by those people as well, no doubt, or there will be a blow-out in inflation or the Government will simply have to print money to cover the cost of it. On that basis, it is a Mickey Mouse arrangement. Unless these things are funded, it is really rather meaningless. So $3 is fine, but unless it comes from somewhere it is nothing more than a short term palliative; it does nothing about longer term assistance for those groups.

By and large, people do not want an extra couple of dollars a week. They want not just income security; they want job security, a stable economy and a low inflation rate. They do not want Mickey Mouse schemes that throw some money at people on an unfunded basis. I cannot possibly imagine anyone being other than utterly cynical about that sort of payment. Nonetheless, it is a Budget measure and no doubt the Government will try to claim some credit for it.

We take the view in regard to the abolition of rent assistance waiting periods that this involves much better targeting. In a sense, it is a nonsense to be making a payment to people after they have been out of the work force for six months. Indeed, people have said to me that they could not understand why they were on what used to be called unemployment benefits and then six months down the track suddenly found that the Government was paying them a bit more to be staying out of the work force.

Clearly, what the Government is trying to do is rationalise the system. However, to suggest that this will do much more than enable landlords to jack up the rent is, I think, overstating the virtue of the initiative. Once again, it does not do much for structural reform. It is really just another way of providing a backdoor increase in allowances and benefit rates from day one. Again, I am sure that if we asked people they would say that that was not the major problem. They want the economy fixed up. They want properly funded initiatives. They want the economy back on track. And they want jobs.
We do not oppose these initiatives. However, I move the second reading amendment standing in the name of the Opposition which has been circulated to honourable senators. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate notes that the Government's family allowance proposal is little more than a one-off electoral gimmick—albeit a very costly one—which pales into insignificance when compared to the coalition's `Fightback' proposal for substantial and permanent increases".

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pity when we get debates such as these dominated by allegations of a `one-off electoral gimmick' and cynicism. I always find that, when one wants to find what motivates people, the first place to look is how they analyse other people's actions. That tells how they think. If they say, `Everybody else does things for self-interest' it probably tells something about their own values. But it does not tell anything about the Government's values. This is actually—

—The fact that you have criticised it comprehensively tells us more about his motives, doesn't it?
—It tells you that we think it is very unfair.
—Why are you quarrelling with me about being critical of your motives?

—I am not saying that the Opposition is evilly motivated. I am saying that it has come up with a conclusion with which I strongly disagree. I have said here in this place that I think it is very good for Australian democracy that we now have two comprehensive packages before Australia.
—You started off by impugning our motives for criticising it.

—Exactly. I think I was right. Senator Alston is entitled to say that an individual has got a policy wrong and we, because we have a different philosophy, come to a different conclusion about the best way to solve social problems. That is a perfectly valid debate.
—Since when have you decided that one-off payments are a better way of targeting than permanent increases?

—If Senator Alston just kept quiet and opened his ears instead of his mouth, which is a very rare event, he may actually learn something although I doubt that he will absorb it. The situation is—if Senator Alston wants to talk about the economics of it, and some absolute economic nonsense has been talked here this morning—that nobody would want to exaggerate the economic significance of a $300m stimulus.

PARA.TAB: The nature of the stimulus and the way it is being paid constitute an absolutely orthodox economic method of giving quick stimulus. There is no other way of so quickly providing economic stimulus than a direct payment to facilitate consumer expenditure. It is much better than tax cuts and much better targeted than tax cuts. The Opposition's obsession with tax cuts is to do with an entirely inappropriate priority. This way is much better targeted, much more effective and much quicker. The assistance goes to the people who need it most directly and it works very successfully.

The reason we have chosen to do it through family allowance and family allowance supplement is the reason that Senator Harradine referred to—that it is both a stimulus and a targeted stimulus. He was absolutely correct about that and that is what this does. It is a very straightforward thing. People can pore over it to find all sorts of complex motivations and get themselves in a lather—and I hope they do because it probably stops them from doing any more serious mischief—but it will not advance the course of public debate in Australia at all.

Let us just look at this objectively within the broad parameters of the One Nation package. This is a very simple, straightforward economic stimulus of a very orthodox economic nature which is targeted very successfully to people in need. There is some view that people will use it to just pay off their debts. I have to say that that is not a crisis. It will reduce but not remove the element of stimulus within it. When we see the vox populi on television and families being asked what they are going to do with this, they have not been saying, `We are going to use it to pay off the debt'. They have been making very sensible statements about things which they will do with it to assist themselves, to assist their families and children. That is a wise thing for them to do and it is what they are most likely to do.

If I might refer to something of a diversion from Senator Lees, it is also why it is unlikely to flow into imports. Of course, any expenditure has a propensity in some part to flow into imports. That is inevitable. But the sorts of expenditures that are likely by people who are getting the money are much less likely to flow into imports than are many other sorts of stimuli—including, I might say, tax cuts. Even if the money goes to pay off debts, it changes the capacity of those people subsequently to enter into other commitments. The money, when it goes to pay off debts, does not disappear. It stays in the economy as a stimulus applying a little more indirectly.

When one looks at the motivation, one sees that it is primarily a quick stimulus which will, by all the conventional economic analysis, create some several thousand jobs. It is targeted directly so that the money goes to those in need, as everybody has agreed it should.

There are other worthwhile initiatives: the continuing increase in the family allowance supplement and the change to the rent allowance. There has been no Opposition criticism of those proposals. I welcome their support.

A second reading amendment has been moved by Senator Alston with great enthusiasm—which I think everybody would have noticed—and with his usual passion, verve and commitment regarding these things. He said that the coalition's Fightback proposal will provide substantial and permanent increases in payments to people. However, it is misrepresentation for the Opposition to say that these expenditures compensate people for the GST and then at the same time laud itself for giving people increases. If it is compensating people for the GST, it is not making them better off; it is simply changing the nature of the cash flow in people's family budgets.

We have had a little controversy, with people getting a bit agitated, because I said that under the GST the price of food will go up by 8 per cent. The Treasury analysis, which Opposition senators have quoted when it has suited them during this debate—Senator Newman is entitled to do so; she picked those parts of the Treasury analysis with which she agreed and quoted them—makes it quite clear that under the GST package the price of food will go up by 8.9 per cent: fruit and vegetables by 10.1 per cent; clothing by 11.2 per cent; other necessities such as electricity by 10.7 per cent; and post and telephone by 8.1 per cent.

Some things will get cheaper, as we all know. Luxury cars will get cheaper, jewellery will get cheaper and fur coats will get cheaper. I am sure that the beneficiaries of this package understand that that combination of things would make them much better off. They will say, `We will give up food and buy another Ferrari'. It is a nonsense to talk about the elements of the Fightback package as making the beneficiaries of this package in any way better off.

Senator Harradine talked about stimulating the economy and targeting assistance. There are alternative ways of kick-starting the economy. One can provide consumer stimulus in other ways, but no way more effectively targets assistance than this combination of measures. That is why we chose it. Senator Harradine made a point which is slightly off the point but which I wish to refer to because it is important to put it on the record regularly. Senator Harradine used a slightly different emphasis than I would, but nevertheless he was correct. He said that what we are spending is not the Government's money. Every dollar we spend is, in one sense, taxpayers' money. We should spend it in the knowledge that we are the trustees of other people's money, rather than thinking of ourselves as a source of generosity, giving away our own money to people who may well deserve to receive it. I think the taxpayers of Australia would agree that that is an appropriate way to be doing it. But it is important to put on the record from time to time that that is the case.

If people think we are mugs enough to believe that we are going to get a great rash of electoral support for these expenditures, they underestimate us and they underestimate the Australian voters. The Australian electors will support these measures to the extent that they think it is a sensible thing to do and that they are good policy. I think they will support them. But to say that people are going to flock in droves to change their vote because their bank account gets a direct injection is an extraordinary proposition; it is a measure which has never worked.

In 1987 the Opposition tried it with an extraordinary set of tax cuts that were funded by a very unfair set of expenditure cuts. The voters, quite understandably, rejected it. The opinion polls made it clear that the voters said, `Yes, I understand that I would be better off under this proposal, but the country will be worse off'. They voted against it, and they were absolutely right to do so. They will do the same with regard to Fightback as the year advances and the choice is made between the options that are before the Australian people. I remain optimistic about the choice they will make.

I welcome the debate on this Bill and the support for the measures within it. I reject some of the motives attributed to the Government, but let us not quibble about that. I am pleased that people are supporting the legislation. I will worry about the substantive amendments when we get to the committee stage later this evening. I oppose the Opposition's second reading amendment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move an amendment to Senator Alston's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after be `gimmick' be omitted.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have great problems with Senator Alston's amendment. I worry sometimes when I agree with Senator Alston on issues, but I also have great problems with the targeting of this legislation. I think we really do have to look very carefully at the motives behind it. For example, if there were $300m going, we could have looked at more than the welfare agencies, which, in many cases, are not able to give relief on anything more frequent than a three-monthly basis. SPEECH.PARA: These amendments give effect to the sort of changes which would often be supported, in particular, by Senator Watson and, I would think, in general by the coalition. I would be surprised if the coalition did not support these amendments today.

We think that the authority will operate effectively, notwithstanding these amendments. Whether we think they are improvements or not is a question we will discuss another time. We are agreeing to the amendments and, hopefully, we can proceed with them fairly quickly.

—I am not surprised that the Government is agreeing to the amendments. The Government wants to set up a new bureaucratic structure, and I have already heavily criticised this approach to solving the problems. I think the amendments Senator Bell has put forward really flow from the fact that we are doing this exercise. The Opposition is not going to oppose these amendments. I noticed that Senator McMullan, representing the Minister, was pretty lukewarm about them. Perhaps the only thing to be said for this Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1991 is that the agency has a short life; there is a sunset clause that will bring it to a close in two and a half years or something like that. It is not as though it is a structure that is going to be there for very long for Parliament to give detailed concern to, as it might do if it were setting up an agency for some length of time. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991. This is an omnibus Bill covering, once again, a wide range of taxation measures, some highly technical and, consequently, quite complicated. Before I go into that, the March 1991 statement, especially the depreciation provisions, was designed—over 12 months ago now—to kick start the economy. Unfortunately, because of the problems in framing legislation, procrastination and delays, we are only today seeing the legislation to cover some of the outstanding issues of the March 1991 statement.

PARA.TAB: The result has been that many corporations have actually delayed, rather than brought forward, their investment programs. I remind the Senate that there will be a further delay as a result of the further changes to depreciation announced in the One Nation statement.

Again, measures which were designed to kick-start the economy will not have the effect that was intended because there is going to be no legislative base. Mr Deputy President, you will recall that this morning I put before this chamber a notice of motion calling on the Government to bring forward its legislative program, particularly in relation to depreciation, in order that companies can have some certainty and encouragement to bring forward, rather than delay, their investment programs. Unfortunately, the changes are just seen as another delaying technique.

The legislation before us at the moment has been introduced to plug loopholes, to correct anomalies and to address a number of outstanding issues. In doing so it has created a number of new flaws and new problems. This has added a great deal of confusion for the taxation profession and to companies seeking investment. It will be necessary to introduce new amendments to cover the depreciation changes announced only last week in the 1992 Federal economic statements.

It is incumbent upon the Government to introduce speedily legislation which will, for example, remove the delay as to the future of the 20 per cent loading that has been enshrined in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991. With all the changes announced in the One Nation package, the coalition is concerned that there will also be a resultant legislative bottleneck later on in this session and we can only hope that there will be appropriate time allowed for discussing, in this chamber, some of the difficult provisions that arise from the February One Nation statement and that will have to be brought before the chamber.

The legislation before us today does not cover the 1992 economic statement. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 is dealing with measures announced largely in the March 1991 economic statement, by earlier press releases and by some unannounced items.

The Bill contains over 16 significant amendments which include changes to depreciation allowances, anti-avoidance provisions relating to deduction recoupment, balancing adjustment, partnership roll-over relief under the capital gains tax, dividend rebate and deferral of deductions from prepayments of trading stock, as well as changes to the tax file number system. There are also changes in the taxation of foreign source income and substantiation discretion in relation to the fringe benefits tax.

The depreciation amendment figures most significantly. For a year now industry has been writing submissions and complaining about the constant watering down of what was originally announced last year. Today, we still have before us what I call an interim result. Why? Because the Government will be making further changes to the depreciation regime following this February economic statement.

For a government to bring to fruition legislation announced 12 months ago and then announce changes again is a tragedy. Some time ago the Australian Taxation Office developed the slogan—and I complimented the Office on it—`A service orientated office'. Again, it is unfortunate that this Government, which administers the Australian Taxation Office, does not show the same commitment to its taxpayers or to its constituents as does the Australian Taxation Office.

Why? We have had questions on taxation issues on the Notice Paper for up to five months and they are still outstanding. In an environment of self-assessment which demands a regime of certainty, the Australian Government is simply taking the Australian taxpayers far too cheaply. Already most parliamentarians' phones and fax machines have been running hot with requests from accountants for knowledge about the starting dates and the implications of the new depreciation arrangements, particularly in relation to the effect these arrangements will have on the Bill now before us. There is confusion and uncertainty. This seems to be the outcome of most things the Government touches, especially in the taxation field at the moment.
The legislation before us and the expected legislation make a mockery of this Government's comment in last year's statement when Prime Minister Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have radically overhauled depreciation provisions to bring them more in line with business realities.
It certainly attempted to do that then and has again because it did not get them right. Mr Keating continued in the same vein, saying:
These reforms will have many positive benefits as they provide taxpayers more discretion, greater certainty, and enhanced simplicity.

People should have a look at the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 and see whether it brings about more simplicity. The industry does not have simplicity, certainty and more discretion. In the present economic situation and the announcement once again of the country's imports rising and exports declining in this month's balance of payments figures, businesses are looking towards the Government for incentives to encourage Australia's export performance. We are getting these things on paper and in press releases but we are not getting them into legislation sufficiently quickly to give businesses the certainty to go ahead with these so-called programs. This is because the statements are phrased in such a way as to lack clarity.

PARA.TAB: Australian companies, therefore, are choosing not to enter the export markets. Why? Because Australia's inhibiting tax laws are destroying investment potential. The changes announced last month to depreciation regimes were intended to boost exports. This week's current account figures certainly do not testify to the achievement of that grand objective.

On 24 January, Martin Soutter from the Business Council of Australia described Australia as having basically a repair and maintenance-type economy, whereas dynamic economies are those constantly replacing capital stock with state of the art equipment. He states that part of the reason we have done as we have done is the way our tax law works. This Government did start with some change to the depreciation regime last year, but unfortunately it could not get it right. Therefore, I now wish to examine the technical aspects of the Bill and point briefly to the areas which need re-examination.

I intend to use the committee stage of this Bill later this month for a deeper and more meaningful explanation of the technical aspects. I think it is unfortunate that we have this Bill before us without any amendments. I believe that amendments could be introduced at the committee stage and I look forward to them. If the Government cannot produce the amendments to cover a number of deficiencies, the Opposition certainly will.

The proposed meaning of `effective life' leads the list. Last March, the new definition of effective life under a system of self-assessment was introduced. By September, the newspaper headlines were crying, `No significant changes to depreciation rate'.

The present arrangements, as outlined in this Bill, will only add uncertainty to a taxpayer's calculation of effective life. Every taxpayer will be expected to determine effective life objectively by reference to the use of the item of plant and equipment, not only by himself, but also by future owners. The limiting aspect of the definition is the property's use for income producing purposes by any person—a great qualification which is put on the initial person who acquires that plant.

Thus, the life of second-hand plant restricts the value of the amendment to the first purchaser of the plant. This is regardless of the fact that, on a subjective test, the item may no longer by utilised by a particular taxpayer. The concept of economic obsolescence is not recognised in the proposed definition of effective life.

I therefore urge the Government to consider a more appropriate definition, such as a reference to the estimated life of a item of plant or equipment which it will have in the ordinary course of the proposed income producing activities, taking into account such factors as expected circumstances of use of the item by the taxpayer, whether the expected life of the item is restricted by the duration of a particular project in which it is to be used, and predictable obsolescence.

A definition along these lines will permit a taxpayer, electing to make a determination as to effective life, to write off in whole the cost of the plant over the period ascertained. For example, a taxpayer permitted to depreciate an item over a five-year period under the existing depreciation rates might determine that the effective life of the plant in his or her own circumstances is perhaps four years. A taxpayer under such a system would not be required to have regard to the possibility that the item might have some alternative income producing capacity beyond the period that the taxpayer regarded as unproductive.

If the taxpayer sought to write off an item at a faster rate than could be justified, not only at the time of acquisition but also some years later when the auditors come in—the effective life could subsequently change due to changes in technology or as a result of changes in demand—an audit adjustment would be made rendering the taxpayer liable to a penalty.

Problems also occur with the transitional rules dealing with the introduction of effective life rates of depreciation as they are unnecessarily complex, especially for companies with substituted accounting periods. Companies with substituted accounting periods have simply put off their investment programs because of the uncertainty and complication. The effective life rates apply to property acquired after 1 March but not applicable until 1 July 1991. A company with a substituted accounting period is not able to use the broadbanded depreciation rates until the start of its 1991-92 year of income. Clearly, the record keeping requirements in such a case are overly onerous for a change in the law that was designed to simplify the depreciation regime. They are counterproductive.

Again, problems occur with the new pooling arrangements. Proposed new section 62AAC requires a taxpayer to give a written notice of the creation of a depreciation pool within six months of the end of the year of income. This six-month period is at odds with the general requirement that corporate income tax returns must be lodged within 8 1/2 months of the end of the year of income. There is no reason why the written notice is required any earlier, especially as it appears that, under self-assessment, there is not a requirement to lodge it with the Commissioner of Taxation.

Depreciation of plant which is acquired part way through the year cannot be pooled. Depreciation must be calculated not by the straight line method but by using the diminishing value method. It appears that the new One Nation statement will make it mandatory for depreciation to be calculated on a reducing balance method. That is not convenient for a lot of companies with fairly regular and not complex investment programs which might be suited to the straight line depreciation method. These companies will have to switch over and change their computer systems just to suit this particular whim of government.

With these pooling arrangements, the plant may then be allocated to the relevant pool in the following year. This aspect is unnecessarily cumbersome and requires virtually all plant—other than that which happens to be bought on the first day of the year of income—to be depreciated in the normal way before it can be depreciated under the pooling approach. One is losing many of the benefits in the initial year of the pool.

This requirement appears to be at odds with the stated objective of pooling, as outlined in proposed section 62AAB, which is to provide a simplified method of depreciation. It is not simplified; it is complicated. I would suggest that an alternative might be to allow half of the normal depreciation rate as a deduction in the first year in which items are brought into the pool. That would solve the problem. I ask the Minister: what effect will the 20 per cent loading enshrined in this Bill have when we have this new rate? I understand that it is going to be substantially changed for part of the tax scales. This will only add confusion to confusion.

Another problem which has surfaced is that industry feels confused as to whether it should use the Australian Taxation Office depreciation schedules. Clause 16 repeals section 55 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which currently sets out the basis of depreciation, including how effective life is to be calculated with, in particular, a recognition of the fact that the Commissioner is currently authorised under that section to determine the effective life of units of property.

This is presently evidenced by income tax order 1217, which sets out a schedule of depreciation rates for various items of property. Because of the repeal of this section, technically a taxpayer has no authority to rely on any rates that may be set by the Commissioner in an ancillary document such as ITO 1217. Consequently, regardless of what is said in the explanatory memorandum, a taxpayer may in fact be open to penalties under the law for adopting such a rate—how ridiculous—in the absence of any evidence to support effective life being adopted, because proposed subsection 54A(1), does not contain any words authorising the taxpayer to adopt the rates set out by the Commissioner.

I say to Senator Tate that I trust that the Government will introduce amending legislation to correct this dreadful unintended consequence, and I look forward to seeing the amendment at the committee stage—I understand it is not ready yet. It is incumbent on the Government to introduce that amendment.

Thus, a taxpayer who used the Tax Office depreciation schedules because they gave a more favourable result will be relying on the goodwill of the Office not to challenge it at a later date. We cannot have such a situation in tax law. Consequently, there should be imported into section 54A (a) a specific reference allowing the taxpayer to adopt, as an alternative, any estimate of effective life set by the Commissioner.

As I stated at the outset of this speech, the legislation before us has been produced to overcome anomalies in the present taxation Act. However, in doing so, more problems have been created. This is especially so with the legislation that has been designed to clarify a major area of uncertainty in corporate tax laws. The terms of the proposed section 45Z in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) throw into doubt the availability of rebates of tax under section 46 in respect of dividends received through unit trusts by unit-holders which are resident companies. Proposed section 45Z applies only where the beneficiary is `absolutely entitled' to the relevant shares, and therefore may deny a rebate where the dividends are received through discretionary or unit trusts. That is an impossible situation.

If the proposed section is not amended to secure the dividend rebate to corporate unit-holders, multiple taxation of company profits distributed as dividends will be imposed on this class of investors. Consequently, existing corporate unit-holders may need to sell their units, and prospective corporate unit-holders will not in future invest in the unit trusts which acquire equities. The coalition urges the Government to take immediate steps to expand proposed section 45Z to make it clear that corporate unit-holders in a trust are entitled to a section 46 rebate to the extent that distributions represent dividends received by the unit trust from exempt companies.

It has been a longstanding practice for the Tax Office not to deny the dividend rebate claimed by corporate unit-holders in respect of the dividend component of unit trust distributions received from public investment trusts. I refer the chamber to past issued rulings of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation which confirm the granting of the section 46 rebate to corporate unit-holders in large `public' unit trusts which carry on investment activities and are division 6 trusts; hence the anomaly.

To penalise such unit trust investors when compared to shareholders in investment companies is to discriminate against unit trusts, which are a long established and important sector of the economy for the collection of private savings for investment. Such treatment offends against the basic tenet of neutrality in a fair and efficient taxation system.

I was interested to note that one correspondent to the Australian Financial Review on this topic expressed that he was pleased that the Government was finally giving statutory legitimisation so that the corporate rebate on dividends is now available to beneficial owners of shares registered in the names of nominees. The law is to be changed retrospectively to 17 August 1976, the date of the High Court's decision.

Consequently, it effectively removes any personal liability on the officers of the Tax Office for not technically enforcing the law for the last 25 years. I ask Senator Tate what sort of legislation that is. Treating taxpayers equally and protecting officers of the Tax Office who apply commercially sensible practice should be axiomatic in any system. But the question arises as to why it was thought necessary in the Bill to exclude from the benefit of this retrospective legitimisation those few taxpayers to whom the Tax Office had not applied the practice. Why should they be discriminated against? I mention one name which I think is relevant. Why was Adelaide Steamship selected while everybody else was let off the hook? With this legislation we retrospectively let everybody else off the hook. This discrimination is just intolerable in any system, and I note that Senator Tate is nodding.

In respect of the amendment for anti-avoidance deduction recoupment—that is, for roll-over relief—the measures in this Bill effectively force companies that want to transfer assets within a corporate group to adopt market value where those assets are subject to deduction recoupment provisions. There appears to be an overemphasis on the claim that the amendments are required to deal with tax avoidance arising out of these provisions. That is just a nonsense. In effect, with the advent of capital gains tax—save in respect of motor vehicles, pre-CGT assets and assets which may not constitute separate assets, under section 160P, for the purpose of capital gains tax—many of the opportunities no longer exist. There may still be some deferral advantage available. In these circumstances, to justify the amendment solely on the basis of anti-avoidance measures must be questioned.

The combined effect of these measures is to add considerable further complexity to corporate group reorganisations where there appears to be little scope for avoidance. For example, for the vast majority of items of depreciable plant, the market value is not significantly different from the tax written down value. For administrative convenience, assets have normally been treated intra-group at book or tax written down values. This practice has had wide acceptance. In situations where the market value of assets may be greater than their written down value, companies will now be called upon to undertake a separate review to determine the tax impact, or ensure that capital gains roll-over tax is elected, if available. This is just a nonsense—and extra work for corporations.

For taxpayers with high volumes of depreciable plant the vast majority of which would not generate a CGT gain or loss, this is an unwarranted additional burden in record keeping. For taxpayers in groups with less than 100 per cent common ownership because of, say, preference share financing, CGT roll-over is not available. These companies cannot avoid the effects of the deemed market value disposal. The tax impact of this measure to the group can be deferred where capital gains tax roll-over relief is utilised.

When the balancing adjustment roll-over relief amendment is examined, the coalition fears that there will be situations where it may be difficult for the transferee to obtain full details from the transferor of depreciation previously claimed on an item of plant and equipment acquired by the transferee. That is a practical, everyday problem.

This amendment highlights the problems that arise when we have a government that insists on legislating by press release. Taxation and business commentators have warned time and time again that the practice is fraught with danger, as so often happens when legislation does not use the words of the press release or the press release is ambiguous. In this case we have a press release proclaiming balancing adjustment roll-over relief of which the tax profession was generally unaware. The explanatory memorandum advises that the measure was announced on 8 December 1990. But on investigation we find this did not occur. Apparently the press release involved, No. 119, was withheld from circulation on the planned 6 December issue as a mark of respect for the sudden death of Chris Higgins, Secretary to the Treasury.

On 8 March another unnumbered release was announced. The press release in question was also not distributed by the Australian Taxation Office as a result. Fortunately, unless taxpayers have decided not to roll-over because of recoupment of depreciation issues, et cetera, they have not been seriously disadvantaged. They have six months from royal assent to make an election and request an amended assessment. At another time the consequences could have been worse.

Finally, I would like to point out some of the technical problems, which I shall also raise during the committee stage, associated with several other amendments within this Bill. I am pleased to see that the Commissioner is being granted a discretion when applying the substantiation rules in the fringe benefits tax legislation. This is a further extension of my private member's Bill several years ago, which was subsequently adopted by the Government. At the time it only moved so far as income tax was concerned, although the second leg did relate to the fringe benefits tax. We have had to wait all that time for the discretion that has now been built into the fringe benefits tax regime through this legislation.

Unfortunately, I still have some queries with this discretion. The requirement of proposed section 123B(1)(a) is that the Commissioner be satisfied that `a benefit has been provided in, or in respect of, a year of tax in respect of the employment of an employee of an employer'. It is difficult to understand why the Commissioner needs to reach a state of satisfaction as to the provision of a benefit. If no benefit has been provided there will be no need to consider the application of the substantiation rules and therefore no need to ameliorate their impact. That is quite obvious.

Declarations are a significant operational aspect of the fringe benefits tax legislation and have the effect of reducing the taxable value or giving effect to an exemption. They are substantiable materials in another guise. The amelioration provided by the provisions before us should extend to declarations. I am concerned that the full substantiation relief granted by section 82KZAA(1)(c) in the Income Tax Assessment Act is also conveyed in proposed section 123B of the fringe benefits tax legislation. I shall examine this more closely during the committee stage.

In the amendment dealing with the deferral of deductions for trading stock purchases involving prepayments, the most obvious defect in that provision is that, if the goods never come on hand because they are dealt with by the purchaser between the time of ordering them and the time of their delivery when they would ordinarily constitute trading stock, no deduction would be allowed under section 51(1), as it is currently drafted, therefore denying a legitimate deduction. This is another travesty of justice.

I am pleased, however, to see that the Government has allowed for a maximum deduction of up to 150 per cent of expenditure for qualifying plant claimed over three years in three equal instalments if that plant is first used prior to 30 June 1992.

With regard to division 10AB, which was introduced by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and which allows a deduction for certain costs incurred in rehabilitative mining, quarrying and petroleum sites, the Bill before us aims to clarify the operation of the division. However, it fails to address one critical aspect, which is the meaning of the word `site'. Considerable uncertainty exists within the mining industry as to what expenditure is covered by the division when site rehabilitation is undertaken. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) presents the perfect opportunity to rectify the situation, and I hope that we will see an amendment clarifying this definition.

Mr Deputy President, as time is fast going I will just mention a few other points of concern: the foreign exchange gains and losses provisions, the capital gains tax roll-over relief for partnerships, the taxation of foreign source income and the tax file numbers.

Overall the coalition supports the thrust of the Bill but it condemns the number of flaws contained in it and deplores the time that it has taken to bring this legislation into effect. We also condemn the Government for its inability to legislate with certainty and clarity on the depreciation issue. We urge the Government to introduce amendments to clarify the confusion that exists where there is a chain of ownership between companies in a corporate group, and to take into consideration all the other matters that I have addressed during the few minutes that have been made available to me. I look forward to further debate during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, we are today finally debating Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). As Senator Watson pointed out, it is probably the longest standing Bill on the Notice Paper. Certainly, we are debating it very belatedly. Although it is still only an interim Bill, it is the first Bill I know of that is likely to be out of date before it has been debated. Although the measures contained in this Bill were announced in the 12 March statement of last year, they have been overshadowed by the One Nation package of February of this year.

PARA.TAB: I suppose things have gone so far down the track—and Senator Tate will probably agree—that we could just about call it retrospective legislation. The effects of the Bill will not be around for very long because further legislation will be introduced eventually.

The aspect of the Bill worst affected by the delay—Senator Watson mentioned this briefly—is the one relating to the purchase of plant. In the 12 March statement we were given the idea that there would be far more use of accelerated depreciation of the effective life. People contemplating the purchase of mining machinery—the mining industry is the one with the most to gain from this Bill—were all wondering when this was coming into effect, because the 12 March statement put no starting date on it—although I stand to be corrected on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Watering down.

—Yes, watering down. What happened then was that the people who wanted to buy big gear—in mining people do not buy an item of plant, even a very small one, for much under half a million dollars; it is mostly around the $700,000 to $1m mark per item—could see that there was going to be a change, because there was a bit of talk going around before the announcement of 12 March, and they just stopped buying and waited to see what the rules were going to be.

PARA.TAB: Then 1 July arrived but still nothing had been done. Senator Watson and I were screaming in this place asking when the legislation would be introduced. But the Bill did not arrive. Between 12 March and July and beyond there was pressure from the earthmoving industry and the people who sell the gear to make the new definition effective from 12 March. The Government agreed to it. I do not know when the Government agreed to do that. I never saw it in writing.I only found out about it when I got the memorandum. Let us say, for example, that the Government agreed to that in October—I certainly do not know when it happened—then there would have been a resultant 12 months loss of production due to new machines sitting in yards at, for example, South Guildford in Western Australia, where the Caterpillar gear is.

That equipment was sitting doing nothing when it could have been out in mines generating wealth for Australia and replacing older machines. The machinery distributors were left in the lurch. They had servicemen and salesmen doing nothing but waiting for the Government to make up its mind about the legislation. Of course, the gear bought after 12 March 1991 will now have these measures applied to it.

We then get back to the other story: one set of rules applying from 12 March 1991 to 30 June 1991 and another set of rules applying from now on. Equipment will be written off under two different systems. Who wins out of this? I believe that the only winners are the accounting firms. The present Government, with its amendments to taxation legislation—we have about four changes a year—has created more work for the accountants and more work and costs for people using the accountants. The situation is heavily in favour of accountants.

I now turn to the finer points of the Bill. I would firstly like to address the depreciation provisions in the Bill. They can briefly be described as the re-definition of `effective life'—which Senator Watson has already spoken about—and the broadbanding and pooling of equipment. `Effective life' means the time over which an item of equipment can reasonably be expected to be used for income generating purposes by any person. My experience in regard to buying equipment—especially equipment with motors—is that such equipment can be expected to have an effective life of five years. It is written off in a straight line over five years. Although I suppose that, really, with diminishing value it would be written off in about four and a half years.
We now have proposed a change in the meaning of `effective life'. Senator Watson said that we have to have regard to the use to which equipment will be put after the first owner has disposed of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a nonsense.

—It is an utter nonsense. How can we really tell what condition a machine will be in at the end of that time? How can we tell what sort of use that machine will be put to after it is sold? After the initial five years use of the machine it could be sold, for example, to a contractor who will really work it 24 hours a day and thus get only 12 months use out of it or it could be used on a farm—say it is a front end loader—where it will last another 15 years. Who can tell? It is an utter nonsense.

PARA.TAB: I believe that depreciation measures will be far worse as a result of this Bill than they have been before. We need to look at total effective life. I can see no real incentive in this Bill for industry, whether the earthmoving industry, the farming industry or the mining industry, to spend more on new equipment to increase production. There may be incentives by way of an upturn in the economy—if that is ever going to happen under this Government—or an upturn in iron ore or gold prices or an upturn in rural production to encourage people to reinvest in equipment. But I can see no reason why business should invest in new machinery more quickly than they had expected because of the measures in this Bill.

Since the measures we are debating now, which came out of the 12 March statement, new measures have been introduced to try to improve on the package. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there are no incentives in the One Nation package. Investment allowances are narrowed, and we will debate that. It has only taken the Government from last March to February to work out that the` effective life' provisions and new depreciation schedules were hopeless. The package we are dealing with now went through the House of Representatives only 24 hours before the new package was announced.

Industry is concerned about the Government's effective life provisions. Who is going to work out what the effective life of a machine is when they have to look at what someone else down the track may be doing? What one really has to do, I believe, is look at the economic life of the machine. One works a machine for so long until one can see that it is not producing enough and so on. One must look at how it can be improved, technologically or otherwise, not at what it may or may not do.

Broadbanding has been covered very well by Senator Watson so I will not go into it in detail. The idea is to reduce the number of scales by which one can depreciate to seven: 33 1/3, 20, 15, 10, 7 1/2, 5 and 2 1/2. Anything over 33 per cent is written off in one year.

The Bill provides that anything up to $300 can be fully deducted in the first year. In the earthmoving game, one starts off at about $500,000 for the first item, and then one goes to the other end of the scale where one can write off immediately in one year anything up to $300. I think this is a nonsense. Having had experience in the game of depreciation and those sorts of things in business, I believe—to throw a figure into the air—that anything under $2,000 should be written off immediately rather than setting up a schedule with accounting fees that will go on it. It costs just as much to set up a depreciation schedule for $301 as it does for $33,000 or $300,000. So I believe that the figure of $300 is ridiculously low. It only causes book work for nothing. I believe that a starting figure should be at least $2,000, if not more.

I turn to something that this Government is very fazed about, that causes it to jump at every shadow. It has to dangle it in front of everyone to pick up the few idle votes around that it may still be getting. I refer to the anti-avoidance measures. The Minister's second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: In some instances, the existing law allows taxpayers to nominate as the selling price of an asset the lesser of its market value and its tax written down value. This rule can result in tax avoidance where an asset with a high market value and a low written down value is disposed of by a taxpayer to a related entity at the lower value. If the related entity then sells the property at its true market value, the proceeds cannot be treated as a recoupment of the previous owner's deductions.

Senator Button, in reply to a question, made quite a bit of noise about this last year. However, the Minister in his second reading speech left out a very important aspect; that is, that anyone doing that would have been picked up by the capital gains tax provisions.

PARA.TAB: If I can briefly indicate how this comes about: a machine or an item of plant is written off completely over five years, and on the books it is worth $10 or $100. If that machine or item of plant is sold for $2,000, the difference between those amounts is a profit because the owner has to allow for what he has recouped through his taxation deduction. Of course, that has to be accounted for. The explanatory memorandum shows us how the Government has gone overboard:

SPEECH.PARA: . . .the plant depreciation provisions require a reconciliation to be made between the consideration for a disposal of depreciated property with its depreciated value (ie. the cost of the property less the amount of deductions allowed).
2.4. Any excess of the consideration for disposal over depreciated value—
this is what the Minister had to say about depreciation recoupment—

is assessable to the extent of deductions allowed to the taxpayer disposing of the property. (Any consideration for disposal which is in excess of the cost of the property will fall for consideration under the capital gains tax provisions).

It is here in the explanatory memorandum for the Government to read. Yet in his second reading speech the Minister very conveniently left it out. I suppose that, for political purposes, if people think there is wholesale taxation evasion around Australia, it sounds good. However, the explanatory memorandum says that it does fall under the capital gains tax provision. It continues:
2.5. Similarly, if the consideration for disposal is less than depreciated value, the deficiency is deductible.
If one loses on it, then it is deductible. It is plain to everyone. Further, it states:

2.6. To prevent tax avoidance where property is transferred at less than true value between persons who are not dealing with each other at arm's length, some of the capital allowance provisions required balancing adjustments calculated as if the disposal was at market value. However, others (most notably, plant depreciation allowances) treat such non-arm's length disposals as made for consideration equal to the lesser of market value or depreciated value.

2.7. This has resulted in tax avoidance. For example, an asset that has a low depreciated value, but a substantial market value, might be sold for its depreciated value by the original owner to a related entity—
that is what Senator Button said—

eg. a company of which the original owner is the principal shareholder. That transaction would not result in any recoupment of the vendor's depreciation. The related company could then sell the asset for its true market value without being taxed on recoupment of depreciation allowed to the original owner.

The explanatory memorandum is confusing. Under that last paragraph, section 25A of the Income Tax Act would pick it up and it would then go through as a capital gain. Is any taxpayer going to deliberately put himself onto capital gains tax rather than normal income tax? I just cannot see any reason for it; perhaps Senator Tate can tell me. I believe there would be very minimal advantage in doing that because under capital gains the rate is not taken to be the top tax rate, it is taken to be the taxpayer's rate. For capital gains tax his income is increased by 25 per cent to get a tax value that the Tax Office can charge him and it applies that over the whole lot. Having done an exercise on it, I can say that it works out to make very little difference.

PARA.TAB: I just cannot see why the Government and the Tax Office are getting so fazed about avoidance that they include paragraphs in the explanatory memorandum that contradict each other. I would like an explanation from the Minister as to why it is being done. As I have said, I cannot see anyone deliberately going into capital gains.

I turn now to deductibility for the rehabilitation of mine sites. As Senator Watson has already pointed out, there is an amendment in this Bill to clarify the position. Time and time again in this place legislation is rushed; in this case it was not rushed, it was delayed for 12 months. There was total confusion about deductibility for the restoration of mine sites. The original Bill went through this place six months ago—
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been recently drawn to my attention that the Department of Defence has circulated a defence economic brief to the senior hierarchy of the Department which I understand numbers about 60 people. I intend to read some of what it says onto the public record. It is a very short item—it is short but not sweet. The heading is `Goods and Services Tax (GST)'. The body of the message, as it comes from the Department of Defence, is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The GST as proposed in the Coalition's "Fightback" package would be levied at 15% and charged on the supply of goods and services in Australia and on the importation of goods into Australia. In essence it is a value added tax where the full brunt of the tax falls on the final consumer of goods and services. The possible impact on Defence could be considerable. If exemptions were not provided, the impact on Defence, based on 1990-91 outlay could be of the order of $740m.

That went out to the senior hierarchy of the Department of Defence with a covering note dated 19 February, 1992. First of all, the material in that brief is quite untrue and it shows that the Fightback package has not been read by the officials who compiled that brief, or it suggests that they are prepared to misrepresent the true state of affairs. I am concerned that there may be an element of misrepresentation in this because the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, came into this chamber on 11 December last and made a similar allegation. There and then, my colleague the shadow Minister for Finance, Senator Short, jumped up in this place. I now wish to read some of what he said. He said:

I refer Senator Ray to pages 15 and 16 of supplementary paper No.5 of Fightback!. If he or some of his acolytes had taken the time to read this document; if he had used some of the resources of the Public Service, which were at his unlimited disposal at taxpayers' expense to try to knock holes in this thing; and if they had half a brain and had read the technical manual on the GST, they would have read section 5.4.3 which deals with supplies by public sector bodies. It says:
`The public sector is taxable if the goods or services are provided in the course of commercial activity.
Goods and services are zero rated—'
That means that they pay no GST on their input and no GST on their output—`if they comprise a regulatory activity or are non-commercial in nature, for example'
It lists a number of examples. The last example is:
`governmental services like defence, law and order'.

I refer Senator Ray to page 16 of supplementary paper No.5 of the Fightback package. I hope that he will have the courtesy and the decency to come back into this chamber at some stage, admit that he set up the greatest straw man of all time and apologise to everyone who heard him make that absolute furphy.

Senator Ray did not come back to this chamber and make such an apology. I am disappointed that when the inaccuracy of his claim was pointed out to him he did not do so. I would have expected him to have the grace to acknowledge how wrong he was. I would have expected at least that his Department would be reading the Hansard to see what its Minister had been saying and anything that was said back to its Minister. I understand that Hansard is circulated to the top echelons of the Department. I would expect them to read it; it costs them money, I think.

PARA.TAB: Why is it that Hansard was not read? Why is it that the Fightback package was not read? Or were they read and was there a deliberate intention to misrepresent the Fightback package and its implications for defence? I find it completely unsatisfactory that on 19 February, some two months after the Fightback package came out, the financial section of the Department of Defence should be sending this claim, which is so wrong and so misleading, to about 60 senior personnel in the Department of Defence.

When are we going to get that apology from the Minister? It is long overdue. Why is that inaccurate statement and claim being made by the senior officers in his Department? Will the Department put out an official correction? Will that official correction be distributed to that same distribution list, those same senior officers who received the inaccurate briefing, in what was meant to be a professional, technical defence finance brief. We can surely expect to have honesty in government. Certainly, the taxpayers expect that their funds are not spent on misinformation campaigns on such a serious matter which affects the future good governing of this country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1991 the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures had before it a number of witnesses. One of those witnesses was a Mr Sherry who made false accusations against members of the ETU in Queensland and against the union generally. This view was taken up by Senator Walters when she maligned two officials of the ETU during a session of this Parliament. I believe that those people's explanation and point of view should be not only heard in this chamber but also read into the Hansard. I quote a letter from Mr Robert Henricks, who is the Secretary of the Queensland branch of the ETU, to Dr Laing, who was the Secretary of the Select Committee. The letter said:

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge your letter of November 19, 1991. I thank you for the opportunity to respond to allegations made against me by Mr Sherry. I apologise for the delay in replying. However, I was absent overseas until after your committee completed its hearings of evidence.

Mr Sherry alleges that I threatened him on two occasions with physical harm and that he was so alarmed by my threat he was prepared to commit an offence under the Telecommunications Act. He went so far as to suggest that he was "scared for my life". This demonstrates the lack of credibility which any fair minded person would find in his evidence. I never at any time told Mr Sherry that I would "fix him". Nor did I threaten his life. Nor did I intend that he should have any such perception. Nor do I believe that he had any such perception.

I recall a heated discussion with Mr Sherry when, after believing he was a genuine supporter of the Sacked SEQEB Workers, it was brought to my attention that his intentions and reasons for carrying out the research he was performing were not honourable.

In relation to his accusations of money collected to support Sacked SEQEB Workers being used to financially support political candidates, which some people have interpreted to infer that some of the money in the so called "ETU Fund" was used for such a purpose, I can confirm after discussing this matter with Sacked Workers who were involved in managing and running that fund (which was not controlled by the ETU but by the Sacked Workers themselves), that to the best of my knowledge absolutely none of that fund was used to support any candidate or any political office.

I am very conscious of the importance of my position. I am proud of that position with the ETU and of my achievements as a member of the Executive. I certainly made it clear to Mr Sherry that I would be most upset if he used information he had obtained from me to malign that Union or its members. There may have been some words said in heat but in fact I was consciously restrained, as far as I was then able, in my conversations with him.

I did not want anything said or done by me to defeat the hard work and effort put in by myself and by other members of the Executive to this Union of which we are all so proud. For Mr Sherry to suggest, as he has done, that he felt physically endangered can only be the most deliberate of fabrications and proves to my mind what I had come to suspect that his intentions were dishonourable and malicious.

Mr Sherry has demonstrated to your Committee that he is prepared to break the law for his own purposes. In my opinion one of those purposes is to malign this Union and its members. I have no doubt that he is prepared to further break the law to achieve that end. When he was carrying out his research with my approval at the offices of the ETU he arrogantly abused the privileges I had given him. On one occasion I observed his going through confidential records of the Union which were irrelevant to his stated purposes and which he had no authority from me or any Officer of the Union to inspect. When I approached him about that he immediately left the Union's office. He made no explanation and gave no excuse and I took that to mean an admission by him that he knew his actions in that regard were improper. Relations between us became somewhat strained but I assert that the fault was his. I believe that his present evidence so far as it concerns me is false and malicious.
I trust that the foregoing assists you in relation to your enquiries. Should you require clarification of any issue contained herein please do not hesitate to contact me.
I now read a letter addressed again to Dr Laing, the secretary of that Committee. It is written by Mr A. Doodney. I quote:
Dear Dr Laing
I have received your letter of 19th November. I am grateful for the opportunity to respond to the evidence given to your Committee, by Mr Sherry.

The accusations made by Mr Sherry at page 388 of the Transcript are simply untrue. I emphatically deny that I ever offered Mr Neville $50,000 to opt out of the SEQEB dispute. Additionally there was only one fund with which I had any involvement. It was established to assist the striking SEQEB workers and their families. That Fund was administered by the striking workers of whom I was one. The proceeds of the Fund were used to provide financial relief. The administration of this Fund was intensively investigated by the Cooke inquiry. Commissioner Cooke, whilst making some minor criticisms, was obviously satisfied that the Fund complied with the purposes for which it was established.

Mr Sherry clearly fails as a researcher. His evidence from my knowledge is tainted with information which is clearly untrue. The reference to the ATEA on page 388 totally misrepresents the true position. The case there was simply that members of the ATEA allowed payroll deductions to two accounts, one at the Sunstate Credit Union and the other at Credit Union Australia. Those monies were at practical intervals remitted to the SEQEB Strike Fund, administered by myself and several others. A receipt was issued for those monies on each occasion. Mr Sherry is attempting to infer that some clandestine relationship existed between Messrs Kane and McLean. This simply was not the case. In fact Mr Kane had nothing whatsoever to do with the administration of the Fund. Whilst the Executive of ETU assisted in the raising of funds they had no involvement in the administration of the Fund.

Having read the Transcript and from my own knowledge of the SEQEB dispute and related matters, it seems that Mr Sherry's evidence can carry no weight. His evidence is, at least on the occasion I have adverted, contrary to the findings of Commissioner Cooke. I trust that my responses are to your satisfaction. Should you require to discuss any matter contained herein at length please do not hesitate to contact me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Whilst not wishing to be disruptive, I query whether these letters have been tabled before the Committee or whether tabling was refused. It is for the edification of the chamber. If tabling was refused, it would seem inappropriate that they be read here at this time.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I have been informed that they were tabled in the Senate by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might refer to that. It seems to me that, rather than people having to go looking for the letters if they had an interest, they should be clearly there for everyone to read in the Hansard.
