The remarks of Senator Walters and others when they sought to malign two decent trade unionists are clearly available in the Hansard. They chose to use the Hansard to malign those honourable and decent union officials and now they squeal when a response shows them to be as dishonest as Mr Sherry was. All they want to do is bash workers and bash trade unionists. That is their pastime.
—Order! Senator Burns should withdraw the word `dishonest' in reference to another senator.

—I withdraw. I find it difficult to believe them. I think, however, that this at least in clear terms places before the people of this country in the Hansard the role played by these two honourable people. I suggest that in the future people should be a little more restrained before they question and attack the reputation of others who are not in this chamber to defend themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days three things which I and millions of other Australians love and cherish have been the subject of demeaning and vitriolic attack. I refer to our Constitution, our Queen and our flag. All of these have been attacked by the man who parades as Prime Minister for all Australians. He has the temerity to talk of one nation when his actions have been to set a Australian against Australian, to create division and to demean our system of governance and the symbols which attend it.

PARA.TAB: Long have I known of our need to be a good neighbour and trading partner in this our Pacific region. Indeed, it is a region far more diverse and complicated than the one embracing the term `Asia' and one which is multicultural by any definition. This is a region in which I have spent more than a decade working and building personal relationships to see us prosper and interact in this our own region.

As I said, the Pacific Basin is a multicultural region. There are many tensions and differences within it, with some nations remembering Japan's occupation, others maintaining ties with old colonial powers. There are nations that are as independent as we are but value access to international trading markets through their European contacts. I cite Indonesia with Holland and the Philippines with Spain.

The fact that Australia, Singapore and Malaysia share a similar legal system and old alumni ties of the Colombo Plan is another example. One does not need, nor should one try, to jettison one's heritage and tradition in order to be a good neighbour and trading partner. To do so in some pathetic attempt to impress a neighbour would cause that neighbour to despise us. Our neighbours are proud of their own heritage and cannot countenance or comprehend those who do not value theirs.

Paul Keating's rabid attack on Britain is one against an old ally with whom we fought proudly in Flanders and Ypres in World War I, commemorated by the red poppy which we still wear each year to remember; in the Middle East, in Greece and in Crete in World War II—and, yes, World War II saw us suffer in the POW camps of Malaya and Singapore and on the Burma railway. Part of our tradition is the selfless sacrifice given by so many Australians in so many theatres of war to give us today the freedom we enjoy.

My father fought for me and my land in places such as Balikpapan and Borneo. He joined up, together with thousands of other Australians, after war was declared because Germany invaded Poland. Perhaps he remembered that General Monash was of part Polish Jewish heritage. I do not know. But I do know that he believed that the general was a great Australian. I know he believed himself that he was fighting against evil—the evil of Nazi Germany, of Hitler, of Mussolini. He knew all of that before Japan entered the war. He joined before he knew that his theatre of war was to be his own backyard. He and thousands like him believed in the dignity of the freedom of man and that it was worth fighting for in any part of the world. It was, if you like, an internationalist attitude. It was the sort of attitude we have when we negotiate in the GATT round—where we call for free and fair trade—when we appreciate the support of Britain with her attitude to the common agricultural policy and the need to bring down the subsidising of European trade in agriculture.

We similarly get angry with our major trading partner, Japan, over contemporary issues—that she forbids any rice should be imported into Japan. Again we express our anger at the United States of America for her export enhancement program, that is, subsidy by any other name of wheat into our markets. But at the end of the day we trade with them all and in large measure. Never in any of these negotiations is our Constitution, our Queen or our flag a term of that trade.

In my view, our Constitution is worth fighting for. We have the oldest democratic constitutional monarchy in the world. It was the first of its kind to have full adult suffrage with women entitled to stand for elected office. It has given us a stable, peaceful, tolerant, multicultural society where people have come as migrants and have found a haven from conflict, a new start in life and a society which welcomes the contribution they make. Australia is what she is because of her institutions, the rule of law and the Constitution that enshrines and protects them.

The current newspaper reports about republican sentiment remind me of the reports that predicted that the last Labor Party assault on our Constitution would be successful. Of course, the referendum in 1988, designed to drastically alter our Constitution, was defeated in every State of Australia by a majority in every State. Australians are sensible people when they are acquainted with all the facts.

I have been spurred on by a large number of letters that have crossed my desk from ordinary Australians who are enraged by the Prime Minister's remarks and the divisive debate which he is promoting. These letters have raised with me some interesting issues and have indicated the depth of feeling that exists. An example of one such letter poses some very fundamental questions:

SPEECH.PARA: Just how much better off would we be if we were a Republic? Would we have a better economy? Would we have less unemployment? Would a Republic make any difference in the lives of Australians? Would there be more money to open better hospitals?

These are the real issues of concern to ordinary, decent Australians. They are far more concerned about the state of economy, the tragedy of mass unemployment and the quality of schools and hospitals than they are about the diversion of the republican debate. Another wrote:

My dear mates who died in the Battalion would not believe what has happened. I do not whinge. My sense of humour overcomes pain, but I ask you now, do not add insult to my injuries, by abolishing the symbol which represents the spiritual qualities which invest a nation with nobility and integrity.

To tear the monarch from our Constitution would mean that we get an elected head of state, and an elected President—and elected he or she would be, because no matter what method were used the party which wins the election would control the President. No longer would there be a head of state above politics—the monarch remaining constant and the Governor-General in charge on a day-to-day basis. A President would be in an elected party-political position, with only approximately one half of the population supporting him or her at any given time. Perhaps it would be the ultimate job-for-the-boys, with the government owning the President.

PARA.TAB: This is a time when true patriotism is served by giving leadership which pulls us together, not divides us; which gives us a common purpose, not divisionary tactics. We need leadership which travels the road to prosperity, not the Argentinean road which leads to banana republicanism.

I love this country. I am a proud Australian and I am proud to know that in only 200 years we have forged an independent nation which is the envy of so many. Wise forefathers gave us a Constitution which has allowed our Federation to flourish while other federations have failed. I cannot think of any other country's constitution that I want to copy, nor do I wish to traverse the route to violence which is the history of so many other republics, whether inside our region or outside it—be it the United States of America or Yugoslavia.

Our system is unique and serves us well. Our Queen is gracious and our flag is the symbol of a free and independent nation for whom so many proud Australians have died. Let us fight our partisan battles and test our economic theories, but do not tamper with our institutions, tear our Constitution apart or destroy the symbols of our nationhood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to make some brief remarks in the current debate regarding Australia's Constitution and our flag. This debate will run for years, if not for decades. In many ways this is a pity because there is no doubt that the nation will become polarised over the value of central national symbols and institutions.

PARA.TAB: I will make two predictions about this debate. First, it will do nothing for jobs and the reform of the economy. Worse, it is an attempt to distract the nation from these issues. Secondly, the debate will be very divisive. It has been instituted not because of any upsurge in community feeling, but principally because of the internal problems of the Australian Labor Party; a party which we have seen over the last nine years or so is without any clear beliefs or ideology; a party which, in its desperation, has decided to attempt to beat the nationalistic drum.

The beat of this drum, however, is very selective and very discordant. At the same time, for example, as Mr Keating bashes the British, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) seems to suffer no embarrassment from grovelling to some countries in our region. As I say, the nationalistic drum that is being beaten is very selective.

There are a number of aspects of this debate on which I wish to comment today. The first relates to Mr Keating's call for an independent Australia. There is no argument from this side of the chamber about the need for Australia to remain an independent and sovereign country. The question I ask myself is whether, by focusing on our independent Constitution, Mr Keating is focusing on the wrong issue regarding the national independence of this country.

We have long been an independent country. Indeed, all Prime Ministers of this nation for 40 or 50 years have strongly believed in the independence of Australia, whether they be Labor or Liberal. I suggest that Mr Keating is the first Prime Minister for a long time who seems to have some doubts about this. When I was looking at the debates on the Australia Act which passed into law in 1985, I noticed that the former Labor Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen—a former colleague of Senator Robert Ray, who is in the chamber—told us that this Act reflected the fact that Australia had long been an independent and sovereign nation.

So I think there was consensus that Australia was an independent country. But as far as Mr Keating is concerned, this is apparently not the case. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are major threats to the independence of Australia. These are the sorts of issues that Mr Keating may care to focus on if he has some genuine concern about this country, as distinct from a genuine concern about his need to get back into the job after the next election.

The first major threat to Australia's independence is the massive build-up of foreign debt in this country, which has risen from about $23 billion when this Government came into office to over $160 billion today. In short, this Labor Government has put us in hock to foreigners. No doubt a number of people will realise the massive irony involved—that the man who speaks about the independence of this country has, in fact, through his policies put us in hock to foreigners.

Labor members of parliament might ask themselves—if they have not already seen examples of how having a massive foreign debt effects the independence of this country—why Mr Keating brought about the recession that we had to have. Why did Mr Keating engineer this recession when he was Treasurer? It was because of the very fear that Australia, if it did not try to slow down the growth of foreign debt and deal with the balance of payments crisis, would have its credit rating downgraded. Foreign debt is a huge problem regarding the independence of this nation.

I suggest that a second threat to the independence of this nation relates to the sell-off of Australian assets which is occurring. When a company goes broke and is forced to sell its assets, most of us have seen how cheaply they are sold. When a country goes down the road to economic ruin it, too, has to sell off its assets. It has to sell them off cheaply to foreigners to raise money.

There are real threats to the independence of Australia but they do not relate to our Constitution. As Senator Bishop has so well demonstrated, our Constitution is arguably the world's oldest democratic constitution. It has maintained our national unity for almost 100 years. It is not the Constitution which is our problem. Indeed, our Constitution is our great pride. The independence of Australia is threatened by other factors, principally in the current period by the destruction of the economic standing of this nation.

There are some further aspects of irony in this debate. The Australian newspaper and the Fairfax press are running very strongly in support of the republican movement. In today's Australian there was a headline endorsing Mr Keating's call for a more independent Australia. Both Fairfax and the Australian are foreign owned; both are telling Australians that they should become more independent. What a massive irony!

TALK.START.PARA: —You changed the Broadcasting Act to accommodate one of them!

—We have finally got under Senator Ray's skin, and rightly so. There is a massive irony there. I think that, as this debate goes on, Australians will start to focus on a few of these issues. If we are looking at the influence that foreigners may have in this country, let us start with Rupert Murdoch and Conrad Black, because they control massive organs of public opinion.

PARA.TAB: Another aspect of this debate is our cultural cringe. But the cultural cringe, I am pleased to say, does not come from this side of the chamber. Let us listen to the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in discussing our great flag:

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose people around the world are entitled to say, well we look at your Flag, you have got the Flag of another country in your flag. I mean, are you a colony or a nation?

Which countries attacked our flag? Who were the people who said that? I have been overseas on many occasions and I have never heard such comments. Senator Bishop, I am sure, has not heard them, either. If anyone decided to make such comments to me, he or she would get a very sharp response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keating ought to listen to his colleague Graeme Campbell.

—Yes. Have we ever seen a cultural cringe of this order? It is the ultimate in cultural cringe—other countries do not like our flag, other countries do not like our institutions, so we should change them. And this is the man who wants us to be independent. It is a pathetic cultural cringe. I suspect that no other Prime Minister in living memory would ever have contemplated it.
—Are you going to dig up Robert Menzies?

—You can dig up Robert Menzies. We will be throwing Paul Keating back at you day after day. We have all these lovely quotes from Paul Keating and they will be thrown back at you day after day. Of course honourable senators opposite are sensitive. Mr Keating has not only changed all the traditions of their own great party in relation to how they manage the economy. They used to call each other comrades—remember that?—and what great socialists they all were. That all went out the roof. But there was one aspect of the Labor Party which I did admire, and which I still admire: the Labor Party flies the Australian flag in its logo.
—And always will.
—We are very pleased to hear that from Senator Ray. Let me remind Labor colleagues of the views of three of their former leaders on our great flag. Dr Evatt said:

SPEECH.PARA: The flag that is now Australia's national flag. . . .is a very beautiful flag. It is probably the most beautiful flag in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Ben Chifley, like Senator Ray, also had strong views on our flag. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The flying of the flag on public buildings, schools and the public generally is not only permitted, but would be appreciated.
I agree with Ben Chifley that we should fly our flag as much as possible. Arthur Calwell, another Labor leader, captured the essence of our flag when he said—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they never tried to wear it around them.

—I am proud to wear the flag; I have no embarrassment. The Minister hurls the comment across the chamber, `They are not proud to wear the flag'. I am proud to wear it. I admit that. Listen to what Arthur Calwell said—
—I agree with Arthur.
—I am delighted. For the Minister's colleagues behind him, who may not agree, Arthur Calwell said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that if proper respect were shown for the Australian flag, which is flown by our warships and by our troops in battle, a healthy national spirit would be promoted, and all Australians, whether newcomers or native-born, would love and respect the laws of our country.
In this way I think Arthur Calwell was trying to tell us that the flag is a symbol of national unity.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my remarks by drawing on a brief comment I made earlier in response to an interjection by Senator Ray. When one looks at the Labor Party logo, one basically sees the Australian flag. A central feature of the Liberal Party logo, the big `L', is also the Australian flag. The great political battles in this country are fought between two major political parties. Yet in the symbols of this fight there is also the symbol, at present, of our unity. Both our parties fly our great flag in their logos. This is going to change. This symbol of unity is going to be dropped. It is going to become a symbol of divisive debate between the parties. It will cause great division in the community. The responsibility may not be Senator Ray's, because he has told us that he supports our great flag; it will rest firmly with the most divisive Prime Minister we have had in our history—Paul Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Australia we sometimes express our incredulity by saying, `Pigs might fly'. I intend to inform the Senate of some flying pigs that left me incredulous. It was on a recent flight from London to Sydney, Qantas flight 2. Between Bangkok and Sydney, the breakfast menu in business class included `Canadian bacon and pineapple'. It is quite extraordinary that our national carrier, Qantas—which makes a big play of what a great national company it is—should see fit to serve Canadian bacon on its international flights. But worse than that, it sees fit to promote it as Canadian bacon.

PARA.TAB: The point I make is simply this: Qantas may, for very good business reasons, see it as necessary to purchase Canadian bacon. It may find it to be cheaper in the port that it flies out of. But, whether it is cheaper or not, we should not be describing it on the menu as` Canadian bacon'. It makes people believe that Canadian bacon is somehow better than Australian bacon, whereas the opposite is true—Australian bacon is a better product.
I ask Qantas why it promotes Canadian bacon. If it has to use Canadian bacon, why does it not describe it on the menu as bacon and pineapple?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because Qantas does not supply food for the London-Bangkok flight; another airline does.

—I thank Senator Ray for his interjection, but Senator Ray does not understand that Qantas produces the menu and the menu should not say `Canadian bacon'. If Qantas is going to promote a product, it should promote Australian products. If it is going to use an overseas product, it should not call it Canadian bacon; it should just say `bacon and pineapple'. It is absolutely ludicrous that our national carrier should see fit to promote Canadian products.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray may not be particularly interested in the future of the Australian pork industry but we in the National Party and our Liberal Party colleagues certainly are. What Senator Ray and the Government forget is that Canadian bacon is flooding into this country because it is subsidised overseas. It receives enormous Canadian government subsidies.

The Opposition says that if a product is subsidised it should cop a countervailing duty. For Senator Ray's benefit and the Government's benefit, I note that in the last six months of last year $5.8m worth of Canadian pork flooded into this country—that works out at 243 tonnes of Canadian pork a day—not because it is a better product or because Australians want to buy Canadian pork, but because it is subsidised. It is part of the corrupt international trade scene and we let it go on.

A very serious point to all this that Senator Ray may not have appreciated is simply that we have to stand up to these subsidised products that are coming in from overseas. At the moment, this moribund Government has no interest at all in stopping the flood of dumped produce in this country for one simple reason: it disguises the fact that the Government has no anti-inflation policy. It does not matter if the product is cheaper and puts Australian workers out of the jobs. Provided it helps the Government hold down the CPI, that is fine by it. It is not fine by the people of the National Party or the Liberal Party who are on this side of the chamber. I hasten to add that we will not be on this side of the chamber for terribly long, because the Australian populous is sick and tired of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sick and tired of the fact that this Government will not stand up for Australian industries. There is something that we can do and that is—as Senator Chapman rightly interjects—put in place a fair dinkum anti-dumping policy. That would be unlike the policy that this Government has, under which it can tell the customs authority, `Yes, you are allowed to find that the produce has been dumped and that there is material injury to the Australian industry, but you are not allowed to find that the dumping led to the material injury'. It is like finding a dead body with a bullet in it and saying that a causal link between the bullet and the person's death cannot be found.

PARA.TAB: That is the absurdity of this Government's policy and that is why in Australia industry after industry is going down the tubes. This Government will not stand up for them and the Opposition thinks that that is a disgrace. We think that it is absolutely disgraceful that this Government will not stand up for the future of Australian industries.

There are some people, however, who are standing up for the future of Australian industries. I am very pleased to see that recently the general manager of Woolworths supermarkets, Mr John Brunton, announced not only that Woolworths has never sold overseas pork products, but also that Woolworths will never sell overseas pork products.

I say to Australian consumers that if they want to see viable Australian industry and the best pork in the world still on their supermarket shelves there is one simple thing to do, and that is buy Australian pork or Australian bacon. This can be done by going to a supermarket like Woolworths or by looking at the brand name and making sure that the brand is 100 per cent Australian, for example, Huttons or KR. If one is in any doubt, one should look at the label.

The final message to every Australian company is: you have to do your bit by this nation as well. If it is good enough for Woolworths to sell Australian bacon and pork, it is good enough for Qantas to do the same or, if it will not buy Australian bacon, it should not promote overseas bacon. As I say, this whole affair has left me incredulous. I conclude by saying that pigs may fly but, if they do, let us have Australian bacon please.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in his statement last week, handing another $51m of taxpayers' money to the highly subsidised textile, clothing and footwear industries, I wish in this matter of public interest debate today to express not only my great concern but also that of a great many people in the community about the failure of Australian footwear manufacturers, and for that matter overseas footwear manufacturers, to meet market demand. I am referring to the failure of both Australian and overseas sports shoe manufacturers to provide a specific or appropriate piece of footwear for Australia's 750,000 women netball players.

PARA.TAB: Netball, with about 750,000 players, is the biggest participator sport for women in this country. About 360,000 of these are registered club players at many levels. The remainder are school competition players or social players of all ages.

In my State of South Australia, there are about 100,000 players who participate in netball. Approximately 10,000 of these suffer some form of injury during a playing season. Parents of school-aged players, players at all levels, team officials and medical authorities have raised this shoe issue with me because the incidence of injuries—specifically ankle, knee, leg or foot injuries—is not being adequately met by manufacturers of sports shoes.

There is, obviously, with 750,000 Australian players, a local market which has been ignored for far too long. But apart from this burgeoning domestic market, there are 20 other nations which compete in international netball—New Zealand, Jamaica, England, the Cook Islands, Canada, Wales, Western Samoa, Scotland, the Irish Republic, Fiji, Vanuatu, Malaysia, Northern Ireland, Namibia, Papua New Guinea, Sri Lanka, the Cayman Islands, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Trinidad and Tobago.

Together, these countries represent millions of netball players but sadly they remain ignored by sporting shoe manufacturers. Can one imagine a player in a fast moving sport such as rugby union, rugby league or Australian rules—even soccer—not having available a specifically manufactured shoe? Can one see David Campese, Mal Meninga, Simon Poidevin or, for that matter, any of the fabulous Adelaide Crows Aussie rules football team powering down the turf, twisting and turning, wearing only a pair of Nike running shoes or Dunlop Volleys? Of course not. Are women netball players not worth the same investment?

Sports shoe manufacturers, especially Australian manufacturers, must be asked why no affordable specific purpose netball shoe exists. Thousands of players each season suffer all manner of injuries—injuries which could possibly be avoided with the availability of a purpose-built shoe. As a keen cricketer and general sportsman myself—

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good cricketer, too.
—Thank you for that commendation.
—I would acknowledge that too; I have heard that.

—I thank Senator Ray. As a parent of sports playing children, I am only too well aware that there are sports shoes on the market which can be and are used by netball players, but there is still no purpose-built shoe for netball. Although there are many surfaces on which the sport is played—for example, grass, flexipave and asphalt—players say that none of the current general sports shoes available suit. Just ask the thousands of parents who watch their children play each week or even the thousands of adult players who end up with time off work with avoidable ankle, knee or leg injuries.

PARA.TAB: These people are asking why there is no netball shoe which meets the rigorous requirements of the sport. They ask why none provides the proper support for side to side movement, sudden stopping or heavy landings which come with the precision of the sport. Even many players and officials of the sport claim that, after a few hard games, there is little life left in shoes. Much of the support they have has decreased and often the sole may rip.

There can be no excuse for manufacturers, both overseas and local, who produce expensive general sports shoes failing to invest in the production of a specific netball shoe which would be both affordable and satisfactory to the sport.

The Australian footwear industry shares with the textile and clothing industries the dubious distinction of being one of the most highly subsidised industries in this country, by way of the tariff and other protection it is afforded, as well as the assistance of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —We might get some Canadian shoes in.

—Well, no. Neither the Canadians nor anyone else seems to be manufacturing these shoes at present.In the Prime Minister's statement last week, he handed these industries on a platter yet another $51m of taxpayers' money over the next three years. Advocates of such assistance for these industries justify it partly on the grounds of Australia being a small domestic market for products. I put it to the sports shoe manufacturers that three-quarters of a million netball players offer a very significant domestic market for one product line. Beyond that is the opportunity to develop a product with a real export potential, given the millions of players internationally to whom I have already referred who are crying out for a specific purpose-built netball shoe.

PARA.TAB: There can be no excuses from the industry for an affordable and specific netball shoe not being manufactured and available on the market. A strong domestic and international market demand obviously exists. The sooner manufacturers, preferably Australian manufacturers, meet this long ignored market and take women sports players seriously by providing them with a specific purpose-built netball shoe, the earlier injuries will be reduced and possibly eliminated.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)—by leave—agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. I refer the Minister to the proposed $20m expenditure, as outlined in the sixteenth Keating economic package, on the port of Townsville. Could the Minister advise, firstly, on what this is to be spent; and, secondly, what will be the benefit to Townsville or the users of the port?

—The purpose of this allocation is to enhance the prospects of the 900-plus workers at the Yabulu refinery near Townsville. As Senator Parer may know, at the moment there is a continuing discussion between the Federal Government, the Queensland State Government and the operators of the refinery.
—The Goss Government has not made a decision since it has been in office.

—That is not the case at all. The preferred outcome is very much a matter for negotiation with industry as well as government. In the past the Commonwealth has been asked for assistance with options in respect of the rail link between the port and the refinery and/or dredging operations in the port. That matter still has not been finally determined.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that Cabinet agreed to make a commitment in respect of the money involved. The optimum way of investing that money to ensure the continued operations of the refinery and the continued employment of the 900 Australians who work there will be subject to appropriate discussions between the State Government and the nickel refinery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I ask him: is it not a fact that this $20m expenditure is nothing more than a fantasy of the Chairman of the Port Authority and ex-mayor, Mike Reynolds; that there is already a modern rail loop at the port—I understand that the Government is looking at spending another $8m to build another rail loop; that none of the users, including Queensland Nickel, see any benefit at all in this expenditure, this fantasy which is only part of a total expenditure of $80m; and that there are no prospects on the horizon for increased exports or imports? Is this not a complete waste of taxpayers' money—
—Order! This is supposed to be a supplementary question, not a speech.
—Is this not a complete waste of taxpayers' money, which will be of no use to the people of Townsville or to the major users of the port? The Minister should check them out.

—No, it is not a fact. I am, frankly, astonished that Senator Parer would follow so closely on the heals of Senator Macdonald and Senator Tambling in attempting to reject additional Federal funding for northern Australia. As I have said before, there are plenty of white pointers from Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and elsewhere that will grab the money if those honourable senators do not want it. I thought it was important for this commitment to be made. Can I just specify this fantasy. The gentleman just mentioned is the Chairman of the Townsville Port Authority. To propose the construction of an $80m outer berth for the port of Townsville is not a fantasy. It would greatly enhance the commercial opportunities for the major industrial port in northern Australia and Queensland.

PARA.TAB: It is not unreasonable that the desire of the Port Authority—not its Chairman, but the Port Authority—to assist in enhancing the commercial opportunities for the Townsville port may not necessarily be completely in accord with the interests of the nickel refinery which, of course, has its own interests. It has a cheaper option. It is perfectly appropriate for the Port Authority to say, `As part of assisting the nickel refinery, we should take the opportunity to construct an outer berth in the harbour because it will significantly enhance'—and there is no question about it—`the commercial opportunities for the port of Townsville'. I am, frankly, astonished that the complaints about this would come from honourable senators who purport to represent the State of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article by Senator Alston in the Melbourne Age of 2 March entitled, `Getting real on foreign aid', in which he suggests that the Government improve the quality of its aid program? What is the Minister's view of that article, if he has seen it?

—Senator Alston's article is nothing more or less than an absolutely pathetic attempt to justify the draconian cuts that the Opposition is proposing to make, if it ever gets the chance, to this Government's and this country's foreign aid program. In attempting to justify his Party's policy position in Fightback!, Senator Alston in fact displays his total lack of understanding not only of Australia's aid program but also of the development process overall. In the latter respect, for example, he cites early on in the article South Korea and Taiwan as examples of countries which have developed, as he says, without significant foreign aid programs. He talks about the need for us to get real on foreign aid.

PARA.TAB: He seems utterly oblivious to the fact that both countries in question, South Korea and Taiwan, have, as everyone knows, received absolutely massive assistance from the United States over many years. Most of Senator Alston's claims about the Australian aid program are equally spurious. He claims, for a start, that Australia should concentrate on the quality of its aid program and ensure that it measures up to strict performance criteria. In fact, Australia has an enviable international reputation as a deliverer of quality aid programs. Of course, individual programs have gone wrong occasionally over the years, as they have for every aid delivering country, and the most spectacular example to cite—and he does cite it, of course—is the Margarini project in Africa some decade ago.

But Senator Alston should be aware, as he is obviously not, that AIDAB is one of the most prolific and public and respected evaluators of its own activities. Through a whole variety of appraisal, audit and review activities, it is continually assessing its assistance to countries, to sectors, to particular target groups. In fact, AIDAB devotes some $10m each year to various quality control initiatives. Again, Senator Alston, who is speaking not for himself but for the Opposition in this respect, displays a total lack of understanding when he moves on to criticise continuing budget support for Papua New Guinea as being anachronistic and counterproductive. As he ought to be aware—but manifestly is not, and I do not think Senator Hill is any the wiser on this subject—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks very much. I thought you were phasing it out.

—I thought Senator Hill would appreciate that. The Government has reached formal agreement with Papua New Guinea to phase out all budget support by the end of the decade and to replace it with targeted program and project assistance. So there is no foundation whatsoever for the criticism of the present Government's aid program, priorities or policies. The point has been acknowledged for years. We have been trying to bring it about and we are in the process of bringing it about, and it is impossible to make it go any faster than that. Senator Alston should know that, if he does not.

PARA.TAB: Again, he asserts that Australia should fund projects which build enduring political, economic and social structures. In fact, as he ought to be aware, this has been an absolutely central part of the whole aid program since its inception: targeting sustainable development activities in consultation with recipient governments and addressing quite specific issues that ensure sustainability such as the role of women and the question of the impact on the environment.

Again, although the idea has apparently only recently occurred to him, Australia's aid program has for many years targeted its assistance on areas of our specific expertise, including agriculture and soil conservation—claims again that are totally misconstrued and misunderstood in the article. The point essentially is this: the failing of this article is a spectacular example of the kind of failing which runs through the whole policy of the Opposition, generally and more specifically, on aid; a failure to understand that development is achieved through a variety of aid mechanisms, including large development projects of the kind that Senator Alston has totally deprecated.

The Opposition would reduce the aid budget by $209m over the next two years and, in addition, increase its costs by some $70m by introducing the goods and services tax. It would reduce the dollar value of that aid by $70m through GST alone while taking another $200m off the top. Yet the Opposition has the gall to criticise the Government's aid program. To go as the Opposition is proposing would not only totally destroy our credibility in this area but also damage the relationships we have with the whole developing world.

This is not a policy on the Opposition's part that is motivated by any concern for aid quality or any concern for the countries in our own region; it is a cynical attempt to find another area of saving in order to justify and pay for a goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call for the next question, I make an appeal to Ministers. We have had two questions in 11 minutes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask the Minister whether the main Australian contingent committed to Cambodia, because of its particular function, will be deployed there ahead of the rest of the United Nations peacekeeping forces.

—As Senator Durack would understand, the UN deployment in Cambodia is in two phases: UNAMIC, which is there at the moment, and UNTAC, to which no final timetable yet applies, although I must say that I am more happy now with the progress that has been made in New York than I have been in previous weeks when I thought that perhaps the UN bureaucracy was operating a little too slowly.

PARA.TAB: The matter has now been to the General Assembly. We have basically indicated to the United Nations the extent of our commitment. The other day, Senator Evans said that it would be in the order of 500, give or take 10 per cent. One would expect, given the nature of that, that it would be one of the earlier deployable units although not necessarily the earliest. Senator Evans also indicated to Senator Durack that, once a formal request is made and a response is given by the Australian Government, the Prime Minister will make a statement in Parliament giving the full details of our commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of an official delegation from the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Federation, led by Mr Yuri Yarov. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the delegation to Australia and to the Senate. I trust that its visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw his attention to a call by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser for all Australians to support the Cambodian peace plan. Does the Minister agree with the call made by Malcolm Fraser? Further, what action will the Government take to help the repatriation of refugees as one of the first crucial steps towards free elections in that country?

—The Opposition in general and Senator Hill in particular will not be surprised to hear me say that the Government very much welcomes the constructive and helpful comments of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser on the Cambodian peace process. He has urged all Australians to support the Government's efforts in the implementation of that peace settlement. I express not the expectation, but the hope, that Senator Hill in particular will take Malcolm Fraser's words very closely to heart.

PARA.TAB: As to the specific question of the repatriation of the 350,000 displaced Cambodians from camps along the Thailand-Cambodia border, that is a vital component of the overall peace settlement. Its success or failure will be a decisive factor in the implementation of the peace settlement.

The office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has been designated by the UN Secretary-General as the lead agency for this repatriation operation. UNHCR is appealing for funding for a total budget for that program of $US116m. In response to that appeal, the Australian Government has contributed $1m to the pre-operational phase of the program, and the Government will certainly be considering in due course a further contribution for the operational and reintegration phases. The Government is concerned to see that these displaced persons are given every opportunity to return to their chosen place of residence in Cambodia in security and dignity. We are taking a very close interest in the preparation and conduct of this entire operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce relates to the report that the English translation of the report of a high level investment team from Japan released on Monday in Tokyo concluded that the `MFP remains an unrealisable dream'. It is also reported that the Australian Embassy changed this translation to describe the MFP as a `project with a lot of potential'. Were two translations produced—an earlier one and a changed later one; who ordered this change to the English translation of the Japanese; was it done at the behest of the Australian Government and/or the South Australian Government; who carried out the changed translation and where; and did Mr Bruce Guerin play any part in the request for or ordering of the changed translation?

—I suggest, in order to get the answer to this question, that Senator Coulter consult yesterday's Hansard report of the answer I gave to Senator Olsen, who asked me a question on the same topic. I can, however, add some further information to the question asked by Senator Olsen—this is in addition to what Senator Coulter has just asked. The final draft of the executive summary of the report was released in Tokyo on 2 March and received in Canberra on 4 March. It will cease to be a draft when it is considered and approved by members of the Japanese investment survey mission.

PARA.TAB: Australian officials from DITAC and the South Australian Government were given earlier drafts of a report on 7 February, and DITAC and Australian Embassy officials were consulted by the Japanese mission on the translation. I just add that the draft as it now exists contains many positive suggestions and commits Japan to a long term role in the MFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports that the Metal Trades Industry Association has criticised the Opposition's industrial relations policy as `totally Rambo' and `failing to reflect changes already taking place in the workplace'. Is it not a fact that the metal industry—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators opposite do not like the question, they will like the answer even less. Is it not a fact that the metal industry particularly has made significant progress on workplace reform? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether or not a major factor in this progress has been the Government's carefully managed transition to a more decentralised wage fixing system?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Cook, I remind honourable senators again that the microphones are now much more sensitive.

—The answers to these three questions are yes, yes and yes. I am aware that Leigh Purnell of the Metal Trades Industry Association responded to the remarks that were made at a seminar by Mr Ian McLachlan, the shadow Minister for industry and commerce. Mr McLachlan chanted on, as the members of the Opposition are wont to do, that only total labour market reform is the answer to our economic problems. The continuous chant seems to be that total labour market reform is the only answer to our problems.

PARA.TAB: Of course, on this occasion what Mr McLachlan got was a blast of reality from the Metal Trades Industry Association, a major employer group at the sharp end of work force reform in this country which was talking about the realities of what is in fact the change that is going on in the Australian community. The Association said that a total Rambo, total labour market deregulation, deregulation at all costs approach—the sort of chanting mantra that comes from the Opposition—is not the answer.

It also said that to pretend that the labour market is rigid, that there is not in fact a revolution in work in Australia, is to ignore the realities—that there is in fact a revolution in work in Australia; that in fact significant change has already occurred, that significant change is in hand, that significant change is in prospect and that that is being done and managed within the existing system. We will shortly amend that system to further facilitate this speed. But what we will not do is throw over the entire system, which is what the Opposition preaches.

In truth, we are now witnessing the management of change smoothly in the Australian workplace. We have done that by our processes of the structural efficiency principle, by workplace reform, by a cooperative approach rather than the old confrontationist approach—the approach that again the Opposition preaches. We have institutionalised cooperation and have put in place workplace and productivity agreements.

I conclude by saying that when I talk to industry spokespersons and to industry leaders, which I do very frequently, they all tell me that what they do not want is a reinstitutionalisation of confrontation. They do not want to be pushed into making war on their own employees, which is what the Opposition's policy is. Industries want to work with us to achieve the significant change that is already there, consolidate that and move on to an even better and more productive climate in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer the Minister to his promise in Question Time on 8 October last year to make representations to the National Food Authority through the Minister for Health for the Authority to review country of origin labelling size. In view of the Minister's excellent progress while Minister responsible in ensuring that unpackaged imported food now bears 4.5 millimetre labels, with imported fruit juice now being clearly labelled as such, has a National Food Authority review and survey of the rules relating to labelling been commenced? Has he requested the Minister for Health to include a review of country of origin label size? Considering that there has now been an industry application to the Authority to review labelling size, I ask whether this review, which normally takes up to 12 months, could be accelerated as a matter of urgency under section 37 of the National Food Authority Act.

—Senator Boswell, along with Arch Bevis in Queensland, has taken a particular interest in the question of the size of labels which indicate whether a particular product is a food product of Australia rather than from overseas. It has been very gratifying to see in the last week that in relation to unpackaged food—nuts, fish, fruit and vegetables—there is now a requirement that those unpackaged foods should carry a label of 4.5 millimetres indicating whether they come from overseas. I think that will enable Australians in the marketplace to make choices that aid our farmers and our fisherpeople in their occupations.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth noting that only last week controversy arose in Queensland where a particular supermarket chain was forced to withdraw some 9,000 packets of nuts from its shelves after it was accused of misleading consumers about the origin of the nuts. Apparently the chain had a label which in large print said `Produce of Australia', and below that in very much smaller print was a message that read `or China'. That was thought by many to be misleading. I have referred it to the Trade Practices Commission for its investigation of whether this was a practice that could be regarded as deceptive and misleading in the marketplace and therefore contrary to the provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

It is a fact that the question of the size of the print on the labels indicating whether a product is produced in Australia or overseas has been a matter of some controversy. At the moment it is 1.5 millimetres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very small.

—Do not forget that it is only a minimum. If Australian manufacturers of food products want to encourage Australians to purchase those products, they should ignore the minimum requirement and advertise that fact in very bold print as an incentive for Australians in the marketplace, the supermarkets, to support their own farmers and those of the fishing industry, for example.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the National Food Authority is considering an application from the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing, which I think is a Queensland-based organisation, to increase the print size of country of origin labelling on packaged goods from 1.5 millimetres to a 3-millimetre minimum.

The application will be dealt with by the National Food Authority under the public procedures laid down in the National Food Authority Act. That will involve the Authority making a full assessment, after seeking public comment on the application. If it decides to prepare a draft standard of variation of the standard, again it will need to seek the input of interested parties. It has a statutory obligation to make a recommendation in respect of an application within 12 months of receiving that application. In other words, I believe that it should be able to complete this task by the end of the year or a little after that.

For that reason, it will not be possible for the National Food Standards Council to consider the matter at its meeting in April 1992. However, I suggest that Senator Boswell and other parties with an interest in this matter should take the opportunity to make further submissions to the Authority. I am quite sure that those submissions will be taken into account in its deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of claims in an article in this morning's Australian Financial Review that the Department of the Treasury has correctly analysed the effect of inflation on a proposed taxation system? If so, what is his view of these claims?

—The extraordinary thing about the poor old HMS Fightback! is that it is springing a lot of leaks now; it is running out of steam as it goes on. That is not surprising: it is an old model, dating from the Thatcher and Reagan period. As HMS Fightback! gets under a little bit of pressure, we see the captain rolling his marbles, rolling his eyes every day—
—It's a pity you have lost yours.

—Captain Queeg Hewson starts to roll his marbles every day—something which Senator Alston has been doing for a very long time. Yesterday Dr Hewson said at the Press Club that he would have to increase his promised tax cuts—the formerly sacrosanct tax cuts—to compensate for inflation. It just shows how fragile the whole package is.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury analysis shows how much worse off most people would be under the package proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition cannot say that the Treasury is to be damned for all time, as is the ABC, and then say, `But we will react to this criticism and that one. There may be a few problems along the line; we may have to put a bit of paint over old Fightback! in order to keep the thing going'. There is a $4 billion hole in the package: expenditure cuts are overstated to the tune of $2.7 billion, the tax revenue to the tune of $1.1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I remind you of your own rulings in this matter. I know that the Minister is embarrassed by his own package and, therefore, chooses to talk about the Opposition's package instead. He is really entitled to speak only about those matters in the question which pertain to his portfolio. That is your ruling, Mr President. I ask you to uphold it.

—On the point of order: apart from the speech Senator Bishop made before the point of order, Senator Button is referring to a document prepared by the Treasury. He is referring to it in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. Of course, it is exactly within his portfolio. This is another spurious point of order from people who then complain because they do not get enough questions.
—Order! The Minister is in order.

—The function of the back bench on HMS Fightback! is to say, `Heave ho, Fightback!, heave ho, Fightback!' all the time—`Four legs good, two legs bad'. Senator Bishop's function is to take points of order and to shout slogans on this dreadful ship.

PARA.TAB: There are two key flaws in the Opposition's modelling of the GST. I illustrate those by referring to the Treasury model. First, the Opposition is trying to make one pot of money—I said this yesterday—do two things: compensate for the effects of the GST part of the package and compensate for bracket creep with the same amount of money. Secondly, the Opposition has not attempted to fully analyse the distributional effects of the welter of taxing and spending changes it suggests.

One very important thing which has emerged in the last day or two is that the Opposition package shows that it does not understand bracket creep. Honourable senators opposite show that they do not understand bracket creep by the questions they ask. They did understand bracket creep when they purported to introduce tax indexation during the last Liberal Government. They introduced tax indexation in response to an election promise and it lasted one year. When they introduced it at the time of the last Liberal Government and it lasted one year, they assessed it on the basis of the CPI, not on the basis of wage movements, which is what the present Fightback proposal purports to do.

The Opposition shows that it does not understand that wage growth and inflation are different things. Senator Hill frowns because these are concepts that he, as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, has never grappled with. Indexation of the income tax scales requires that they be adjusted by the rate of inflation rather than the growth in average earnings. The Opposition has used the wrong figures to calculate the necessary indexation adjustment of the tax scales.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have even had the points underlined for you.

—No, I did that myself. The rate of inflation relevant to households is the CPI, not the growth in average earnings, which is the basis which the Opposition uses. There are new flaws, cracks and holes emerging in the Fightback package every day. They are reflected in the demeanour of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and in the demeanour and behaviour of honourable senators opposite in this place.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The Minister will recall speeches he made to the legal fraternity in Tasmania and other States at functions marking the official opening of the legal year, in which he said that the coalition's Fightback package would reduce the amount of Federal funding for legal aid and result in an increase of 15 per cent in costs to legal aid work referred to private lawyers. As the shadow Treasurer has directly refuted this statement, does the Minister now admit that he was wrong and that he misled the legal fraternity at the most important event in its calendar? If so, will he now publicly apologise to the Australian legal fraternity? Also, was the Minister aware at the time he made those speeches that his Government intended to impose by regulation gigantic fee increases for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Family, Federal and High courts? Those regulations were tabled by the Government last week. Would those fee increases have resulted in, for example, an increase of $3,000 to $4,000 in the cost of a three-day family law court matter if they had passed the Senate?
—Order! There have been three very long questions today.

—I find it extraordinary that Senator Walters has the gall to ask this particular question, particularly of me as a person who has, in Budget negotiations—for example, in the last Budget—secured an extra $2m for legal aid commissions throughout Australia; and who has doubled the money for community legal centres which provide legal advice for persons in their local communities and which, by the way, as lawyers on the opposite side will know, encourages the more ethical and professional members of the legal fraternity to come to those community legal centres and offer their services for free in order to give advice. This Government can be extremely proud of its record in that respect.

PARA.TAB: However, it is absolutely uncontestable that there is a warning, a direct assertion, in the Fightback package that $10m will be slashed from the legal aid budget as funded by the Commonwealth Government. When that is apportioned amongst the legal aid commissions throughout Australia, that must translate to many thousands of cases which will be unable to be funded. This means that when clients approach legal aid commissions for assistance—for example, in the Magistrates Court when facing a criminal charge, or in relation to Family Court matters—those legal aid commissions will be $10m less able to provide those particular services. That is absolutely uncontestable.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about administrative savings?
—There are not $10m worth of administrative savings to be made. Administrative savings on that scale are impossible.
—Oh, are they?

—Yes, because the administration of the legal aid commissions costs about $11.3m Australia-wide. One cannot take $10m away from that and leave them as viable institutions. In relation to the further matter as to whether legal aid commissions will be required to pay the 15 per cent GST on the services they purchase from private legal practitioners on behalf of clients, that is a matter which—
—You were wrong.

—I do not believe I am wrong, and I believe that what I have asked for ought to be acceded to by the Opposition; that is, that it adopt the Canadian precedent. The Canadians found that the legal aid commissions, as is the case here, are not quite properly described as benevolent institutions, charitable institutions or businesses providing services; they are a bit of a mixture, as Senator Vanstone, Senator Durack and others will know, because of the contributions regime. It is not easy to put them into a simple definition. In Canada, with the GST, the legislature explicitly and expressly in the statute excluded legal aid commissions from the operation of the GST. If the Opposition were to give a firm undertaking to adopt the Canadian precedent, I would be the first to congratulate it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister first of all tried to filibuster on the administrative savings in the Fightback package. That is nothing to do with his statement on the 15 per cent.
—Ask the supplementary question.

—The Minister said that he believed he was still right. The Minister does understand. The shadow Treasurer has already said he was wrong—on the day following his first attempt at telling that untruth—
—Order! Senator Walters, ask the supplementary question.
—I am. Senator Watson explained to the Minister that he was wrong. Why did the Minister still go around the country toting that untruth? Will he now please apologise to those that he has misled?

—Mr President, I do not believe that I have analysed the Fightback package wrongly in this regard. In fact, I am fortified in my belief that my analysis is correct by the fact that John Marsden, the President of the New South Wales Law Society, representing all the practitioners in New South Wales, has come to the same conclusion, quite independently and without any aid from me. In that situation, I believe that there is sufficient uncertainty amongst all legal practitioners, as expressed by that spokesman, to give cause for concern. All the Opposition needs to do is say that it will adopt the Canadian precedent. If the Opposition does that, as I say, I will be the first to congratulate it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware that the application of copper sulphate to the waters of the Murray-Darling river system has led to the production of vegetable crops in the irrigated areas on the Murray in South Australia which contain copper above acceptable levels and that farmers have been prohibited from selling such contaminated crops? Has the Government or the Murray-Darling Commission any alternative way of controlling algal bloom? Does the Government have any suggestions as to how the affected farmers can earn a living until copper levels in the soil return to acceptable levels?

—I am not aware of the circumstances described in this question from Senator Lees. To the best of my knowledge, copper sulphate is not applied to river waters. In fact, a copper based algaecide is routinely applied to reservoirs designated as town water supplies and sometimes those waters are used for irrigation, although one would consider that, of course, a copper based algaecide applied to water for human consumption would be unlikely to have an impact on vegetable growth that would put the vegetables above any such limit to which Senator Lees referred in her question.

PARA.TAB: I am also aware that the algaecide was applied to the river water at Bourke by the Bourke Shire Council, although the New South Wales Pollution Control Commission became aware of it and the Council subsequently stopped this practice immediately. However, there is no evidence that this would cause the problem to which reference has been made.

I am not aware of farmers being prohibited from selling crops because of copper contamination, although there is no reason why the Commonwealth Government would be aware of that directly. If that occurred, then in this context the South Australian Government would be likely to be the government made aware of it.

I think the third part of the question related to alternative ways of handling algal bloom. The preferred method of controlling algal bloom is to address the underlying cause, which is nutrient accession to receiving waters. Reducing nutrient input is a matter of minimising nutrient outflows from point sources such as sewerage plants, and from diffuse sources such as animal manure from agricultural lands. Those issues can only be addressed in the long term.

In the short term the most practical approach is to manage river flow regimes to minimise conditions suitable for algal growth. I understand that under several of the Commonwealth Government programs—the Australian Water Resources Council and their programs, the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council and the management of the Murray-Darling system, and the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation—measures are in place to attempt to manage the problem in both the immediate and the long term.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Can the Minister confirm that under the provisions of Medicare a safety net operates to ensure that over the course of 12 months no Australian is required to pay more than $246 in gap payments for medical services? Can the Minister also confirm that this 12-month period has recently been changed from a July to June financial year to a January to December calendar year? Is it true that as a result of this change some Australians are now being required to pay up to $492 over the 12-month period before the safety net provisions come into effect? If so, when did the Government become aware of this `unforeseen consequence', how many people are affected, and what action has the Government taken to rectify the mess and to see that those unfairly treated are properly compensated.

—The Government is absolutely committed to this safety net in order to protect Australian families from the ravages of high expenditure in relation to the provision of health care. In particular, the decision to abolish the co-payment was taken with the rider that the safety net provisions in relation to that should continue despite the abolition of the co-payment.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the decision that any particular family need not pay more than $246 in any calendar year is one to which this Government is absolutely committed. I can assure the honourable senator that I will take the question back to Mr Howe's office and that that particular undertaking will be fulfilled.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Medical School at University of Tasmania

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian strongly suggesting that the medical school at the University of Tasmania will be closed down as part of the rationalisation of the number of graduates from Australian medical schools? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the suggestion in the article is true?

—I did see an article in yesterday's Australian entitled `Medical Schools Under Siege' which suggested that, amongst other difficulties facing various medical schools, the University of Tasmania Medical School could indeed be abolished, should be closed or could be `terminated' to use the expression in the article. This, of course, has been a great cause for concern in the last 24 hours in Tasmania, particularly for the University of Tasmania. Its Vice-Chancellor has made statements such as that the closure of the medical school would mean that the quality of medical care in Tasmania would be devastated, and that is undoubtedly the case.

PARA.TAB: This particularly mischievous speculation needed to be countered and the threat removed. Indeed, Mr Howe's office has described to me this particular article as being very much in the speculative arena. Mr Howe has given me an assurance that the Tasmanian medical school is not threatened and that the Tasmanian medical school will continue to operate as a full medical school. That is a very important undertaking, as I am sure Senator Walters would acknowledge, because from time to time this particular medical school has been threatened on one basis or another. It is very important that these particular media leaks or beat-ups should not be used by those who wish to undermine that very fine medical school.

In particular, it is important to note that the University of Tasmania is minded to establish a new chair in general practice and rural health matters based at the University of Tasmania's Launceston campus; in fact, I think at the Launceston General Hospital. This is entirely in line with the Federal Government's strategy in relation to the provision of primary health care, particularly in rural areas throughout Australia. We know that the question of the oversupply of doctors is not a crude question of numbers; it is also a question of their distribution and their concentration in urban, as opposed to rural, communities. That, of course, has a major impact in Tasmania, which is so decentralised and is perhaps Australia's most rural State.

I believe that with the University of Tasmania undertaking its organisation of the chairs and their distribution in northern and southern Tasmania and the subjects that they are particularly concerned to deal with, linked to our national health strategy, that should give an absolute assurance that there would be no threat to the University of Tasmania Medical School. I have received that assurance from Mr Brian Howe's office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of the extreme concern in the accounting and financial planning professions about the proven inefficiencies of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in handling determinations on retirees' eligible termination payments with 90 per cent of its determinations proving to be incorrect, requiring costly and time consuming intervention by professional advisers? Is the Minister aware that, because of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission's incorrect determinations, retirees may suffer high tax payouts on superannuation which may go undetected for many years, to the detriment of retirees? What will the Government do to sort out the continuing mess in the Insurance and Superannuation Commission which I first drew to his attention in September 1991?

—I am aware of some of the allegations that have been made. I was not aware that they were as extensive as indicated by Senator Chapman's question. I will seek an answer from the Minister for Senator Chapman and provide it as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. Further to an earlier question by Senator Parer about the allocation of $20m for the upgrading of the Townsville port, is the Minister able to report just how those funds will benefit the local economy and whether the $20m has the support of the local community and, indeed, its political representatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier today in Question Time—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Could you rule for me on the question of questions without notice? The Minister got on his phone, obtained a question, took it up to Senator Reynolds and quite publicly indicated that it was to be asked. It is obviously not a question without notice; it is a question that Senator Collins has arranged.
—Order! There is no point of order. How could I have knowledge of what you have claimed?

—Senator Macdonald's embarrassment will soon become very obvious. I am pleased to say that I was very fortunate in securing Cabinet support for the injection of $20m worth of Federal funding for Townsville, funding which Senator Parer today described here in the Senate chamber as `a waste of taxpayers' money'.
—And fantasy, too.

—And fantasy, too—Senator Parer has confirmed it. He said that it is `a waste of taxpayers' money and fantasy'. Now that we have got the money—the $20m—for Townsville, we will be able, in negotiations that will occur, to determine what this money will be spent on to enhance the port facilities. These facilities will include—
—Tell us.

—I am telling Senator Parer. These facilities will include the construction of a breakwater and a rail loop—as Senator Parer says quite correctly—which will service not only Queensland Nickel, that is, Yabulu, but also Mount Isa Mines. The Mount Isa Mines facility currently has no rail access, meaning that lead slabs that come into the port of Townsville from Mount Isa have to be transferred from rail onto road and then transferred by road onto the wharf. In addition, Mount Isa Mines has firm plans to import into the port of Townsville 200,000 tonnes of copper concentrate a year, which will be greatly enhanced by this development.
—Wrong, wrong, wrong.
—It is right, of course. Instead of attacking the Government, Senator Parer should check with his Queensland Senate colleague who has an office in Townsville.
—I did.
—Senator Parer says he did. This is what his Queensland colleague said on radio in Townsville the day before the One Nation document was produced. The transcript from radio 4RR news states:

ANSWER.PARA: ANNOUNCER: Northern based Liberal Senator Ian Macdonald says the Prime Minister's Economic Statement due out tomorrow must contain funding for the up-grading of the Townsville Port if the Federal Government is to demonstrate a real commitment to North Queensland. Leaks have shown the Economic Statement will include provisions—
no wonder he was trying to shut me up—
for major infrastructure programs for Australian ports, however there are indications that Townsville could miss out.
they would if this mob were in, obviously—
Senator Macdonald says the upgrade of the Port is essential if the future of the Yabulu Refinery is to be guaranteed.

I heard on the news this morning that a team of 20 Opposition senators is about to `blitz' north Queensland—they are about to leave. Could I suggest that, before they leave, they have a meeting and decide whether they are going to blitz northern Queensland by supporting it or attacking it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and relates to the CAA's evaluation of new radar systems to control Australian airspace. Is it correct that the committee reviewing the tenders was recently changed and that all those who had spoken out against the Thomson system were removed from the committee? Furthermore, will the Minister give an undertaking that, after the winner of the tender is decided, the evaluation scores of each tenderer under the operational, technical, civil works and project management criteria will be made public?

—I have no difficulty in saying that I am sure the tenderers would be horrified at any pronouncement by me that the mass of commercially confidential information they have provided the CAA in bidding for this tender would be made public. I am sure it would be an absolute industrial gift to their competitors. So I have no difficulty in rejecting that ridiculous assertion.

PARA.TAB: Could I also reject equally comprehensively the assertion by Senator O'Chee in the first part of his statement. Nobody has been sacked or kicked off the evaluation panel because he supports one system or another. The CAA is undergoing an extremely exhaustive process of evaluating a tender that will be let shortly, which will ensure that for the first time in this country's history we have a national system of air traffic control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did not ask that all of the tender material be made public; I merely asked for the evaluation scores on those four criteria only so that the Australian population can be assured that, for example, F28 aircraft are not going to disappear off the radar screens like they do with the current Thomson system in Cairns.

—The assertions that Senator O'Chee once again is making are made from profound ignorance. He has made simple minded assertions that the current radar in Cairns is not settling in properly. Senator O'Chee would be aware—maybe he would not be aware—that there is not an air traffic control system in the world, each one of which has to be tailored to the region that it serves, that does not have settling in problems. We have had problems with every radar installation in Australia, including ATCARDS in Melbourne just recently. That is common with all air traffic control systems around the world. All of them require a settling in period, and that applies also to Cairns.

PARA.TAB: As I said in the earlier answer, what the Civil Aviation Authority is doing—and I am pleased that it is doing it—is removing, and it is about time, the ancient system of air traffic control that has existed in this country for a very long time, where our air traffic control regions are divided according to State boundaries rather than where the aircraft actually fly. After this tender is awarded, this country will have a state of the art, world class, national air traffic control system.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Compulsory Abortions and Sterilisations in China

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the report of the Australian human rights delegation to China which repeated, without challenge, assurances by the Sichuan Province family planning officials that compulsory abortions and sterilisations were prohibited. Is it a fact that the Sichuan Province family planning regulations were not given to the delegation until the delegation reached China? Is it also a fact that a portion only of those regulations was translated into English—that portion which related to exemptions from the one child per family policy—and that those provisions requiring compulsory abortions and sterilisations were not translated? Why was the delegation not given regulations and evidence from other provinces which show that such gross violations of human rights are widespread and are systemic to the Chinese population control program, which would have enabled the delegation to challenge the assurances given to it? Is it a fact that the person who briefed the delegation was an academic contracted by the Department and by AIDAB, whose interpretive knowledge of the subject has been seriously challenged by a number of China experts?

—I thought the matters raised by Senator Harradine had been exhaustively and exhaustingly dealt with in the last Estimates Committee hearings and in a subsequent briefing.
