If there is any matter to which Senator Harradine now refers that was not so dealt with in those hearings and that subsequent briefing, I will ensure that he gets a further answer. I am not in a position to give him such an answer now.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I raise the question today because Senator Evans told me previously to raise the matter with the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I attempted to do that yesterday by attempting to have the matter referred to the Committee. The Minister voted against that. That is why I am asking the question here and now. Given the fact that there are well founded views held which contradict the views of the person who briefed the delegation, in the interests of truth and open debate will the Minister ensure that AIDAB publishes a response to the monograph it commissioned from Dr Hull?

—There are a number of ways of raising these matters with the Committee other than by referring them and occupying its time—time which is already being comprehensively wasted by another reference to it on the conduct and operations of my Department. I am not surprised that the Senate yesterday voted as it did to reject this reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is owed some answers to questions he directed to the Treasurer. On 13 November 1991 he asked a question about anomalies in Taxation Office rulings relating to racehorses. I have an answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 13 November 1991:

(1) With reference to the anomaly that exists as a result of a ruling issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) with regard to the selling of race horses for more than $5000 are owners now to be taxed on any profit made on the sale of a horse for more than $5000.
(2) If owners are not entitled to a tax deduction if the horse is sold at a loss, why does this unfair and unjustified situation exist.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Where a race horse is owned for personal use or enjoyment and not for the purpose of income production then such a horse is classified under the capital gains tax provisions of the tax law as a non-listed personal use asset. Taxation Ruling IT 2585 explains the operation of the capital gains provisions to non-listed personal use assets, particularly in relation to horses raced as a hobby. Where the cost base or indexed cost base of a non-listed personal-use asset would otherwise be less than $5,000, the cost base or indexed cost base is taken to be $5,000. The effect is that a taxpayer will accrue a capital gain calculated under the normal rules, or calculated as though the cost base or indexed cost base was $5,000, whichever gives the lesser gain.

(2) The disposal of a non-listed personal use asset does not give rise to an allowable capital loss. As such assets are primarily for personal use, if these losses were to be deductible against capital gains generally the tax system would be effectively subsidising the related personal consumption expenditures since the stream of services provided by the asset remains untaxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago Senator Kernot asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question on foreign investment controls on the acquisition of rural land. I have now obtained an answer from the Treasurer and I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Before the Prime Minister's One Nation Economic Statement, Government policy required proposals by foreigners to buy rural properties (essentially working farms) for more than $3 million to be submitted to the Foreign Investment Review Board.
However, such proposals were normally approved unless national interest considerations arose.
The Economic Statement raised the examination threshold to $50 million, while still requiring proposals below $50 million but above $3 million to be notified and registered.
The Government welcomes foreign investment in rural properties. It brings new capital, management techniques and linkages to international markets for our agricultural sector.
It should be noted that foreign investment in the rural sector is not high.
The latest ABS figures show that foreign ownership accounted for less than 6 per cent of all Australian agricultural land in 1983-84.

Over five years from 1986-87 to 1990-91, only 135 foreign investment proposals for rural properties over $3 million were submitted to the FIRB for examination. The average consideration involved was about $8.5 million.
It should also be noted that from time to time foreign investors withdraw, selling their Australian properties to Australian investors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asked me a question in relation to bracket creep and for his edification I now provide an answer which I wish to table. It will provide him with some reading in the next couple of weeks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short claimed in a question on bracket creep yesterday that there was a fundamental technical and conceptual error in the Treasury analysis of the GST package.
On the contrary it is Senator Short's question and the Opposition package that contain the flaws.
Senator Short does not understand the difference between inflation and wages growth.

Point 1: the impact of bracket creep on any particular household is calculated by comparing the tax payable under the legislated tax scales with what would be payable if the tax thresholds had been indexed for inflation since some base period.
Just to make that clear, inflation is measured as the increase in the CPI, not by growth in average earnings or the price of a Ferrari.

In the Treasury analysis, the relevant comparison then is between the tax payable under the Opposition's proposed tax scales and that which would have been paid had the legislated rate scale been indexed for inflation between the June quarter 1993 and the March quarter 1996.
Point 2: in clear contrast to how you index the tax thresholds, the only way to calculate tax revenue from bracket creep is to calculate the growth in taxable incomes, not the rate of inflation.
In other words, you collect revenue from wage increases, not increases in the CPI per se.
Growth in taxable incomes is usually approximated by growth in average earnings, not the increase in the CPI.
This is the approach adopted by the Opposition in its manifesto and it is exactly the same approach that was adopted by the official agencies in costing those proposals.
The Opposition claimed that the tax cuts it was proposing would return $3 billion of bracket creep. In fact, the Treasury analysis shows that the true amount that should be returned is $4.2 billion.

This $4.2 billion reflects the difference between the tax that would be paid under the Opposition's scales and what would be paid if the legislated scales were indexed for inflation between the June quarter 1993 and the March quarter 1996.

Just make sure you understand this—that does not mean that there is an additional $1.2 billion floating around. It simply means that within the total revenue the Opposition's proposals would raise, the amount they are calling bracket creep is understated and the amount they are calling `legitimate' revenue is overstated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by Senator Collins earlier today in Question Time in regard to proposed expenditure of $20m to be spent in the Port of Townsville.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins in his answer to me today said that the reason for the expenditure of $20m in the Port of Townsville was to secure the prospects of 900 workers at Yabulu. Senator Collins was clearly wrong in that remark. I do not know the reason for it. Greenvale Nickel, which is the company to which Senator Collins referred, ran out of viable ore and was required to import ore from New Caledonia to refine at Yabulu. The most cost efficient way to do so and to avoid double handling was to build a jetty at Halifax Bay.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't get out of the embarrassment you got into at Question Time. You'll have to sort it out with your colleagues, not in the Senate.

—It was prevented from doing so because of the actions of the extreme Green movement, of which I am sure even Senator Button would not approve. The company is currently importing the ore through the Port of Townsville. Greenvale Nickel is appealing that decision before the AAT.

PARA.TAB: However, when the Goss Government came into power it threw out the chairman and most of the board of the Port Authority, which over the years had done a pretty good job. The new Chairman, in keeping with the actions of the Goss Government, was one of its mates—the ex-Labor mayor, Mike Reynolds. To show how even-handed it was, it also put on the Board a wharfie named Dale Parker, whose only claim to fame has been to earn money and a reputation by workers' compensation claims.

To build a monument to himself, however, the Chairman, Mike Reynolds, thought that it would be a good idea to build an outer harbour. The major users of the port—and there are only two: Mount Isa Mines and Greenvale Nickel—quickly distanced themselves from this fantasy which had an estimated cost of $80m. Naturally, a company such as MIM, which already had berths in the port of Townsville and already had sufficient capacity to include the import of 200,000 tonnes of ore, to which Senator Collins referred in his answer, publicly distanced itself from this fantasy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know all that—better than you do.

—What happened was that the Treasurer of Queensland, Mr de Lacy, came to his mates' aid and told the companies to stop publicly criticising what was clearly an irresponsible and lunatic idea. It is interesting that the Queensland State Government itself did not even totally support this project to the Federal Labor Government.
—You don't know what you are talking about. You had better check with Senator Macdonald. He is your embarrassment.

—Then why did you not give them $80m, if you are fair dinkum? Meanwhile, Mount Isa and Greenvale came to an agreement for Greenvale to use one of the MIM berths, at a very cheap cost. A project that has jokingly been called around Townsville `Reynolds memorial', which none of the users would have a bar of, popped up in the Keating economic statement. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is quoted as saying, not in respect of this but in respect of the economy as a whole, `You are only cheating yourself if you run policies which have scarce national savings going to the wrong places'.

PARA.TAB: We have tried to make sure that our scarce savings go to the most productive places. Clearly, this money is not going to the most productive place. What is it to be spent on? Senator Collins told Senator Reynolds and me that it would be spent on a rail loop. As I indicated in my question, there is already a rail loop at the Port of Townsville. The rail loop cost the Port Authority nothing because it was installed by the owners of the Duchess phosphate deposit some years ago. Honourable senators may or may not be aware that that project never got off the ground. But the rail loop remains. The question is: why build another rail loop? There have been anecdotal stories around Townsville as to why Mr Reynolds wants to do this, but I will not use this place to quote them because they are somewhat defamatory.

The balance of $12m was to be spent on land reclamation and dredging associated with the outer harbour fantasy. In fact, when Mr Reynolds was asked, `If this is only phase one of a $80m investment, when is the rest of the project going to be finished?', he said, `I don't know'. I do not believe that it will ever be finished. These are the facts. I do not care what Senator Collins says or what Senator Reynolds says by way of interjection, I checked with the users.

This raises a very serious question with respect to the sixteenth Keating economic statement. How many other examples of this sort of wastage of taxpayers' money will pop out of the woodwork. Why did the Government do it? Did it not do its homework? Is it a pay-off to a Labor mate for some sort of self-glorification? It highlights a degree of vandalism. I say `vandalism' because the Government has vandalised the country not just in respect of the taxpayer but in respect of the record number of bankruptcies we have had and the million unemployed. Hence, we have had an attack on the Hewson Fightback package which, for the first time, offered hope. The package offered a ray of hope to a whole lot of people out there who had not hope and still have no hope under this Government.

We have seen the latest economic package from Prime Minister Keating and the acid test will be in six, seven or eight months time. What will be the situation then? Will those million people have work? Will we be on track? Will there be more import replacement? Will more real jobs be created? Ideally, as an Australian, I would like to say yes, but I doubt it. That will be the acid test and it will be what brings this Government down at the next election.

I want to clarify a misleading remark made by Senator Collins in his answer. The Opposition clearly supports infrastructure spending where it has clear cost benefits and contributes to productivity and efficiency and where it means more exports or real job creation. We do not disagree with that. I, as a Queenslander, support the building of the rail link from Acacia Ridge to Fishermans Island. I think it should have been done years ago. However, the expenditure on what appears to be—on my own investigations and on discussions with the users; they are the people who count—a white elephant is nothing more than abuse of the taxpayer.

This Government has an obligation to give clear answers as to what this is all about. The $20m could have been spent; I would not deny north Queensland the expenditure of $20m. The more that can be spent up there—one of the most progressive parts of this country—the more I am sure my colleagues would support me on this; and they would support the Government if it did it. However, this $20m has been spent in the wrong place and it raises serious doubts about the whole integrity of this package, which is just throwing money at something which cannot be and has not been justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party in Townsville, and in Queensland generally, is in absolute turmoil over what to do with the Yabulu nickel treatment plant, how to service it and how to save the 1,000 jobs that are so important in that area. Senator Collins has tried to get some kudos and brownie points for the Labor Party by making smart announcements in the north—in the Townsville region. He even wasted some $300,000 worth of taxpayers' money to establish an office for himself in that particular town that he has used only once this year. He had to do something to try to bail out his mates in the Labor Party controlled Townsville City Council and the Queensland State Government over the nickel treatment plant which is about to close down. With the tacit encouragement of the Labor Party, the Green movement took some action which prevented Queensland Nickel's first preference—to have a long jetty out into Halifax Bay.

PARA.TAB: There is all sorts of trouble within the Labor Party—different factions supporting different proposals because there are 1,000 jobs at stake. Heaven knows, Townsville needs jobs. The Townsville region does not need 1,000 people to be thrown out of work; it does not need another 1,000 people to be put on the already huge unemployment queue. The Labor Party has to do something but it does not know quite what to do.

The area has three State Labor members. Some of them want to do something; some of them want to do something else. We have a Queensland government that does not quite know what it wants to do. We have an atrocious Labour Council that has always been anti-development. We have Mr Lindsay and Senator Reynolds, who I think belong to different factions and who are always at each other's throats on different things. The Labor Party knows that Mr Lindsay is about to lose the contest for the electorate of Herbert to the Liberal candidate, Mr Peter Hazard, and it is petrified about it. It had to do something to pork barrel some money in there.

The real problem is that half the Labor Party in Townsville wants one thing and the other half wants something different. The south Townsville region, in which the electorate of the Queensland Minister for Small Business, Mr Geoff Smith, is based, contains a lot of people who are very concerned about the dust nuisance that might arise from the port being used to import nickel ore and also the problems with rail and interruption to traffic. The Labor Party aldermen who hold the wards out that way are also petrified that they are going to be tossed out by their traditional Labor voters at the next election because of the menace of dust, noise and traffic interruptions—all the sorts of things that are causing absolute turmoil.

As you would well know, Mr Deputy President, the Labor Party in Townsville is in absolute turmoil over the whole thing. It is trying to save Mr Lindsay's seat but it does not quite know how to do it. It has announced this project. We tried to find out the next day what the project was for.

From my reading of the `Done Nation' or `One Job' statement, $20m is to be used on port infrastructure in Queensland, including the Townsville port. It did not say there was going to be $20m for the Townsville port; it said there was $20m for Queensland, including the Townsville port. I tried to find out just how much of that was going to the Townsville port. I could not get anything from anyone who might know anything about it. I ended up getting my information from radio and newspaper journalists who told me what Mr Lindsay was telling them. I still do not quite know where they get all the figures from. I do know that to do what needs to be done, the Townsville port area needs something like $70m to $80m, not $20m, and not the $25m that was leaked by the Labor Party the day before the `One Job' statement was released.

So one wonders just what it is all about. There are a lot of projects in the Townsville region that are very deserving of government spending. I only have to point out to you, Mr Deputy President, that the roads in that area desperately need a lot of funding. We get lots of promises from Mr Lindsay and Mr Brown—we got lots of promises from Mr Hawke when he used to come up there every now and again to bolster up Mr Lindsay's chances of retaining his seat—but we never see much action in respect of roads up there.

We really need that Queensland nickel plant to keep going. It needs a hell of a lot of support. It needs real support from both the Queensland Government and the Federal Government—and it does not need the Federal Government to continue to be hijacked by the radical Green movement, as it always is with a lot of projects in north Queensland, such as the Tully-Millstream project and the Yabulu nickel treatment plant. This Federal Government tried to bail out the Queensland Government by deferring decisions all the time, so that no decision would have to be made and the Labor Party would not have these huge fights between its right wing and its left wing and its environmental wing and its pro-development wing.

One might wonder whether something might not need to be done to look into what is happening at the Townsville port. The Townsville port was always a very efficient organisation. It was until recently chaired by a colleague of mine on the Burdekin Shire Council, who with his predecessors did a marvellous job in that port. He had a very good board which did a lot of work there. Those people were sacked with the advent of the Goss Government, when its jobs for the boys program came in and the former Labor Mayor of Townsville was appointed as the new Port Authority Chairman.

That did not bring much surprise in Townsville because we are used to jobs for the boys from the Labor Party in that area. It has even got to the ridiculous stage, Mr Deputy President, as you would well know, where a former Labor Party alderman on the Townsville City Council transferred down to Redcliffe and then took on, would you believe, a job on the hospital board there—down in Redcliffe, miles away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chairman.

—Yes, chairman of the hospital board, miles and miles away without any real background or authority in that regard. It just amazes me what is happening with that Townsville Harbour Board. We have heard what Senator Parer has said about the users of the port and what he is told by the users of the port. We read statements from the Labor Mayor, Mr Mooney. We read statements from the Labor State Government. We listen to what Mr Lindsay says. We listen to what Senator Reynolds says in her questions, supposedly without notice—although everyone could see that Senator Collins picked up his phone, got the information, went and dictated it to Senator Reynolds, and then answered it. If that is not an abuse of the procedures of the Senate, I do not know what is. But we have all these different Labor Party people in Townsville making contradictory statements.

PARA.TAB: I just wonder whether we should not have some sort of inquiry into what is happening in the Townsville port. What is going to happen? What about this rail loop which Senator Parer says is already there, despite somebody announcing that it is to be put ahead. Maybe we should have an inquiry to see what the local Labor alderman wants to do about the dust and the noise and traffic interruption in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or what deals have been done.

—Or what deals have been done, as Senator Tambling says. Maybe there needs to be some sort of an inquiry into all these sorts of things. I hope for Townsville's sake that something positive comes out of this. In north Queensland, and in all parts of remote and rural Australia, the `Kickback' statement, the `One Job' statement, the `Done Australia' statement did nothing for the north and did nothing for regional Australia. In fact, there are huge projects for fixing the national rail highway and national road highway, but as you would know, Mr Deputy President—and you are pretty happy about this—it all stops at Brisbane. The $1.79 billion of goodies being given out in the `One Job' statement is all for the south of Australia. There is nothing for up where I come from, and nothing at all for remote and regional Australia. It all stops on the Brisbane line.
—Like a sewerage dam?

—I am offered a sewerage dam from Western Australia; I understand that they do not even know what it is about over there. I know there is a lot of muck coming out of the Labor Party as a result of the Royal Commission there, and maybe that is what the sewerage treatment plant is for—to throw in all the muck that has come out about the Labor Government in Western Australia as a result of that Royal Commission. I suspect that that is what it is about. But these goodies all stop at Brisbane. There is nothing for the north.

PARA.TAB: The Government threw in this paltry $3m for a duplication of University Road. Neither the City Council nor the aldermen—in fact nobody—knew where it was to go. It needs the duplication of a bridge before the road goes ahead, but there is absolute turmoil there. It was one of those things thrown in in a desperate but very vain and unsuccessful attempt to retain Mr Lindsay in his job as the Federal member for Herbert.

I am very pleased to say that the Liberal candidate, Mr Peter Hazzard, will be representing the seat of Herbert, which is based on Townsville, after the next election. Townsville will then have some decent representation. It will then get some real projects going—real projects such as Townsville used to have when a Liberal government was in power. I refer to the Burdekin Dam, the Lavarack Army Barracks and the marine institute—all of those really beneficial projects for Townsville which were all initiated when Herbert was represented by Mr Duke Bonnett as the Liberal member, followed by Mr Gordon Dean as the Liberal member. We need to return to the days when Townsville was getting something. It certainly needs some government assistance but, as Senator Parer pointed out, is this the right way to go?

I suggest that there are many other ways in which money could be put into that area. Mr Lindsay does not say much about it. Senator Reynolds is almost speechless when it comes to promoting the North. I continue to try to get government money into the North—into Townsville, into Cairns, into Mackay, into Mount Isa—but this Labor Government is absolutely pathetic in the way it deals with it. It only does something when an election is coming up—an election which it knows it will not win this time. The whole thing needs a lot of attention and some real inquiry into just what is happening in that area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion by Senator Parer naturally invites very considered comment in light of the question asked yesterday and the two questions asked today of Senator Collins, in response to which he attempted to blur the issues relating to the One Nation statement and its effect on northern Australia and, particularly today, with regard to proposals for Townsville and the remote and rural areas of northern Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am attracted to the idea put forward by Senator Macdonald that an inquiry should be initiated into the area of transport facilities and infrastructure in northern Australia.In March of last year, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Warren Snowdon, convened an important conference in Alice Springs relating to the issues that impacted on transport in northern Australia. I recently had two questions on notice in this Senate with regard to those transport needs, and I refer in particular to Senate Questions 1662 and 1663 directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) and the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins).

The very detailed answers that have came back in those areas—and I use the word `detailed' because they were lengthy—do not really give any true indication of where decisions could and should have been taken, such as where the proper infrastructure ought to be provided with regard to road works, rail works, port works and so on.

While Senator Macdonald and Senator Parer have highlighted the port development and other needs of Townsville—and the apparent and funny information and advice that has been given to Labor politicians in north Queensland—I am prompted to raise the question of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway because this matter, rightly, has been put on the agenda by the Northern Territory Government. I ask specifically what detailed advice has the Government given to State Labor leaders and State Labor members in Queensland and the Northern Territory, particularly as they relate to the provisions in this One Nation statement?

Earlier this week in the Northern Territory Parliament, the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Brian Ede, said—and I quote from the Northern Territory Hansard: tax breaks and incentives in the form of infrastructure bonds, accelerated depreciation, and development allowances that were announced in the Prime Minister's One Nation package provide taxation incentives of up to $300m for the completion of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link and port facilities in Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the basis of Mr Ede's claim, particularly as there is not one reference to the Alice to Darwin railway in One Nation and as the $300m is not supported in the forward estimates of outlays or revenue given by the Government in the One Nation statement?

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer and Senator Macdonald have very rightly raised the adequacy and the provision of the $20m with regard to the port of Townsville. How is it integrated? How is it linked? Where is it provided for in the forward estimates? If one looks at page 97 of the One Nation document one sees a map which shows the rail infrastructure of Australia. It outlines 12 rail projects. Of course, as Senator Macdonald has rightly pointed out, they are all south of Brisbane. They are all, in one way or another, encompassed in marginal seats. What it really does show is that the only detailing of rail projects that shows Darwin connected to the rest of Australia is by the shore line, not by any other line.

So we have to address these important issues and apparently conflicting information that has been presented to the Senate—whether in answer to questions that have been tabled or not. Certainly I anticipate that in the Senate Estimates this year we will put the Government on notice that Senator Macdonald and I will be pursuing a whole range of these issues very properly with the departmental officials at that particular time.

In comparison to One Nation, and contrary to what Senator Collins said here both yesterday and today, the Fightback package does outline very significant and major advantages for people living in remote and northern Australia. One Nation, and Senator Collins in his answers yesterday and today, did not mention the very significant advantages that will flow through transport and freight costs, particularly because of Fightback completely abolishing the petroleum excise, abolishing wholesale sales tax and also abolishing payroll tax.

The significant freight and personal advantages that will flow to every taxpayer in remote and northern Australia are very adequately illustrated in Fightback! Of course, there is not one mention of any of that in One Nation or in any statement by Senator Collins. What we get thrown at us is purely partial information pulled out of the Treasury documents. I have not yet seen from the Treasury documents any specific statements as they apply to remote, rural or regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with the answers I gave in the Senate today.

—Nor the ones Senator Collins gave yesterday. We certainly do need to note that this is of significant importance, rather than relying on the partial, inadequate and inappropriate answers that Senator Collins comes in and bluffs his way through.
—I wish to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of an answer I gave to a question on the proposed expenditure of $20m in the port of Townsville, and I will be brief.
—That will be a change.

—Yes, and a refreshing one. I have listened with total astonishment today to the contribution of Senator Parer. Perhaps I can understand that, because I think Senator Parer is actually domiciled in Brisbane. I know, however, that Senator Macdonald's electorate office is in the city of Townsville.
—And a great job he does, too.
—Not today. I have been representing, politically, northern Australia for 15 years. And in that time—
—What does Margie do?

—She has also been representing northern Australia for 15 years. We actually have a number of political representatives from northern Australia. There is not just one. Senator MacGibbon would be ignorant of that because he has probably never been north of Brisbane.
—What does John Gayler do?
—He is another one of the political representatives of North Queensland. I will mention Mr Gayler in a minute because I understand that he has just contacted my office.
—Has he?
—Yes, he has, and Senator Macdonald might like to hear about it.
—I was going to leave.

—Senator Macdonald should stick around. He had better hang around here because he will not be welcome back home, I can tell him. He might as well stay in Canberra because they will not want him back in Townsville. I know, as a result of that 15 years, how difficult it is to get our share, as we see it, of Federal Government funding.
—Spend it properly.
—That is not the point of this exercise at all.
—It is not the point!

—Have a look at Hansard afterwards. I listened in my office to what Senator Macdonald said today in response. He said that what really needs to happen in Townsville is not our assistance of $20m for the out-of-berth proposal he spoke about here this afternoon, but the full $70m to $80m to build the out-of-berth project in Townsville harbour—the very project that Senator Parer described as `fantasy and a waste of taxpayers' money'.

PARA.TAB: According to the news this morning, 20 Opposition senators are going to north Queensland. They had better get their act together because the thing will turn into a circus for them, which personally I would be absolutely delighted about. It is difficult enough to get this money—a Budget commitment. Have a look at the answer I gave today in Question Time. As I said, it is subject to further negotiations between the company—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—What does Senator Parer mean by `Ha, ha!'? The money is there; that is the important thing, and it is subject to negotiation with the Queensland Government. My office in Townsville is working very closely with the Premier's office in Queensland to advance this and to make sure that the $20m we have got for Townsville is spent in Townsville.

PARA.TAB: I hate to deliver that bad news to the senator from Townsville, but that is what we will use, despite his protests. What a goose he made of himself in here this afternoon by contradicting today the public statements he made on radio 4RR the day before the One Nation package was brought down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and read what I said and don't be a liar.
—Senator Macdonald will withdraw that.
—Since when are you the President?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask for that imputation that I am a liar to be withdrawn. Might I just say that, to my personal knowledge, it is the third time that that particular appellation has been laid on me by the senator from Queensland. He makes a regular habit of it and I ask him to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I am sorry, I did not hear what Senator Macdonald said. I presume that if the word `liar' was used it will be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say, `Don't be a liar'. If that is offensive, I will withdraw it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, as I said before—

—The transcript will demonstrate that to Senator Macdonald's discomfiture. I do not blame Senator Macdonald for desperately attempting to stop the question being asked by Senator Reynolds at Question Time this afternoon. I have just been informed that the honourable member for Leichhardt, Mr Gayler, apparently has just contacted my office, having heard what has gone on in here this afternoon, and indicated that if the conservative political representatives for Townsville, who in fact have their offices located in Townsville, do not want this $20m of Federal Government money that has been pledged to the city of Townsville, he will be perfectly happy to negotiate it for the city of Cairns instead.

—I had no intention to enter this debate. It has been very amply dealt with by my colleagues. Senator Parer, Senator Macdonald and Senator Tambling have put on the record the things that needed to be said.
