DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's interim response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian Defence Force Reserves. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 27 February 1992
Mr E.J. Lindsay RFD MP
Chairman
Defence Sub-Committee
Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Lindsay
I am writing in regard to the Government's response to the inquiry into the Australian Defence Force Reserves which was tabled in November last year.
As you would be aware, the Government is committed to providing timely responses to reports of parliamentary committees. However, in this case there will be a delay.

A response addressing fully all the recommendations requires detailed consultation and coordination across the Defence organisation. This consultation is necessary as the recommendations are closely linked to the initiatives and policy guidelines provided by the Government-endorsed Force Structure Review and associated studies which are now being implemented.

I am satisfied that the process is moving as quickly as possible but there will be a delay of about two months before the response can be tabled. I will inform you if there is any change to this timetable.
Yours sincerely
ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interim statement of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) finishes with the comment that there will be a delay of about two months before the response can be tabled. It is most unusual that a Minister does not present a report personally; that the Minister on duty does it when it is a Government response to a major report made by a committee of this Parliament, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that is quite unusual about this is the delay. We are talking about a report that was tabled in the Senate on 2 December 1991, which happens to be three months ago. The convention of the Parliament is that the government of the day responds to major reports within three months. Yet today we are given something that is called an interim report, and it is not a report in any sense at all; it is just advice that perhaps in two months time we will get a response. That is five months after a major report has been tabled in the Parliament.

The report is very important because it relates to the place of the Defence Force Reserves in Australia. We all know that the Government is in great difficulty with the subject of defence as a result of its consistent cost-cutting exercises. With the very great rundown in the number of uniformed personnel in the three Services, the place of reserves to flesh out the Australian Defence Force has become even more critical. That is why it is important that the Government take notice of the report and make a response to the Parliament and account for its stewardship.

Clearly, what the Government is on about is moving to extend the time as long as it can and hope that the Committee's report will be buried. As the deputy chairman of the Committee that presented this report, I was more than interested to see how the report would be received in the Defence community. The response from Canberra was very interesting. If I may use a word that infuriates the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and refer to those uniformed members of the Defence Force who love to live in air-conditioned offices, as careerists, as opposed to the warriors in the Defence Force—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have an un-air-conditioned office, Senator?

—But I do not pretend to be a soldier all the time, and it has been a very long time since the people I am talking about have slept on the ground. I think I have spent more time sleeping on the ground with Army units in recent years than some of the people I am referring to. When the report came out, the denizens of Russell were extremely disturbed by it because it showed up all the deficiencies they had been covering up so carefully for so many years—all the shortcomings in the capability of the current Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: While our report was on the Reserves, it also inevitably involved some of the readiness and the capability of the permanent forces. There is no way we can dissect one part of the defence forces from the other. Our report showed up all the things the Government had been hiding with its talk about readiness and all the rest of it. Shortcomings were shown up in the Gulf war, when we found we had no forces at all that we could dispatch. It was only after the expenditure of about $100m that we got two ships we could send to the Gulf for a patrolling task. We had no unit in the Army we could dispatch onto the battlefield for conventional land warfare. We had nothing in the Air Force because we lack any electronic warfare capability to operate in a hostile situation.

The reaction from the senior officers who have been responsible for this situation has been to maintain silence. I am advised that when the Government's response to the Committee's report comes down, we will be attacked for writing a report which claims, in essence, that the corrective measures we have proposed of increasing readiness for the defence forces are quite unreal. That is rather ironic, given the way the interdepartmental committee responded to Mr Alan Wrigley's report of about 18 months ago. The Government attacked the Wrigley report and said that the readiness standards were far too long to be practical in any way at all. The word is now that it is going to attack our report on the basis that our readiness standards are too short to be attainable.

The fact of the matter is that at present we have readiness standards for the Australian Defence Force Reserves of 90 days, 180 days and 360 days. We devote quite a bit of our report to explaining how impractical those levels of readiness are. If we have a unit on 360 days readiness before it can go on active service, we might just as well recruit off the street, as we did in the Vietnam era. A soldier can certainly be trained in 360 days, and there is no point meeting the expense and all the other overheads involved in keeping them on the Reserve.

The Committee was very conscious of the high cost of readiness. In no sense at all are we saying that the whole of the Defence Force has to be ready to go in 30 days or 60 days or anything like that. Such a move would be quite nonsensical. There is a very high cost involved in maintaining high standards of readiness, but at the same time we have to recognise that it is a very different world we live in in 1992 from what we lived in 1932 or 1922, when long lead times and long training periods were quite possible. The facts of life are now that we need a Defence Force with a high degree of capability that is seen by other people and we need to have some of those parts of the Defence Force at a reasonably high standard of readiness. We also have to be able to bring the rest of the Defence Force up in a reasonable time.

Apart from the careerists at Russell Hill to whom I have referred, the rest of the uniformed services have been extremely enthusiastic and laudatory of the contents of the report. I have had many letters from all over Australia congratulating the Committee on bringing down a report of this nature. A difficulty we had in writing the report was that it was tightly written to a set of requirements laid down by the Minister. The No.1 requirement on the list of requirements we were given was that we had to write about the readiness for the reservists in relation to DOA87. That, of course, as everyone knows, is now hopelessly outdated. We are in the post-Cold War era and that document is utterly irrelevant to the needs of Australia. We did show that in the light of the standards set by the Government, as a consequence of DOA87, the Government had failed miserably to attain even those minimal standards that were defined in DOA87.

That is not surprising, because the history of Labor governments in Australia is one of total neglect of defence. History is a subject that might as well be written in Urdu or Sanskrit for the Labor Party. I do not think anyone in the Labor Party has any idea of history whatsoever. People such as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should be barred by statute from ever speaking in public on matters of historical significance. The attack on Britain earlier this week relating to the defence of Australia in 1942 was a scandalous travesty, a misstatement of historical facts. The charge that Britain did nothing to defend Malaya has been dealt with by notable historians in the Australian press, and I do not wish to debate that here.

One of the things Mr Keating was bleating about was the fact that there was opposition to bringing back the AIF divisions that were overseas. The 6th, the 7th and the 9th divisions were overseas at the time. The Labor Government made a big thing about the fact that they did not come back overnight.
The fact of the matter is that under Labor Prime Minister Curtin in 1942, the country was facing its gravest danger, its gravest hours; the Labor Government came in in 1941.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the report of the Committee?

—If Senator Collins has the patience to listen, and if he acquires the necessary intelligence and diligence, he will see the relevance. Prime Minister Curtin failed to take the obvious step of marshalling Australian resources. In the period from 1939 to 1945 over one million Australians were in the Army alone, and that from a population of only seven million at the time—quite an astonishing performance. Because the Labor Party was committed to its ancient pacifist philosophies, despite the fact that we were in the gravest danger ever, it would not introduce conscription; it would not commit Australian forces to attack the enemy. We had something like half a million people in the Army in uniform at the time. Poor old Curtin was bleating to the Americans and the British to send troops to die for Australia, yet we were not prepared to use our own resources.

PARA.TAB: Again, this was another failing in Mr Keating's understanding of history. However, I do not wish to give the Labor Party a lesson in history at this time because the day is passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is a fairly comprehensive review of history.

—But we see an extension of that; I am glad that Senator Collins reminded me. The relevance of that to this report is that we now have a three-tiered army instead of a two-tiered army as we had under Curtin. Under Curtin, we had the AIF and the militia. There was a gap between those two of enormous and debilitating consequence.

PARA.TAB: Under this Government, we have a regular army, which is now quite minuscule because it was reduced to only four battalions after the force structure review, and we have an army reserve which is now absolutely reduced to impotence because of a lack of resources from this Government. We now have the third team coming in—the Ready Reserve—which is neither fish nor fowl. So, in a sense, the Government has become even worse than it was in 1942-45.

While we are on the subject of reserves, I put to the Minister that he ought to consider the commitment of a reserve unit to Cambodia. Again, this is another reason for him to take some time to read this excellent report that was presented to the Parliament over three months ago.

We have been reduced to the tragic circumstance where we have only four Regular Army battalions. This is quite extraordinary for a country of 17 million. But putting all of that aside, two of those battalions are in the operational deployment force in Townsville with 3 Brigade. It is very unlikely that the Government will commit one of those two battalions to service in Cambodia. It will probably send a battalion out of 1 Brigade at Holsworthy since it got rid of 6 Brigade as part of the Ready Reserve scheme.

I suspect that the commitment to Cambodia will be far longer than the Government recognises at present. While I would hope that it is a short and, above all, a safe deployment of Australian forces, the possibility has to be faced at this stage that this could run into 12, 18, 24 months or even longer. I have very little faith in some of the factions that are involved in the negotiations in Cambodia reaching an amicable agreement and holding it in the longer term.

If we are in Cambodia for a period in excess of 12 months the Government will be bound to exercise some degree of rotation of the ground forces that are deployed there. If it follows the same practice it used in the Gulf with the ships, it will probably nominate a six-month period. In that case, there is an opportunity for a reserve unit to go to Cambodia and replace one of the two regular battalions that could go up there.

The beauty of the Cambodian deployment is that it allows time to call for volunteers from the Reserves and to train them beforehand. We could send a battalion like 49 RQR up there. To do something like that would have enormous benefits with respect to morale in the Army Reserve which, under both Liberal and Labor governments, has never been committed since the end of the Second World War. There is really no point in having an army reserve force if it is never used.

In closing, the Government does assign the lowest priority to defence. That is one of the reasons why it has been so tardy in responding to this report; it just does not want it to be an issue to be debated in Australia. It is interesting that in the Mein Kampf statement of Fuhrer Keating earlier in the session where he announced his forward estimates for Defence, apparently $300m is going to be cut out of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I very rarely raise concern about the language people use—I think people are overly sensitive. However, given that the word `McCarthyist' has been ruled as unparliamentary, I do not think that somebody can call a member of Parliament the `Fuhrer' and not have to withdraw it. I call on Senator MacGibbon to withdraw.

—I gladly withdraw that, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is just that, as a student of history, the title of One Nation brought my mind back to the slogan `Ein Volk, Ein Reich, Ein Fuhrer'. That was the mental connotation. I apologise for the sensitivities of Senator McMullan on this point. He is quite right in demanding my withdrawal of it.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, there is apparently a $300m reduction in the budgeting that appears in the One Nation statement and the Minister has been quite unable to explain that. The accompanying qualification to the force structure review statement that was tabled in March last year was that there had to be zero real growth to maintain the capital equipment program. A reduction in the agreed zero regrowth program will mean that the capital equipment program cannot be funded.

In essence, the Committee report that the Government is so loath to recognise demonstrates the consequences of the very low funding that this Government has given to defence. It particularly demonstrates how the Army Reserve has been reduced to impotence by never having been funded at an adequate level.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on change of status on grounds of spouse-de facto relationships. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS ON CHANGE OF STATUS—MARRIAGE AND DE FACTO RELATIONSHIPS
Recommendation 1.

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs review its provision of statistical data in its annual reports with a view to providing more detailed and more comprehensive statistical data in future annual reports, and
Recommendation 2.
Statistical data provided in annual reports be provided in a standard format from year to year.
Response:

Accepted. The 1989/90 Annual Report did not provide the appropriate base level data. This matter has been addressed in the 1990/91 Annual Report and the Department's Program Performance Statement 1991/92 for Parliament now in preparation. Relevant systems are currently the subject of review by the Department, with a view to improving support to decision makers, and enhancing statistical reports. More detailed statistical reporting is expected to be available in 1992/93.
Recommendation 3.

Tho Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs include in its training program for those officers who determine applications on spouse/de facto grounds information on different cultural values and practices.
Response:

Accepted. The Department is currently developing a comprehensive national training program for all residence decision makers. The course will be offered to over 200 residence decision makers within the current financial year and will focus on lawful decision making, the proper exercise of discretionary powers, and issues of cross cultural sensitisation.
Recommendation 4.

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs revise its Procedures Advice Manual (PAM) to ensure that officers are aware that different cultural factors impinge on marriage relationships and that such factors should be considered in the assessment of the "genuine and continuing" marriage.
Response:

The current guidelines for the assessment of the genuine and continuing nature of a marriage or de facto relationship already provide that decision makers should have regard to all the circumstances of a relationship and in particular the range of factors listed in the guidelines. Further, it is made clear to Departmental officers that the factors detailed in the guidelines are not exhaustive, but indicia as to the genuine and continuing nature of the relationship to be taken into account in a full assessment of the circumstances of a relationship. While the guidelines do not specifically mention cultural factors, the focus of the assessment is on the genuineness of the relationship, rather than whether the relationship conforms to a particular stereotype. These guidelines are consistent with guidelines used by other portfolios, such as the Department of Social Security, and as such conform to the Commonwealth position on such matters.

Given the commitment to training in cross cultural sensitisation outlined in the response to Recommendation 3 above, I believe that the current policy provisions are sufficiently flexible to accommodate a range of cultural factors impinging on marriage relationships.
Recommendation 5.

The statement in the PAM concerning de facto relationships be clarified so that decision makers and immigration advisers are made aware of what de facto relationships are not in accordance with Australian social values.
Response:

Accepted. The de facto relationships not in accordance with Australian social values and not mentioned in the De Facto Marriage Relationships PAM subject are relationships between people within prohibited relationships. Item 4.9.1 of the PAM subject on Marriage and Divorce with minor modifications will be included in the PAM subject on De Facto Marriage Relationships as follows:
In Australia, relationships between parties who are within a certain range of relationships with each other are void under Australian law. These relationships:
are between a person and an ancestor or descendent of the person (i.e., parent and child or grandparent and grandchild)
are between a brother and a sister (whether full blood or half blood)
These relationships include adoptive relationships.
Recommendation 6.

Legal advice be sought on the advice given in the Procedures Advice Manual, namely that it is permissible to exclude under age legally married applicants until both spouses are over the marriageable age.
Response:
Accepted. Where only one partner is domiciled in Australia both the applicant and his/her spouse must be over the marriageable age.
Where both the applicant and his/her spouse are domiciled overseas and the marriage is recognised in that country then the marriage will be recognised in Australia except
while either party is under 16 years of age (s.88D(3) of the Marriage Act 1961 as amended by S15 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 applies).
The PAM subject on Marriage and Divorce has been amended to reflect these changes in legislation.
Recommendation 7.

In the event that the advice contained in the Procedures Advice Manual is in fact incorrect, the definition of spouse in the Regulations be amended to include the requirement that a spouse is a person of Australian marriageable age.
Response:

Amendment to the Regulations is not necessary. The recent amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 simultaneously amended the Marriage Act 1961. As the Migration Act 1958 (sl2) recognises Part VA of the Marriage Act, any amendments to that part of the Marriage Act automatically apply to the Migration Act.
Recommendation 8.

The regulations and PAM be amended to allow administrative flexibility in individual cases with respect to the degree of separation required for de facto, or married partners separated but not divorced, before the relationship is taken to be not continuing.
Response:

Accepted in principle. It is not necessary to amend the regulations to allow administrative flexibility in determining the degree of separation necessary before a relationship ceases to be continuing. Given that the guidelines for the assessment of the "genuine and continuing" criterion are provided for in instructional material, guidelines for determining the degree of separation can be similarly provided for.
For instance, items 8.3.1 to 8.3.3 of the PAM subject on Marriage and Divorce can be adapted and included in the PAM subject on De Facto Marriage Relationships as follows:

A separation occurs where either of the parties to a de facto marriage forms the intention that the relationship is at an end and acts on that intention in a way which is inconsistent with the continuation of the relationship.
Separation usually occurs by one of the parties moving from common residence, although physical separation for work or other reasons does not necessarily mean that the parties have separated.

It is also possible for the parties to the de facto marriage to be separated while living at the same address. They would need to show that although they continued to live at the same address they had organised their lives quite separately and were not providing any support or domestic assistance to each other.
Recommendation 9.
The visa and permit conditions included in regulations 17(1) and 28(1) be reworded so as to state the change in circumstances which would justify cancellation; and
Recommendation 10.
Such circumstances to be limited to changes in the nature of the marriage or de facto relationship, such that the relationship is no longer genuine and continuing; and
Recommendation 11.

These circumstances not to include the death of a spouse or the breakdown in a relationship due to domestic violence or such other change which would not disqualify the spouse from obtaining permanent residence as a spouse; and
Recommendation 13.
Visa and permit holders to have explicit written notice of the full terms of conditions attaching to their visa or permit and of the consequences which result from breach of the conditions.
Response:
Accepted in principle. I agree there is a need for applicants to be aware of what constitutes a "material change in circumstances".

However, it is my view (supported by legal advice from my Department) that to prescribe these in the regulations is not the most appropriate course of action. The current wording of regulations 17(1)(o) and 28(1)(m) allows each to be used as conditions for any entry permit or visa. To amend these paragraphs to include spouse specific material would confine their use to the Spouse category.

Delegated officers are aware of what constitutes "material change" through the Department's instructional material. The applicant will be advised of the nature of the material change in initial information/advice letters sent to him/her after application. The letter(s) will include detailed information on all conditions attached to the entry permit (or visa as appropriate) and advice to the applicant of the consequences of breaching those conditions.

A "material change" is a change that goes to the basis of the application. The basis of an application on marriage or de facto grounds is the relationship. A "material change" in this is, therefore, a change in the genuine and continuing nature of the marriage or de facto marriage.

The condition that there be "no material change in circumstance" in regard to the relationship, is a mandatory condition. Breach of such a condition does not automatically lead to cancellation of the visa or entry permit—it is simply a ground for cancellation. Instructional material to delegated officers (PC 1771) reinforces this point, advising that officers have consideration for prescribed circumstances in which permanent residency may still be available before making any decision on cancellation.

The prescribed circumstances are where the applicant's Australian spouse dies, where the relationship breaks down due to domestic violence or where the relationship breaks down and there are access to children or maintenance of children considerations. These prescribed circumstances are part of phase two of the Spouse arrangements and regulatory changes to implement them will be made soon.
Recommendation 12.

The requirements of natural justice to be observed before cancelling the spouse's visa or permit, the spouse to be given notice of the Minister's intention to cancel the visa or permit and time within which to respond to the allegations.
Response:

Accepted in principle. Delegated officers are bound to have regard to the principles of natural justice. Although the visa and temporary entry permit cancellation powers are couched in terms of my "absolute discretion", this does not mean that the principles of natural justice are excluded.

The condition that there be "no material change in circumstance" in regard to the relationship, is a mandatory condition. Breach of such a condition does not automatically lead to cancellation of the visa or entry permit—it is simply a ground for cancellation. Instructional material to delegated officers (PC 1771) reinforces this point, advising that officers have consideration for prescribed circumstances in which permanent residence may still be granted before making any decision on cancellation.

All applicants, except for those who did not hold a valid temporary entry permit when they applied (that is, they were illegal), will have an automatic right of review where their application has been rejected. Cancellation of an EETEP is not a reviewable decision, but the cancellation may require the outstanding application to be rejected and that decision is reviewable.

Where information is received that casts any doubt on the genuineness of the relationship, or where an interview causes the delegated officer to doubt the genuineness of the relationship, the applicant is given the chance and time to respond.
Recommendation 14.
Extensions of the extended eligibility spouse entry permit be given sparingly and only to ensure that the applicant has lawful immigration status during processing.
Response:
Accepted. It was never my intention to use the Further Extended Eligibility Temporary Entry Permit (FEETEP) as a means of imposing the period of conditional residence beyond two years.

The FEETEP was created as a mechanism to keep the applicant legal beyond the two year period where processing was taking longer than expected or where there were proceedings outside the control of the Department (ie. Family Court) that would impact upon the result of the application. This intention is reflected in current instructional material to delegated officers.
Recommendation 15.
The test for a "genuine marriage", to be set out in the PAM, be as follows:

whether at the time at which the matter has to be decided it can be said that the parties have a mutual commitment to a shared life as husband and wife and that they have a genuine intention for their relationship to be ongoing.
Response:

It is not the objective of the "genuine and continuing" criterion in Regulations 126 and 135 to test a genuine marriage. The genuineness of a marriage is established by its legal validity, its conformity to the provisions of the Marriage Act 1961. The objective of the "genuine and continuing" criterion in Regulations 126 and 135 is to assess the quality of the relationship, regardless of whether it is a de jure or a de facto relationship. The current guidelines for the assessment of the genuine and continuing nature of a marriage or de facto relationship provide an adequate test for the genuine and continuing nature of the relationship under consideration.
Recommendation 16.
Clear guidelines on the appropriate assessment dates, including the dates applicable for applications lodged before 15 April 1991, be written into the Procedures Advice Manual.
Response:

Accepted. The procedural advice accompanying the new legislation clearly indicates the decision points for applications lodged after 15 April 1991. This information will be incorporated into the Procedures Advice Manual when next updated. The current Procedures Advice Manual gives guidelines for assessment points for those applications lodged before 15 April 1991.
Recommendation 17.
The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs collect data on the incidence of sham marriage for immigration purposes and make that data available in its Annual Report.
Response:
Refer to the response to Recommendations 21, 22 and 23.
Recommendation 18.

The Procedures Advice Manual include information on particular common marriage customs, with the proviso that staff are advised not to assume that everyone of a particular cultural background adheres to those customs and that all cases are to be assessed on an individual basis; and
Recommendation 19.
Departmental officers are made aware of the community assessment of when the couple are married for the purpose of assessing the genuineness or otherwise of a traditional marriage.
Response:

Accepted in principle. The current guidelines for the assessment of the genuine and continuing nature of the marriage or de facto relationship provide that decision makers should consider the full circumstances of the relationship, having regard in particular to the factors highlighted in the guidelines. Such an approach is aimed at testing the genuineness of the relationship, rather than whether the relationship conforms to a particular cultural stereotype. Also, see the response to Recommendation 4 above.

It should also be noted that the onus is on the applicant to establish that at the time of application he/she was the spouse of the nominating Australian citizen or permanent resident. Regulation 2 defines a spouse as a person who has entered into a marriage recognised as valid for the purposes of the Act, where the marriage has not been ended by divorce or the death of one of the parties and the parties are not living separately and apart on a permanent basis or a de facto spouse. The issue is, therefore, when the spousal relationship commences (a question of fact to be established by the applicant) and will thus be settled within the applicants cultural expectations.
Recommendation 20.
The Department move to tape all parallel interviews and that those tapes be made available to appropriate parties.
Response:
While there are cogent arguments for and against this recommendation, the resource implications mitigate against such an arrangement.
Recommendation 21.

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs closely monitor the de facto marriage class and collect statistics on the approval and rejection rate of applications for this class; and
Recommendation 22.
Statistical evidence on the incidence of sham marriage claims for both legal spouse and de facto spouse be collected; and
Recommendation 23.
Such statistical data be included in the Department's Annual Report.
Response:

Accepted in part. Statistics on approval and rejection rates for applicants on marriage or de facto relationship grounds are collected. However not all refusals are on the basis of the relationship being contrived for the purpose of gaining permanent residence. Even if an application is rejected on the basis that the relationship is not genuine and continuing, this rejection will not necessarily prove that the relationship was contrived. Statistics are also maintained on investigations which are conducted into contrived relationships, but it is not always cost effective to investigate all such relationships which come to notice. Relevant statistics are included in the Annual Report.
Recommendation 24.
In clear cases when such bogus or sham marriages are detected the non-Australian partner, who has used the marriage to gain entry to or stay in Australia, be removed from Australia.
Response:
Accepted in principle.
Recommendation 25.

If the present law enshrined in Section 20(3) concerning the obtaining of residence by deception does not allow the easy deportation of those who have duped their Australian partner in this way, then that provision be amended to enable such a result.
Response:

Accepted in principle. However, deportation is an inherently complex matter. By virtue of the operation of s.14(2) and s.20 of the Migration Act 1958, a person may be an illegal entrant having made (or caused to be made) a statement which is false or misleading in a material particular. Applicants for permanent residence on spouse grounds who are party to bogus or sham marriages, who have made (or caused to be made) statements which are false and misleading in respect of the genuine and continuing nature of the marriage will be illegal entrants by virtue of ss.14(2) and 20 and be liable for deportation. This sanction is sufficient and two test cases in the Federal Court in 1991 upheld my Department's use of this legislation to remove from Australia spouses involved in contrived marriages.
Recommendation 26.
Penalties relating to fraudulent spouse/de facto applicants should also extend to fraudulent interdependency relationships.
Response:
Accepted.
Recommendation 27.

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs undertake a routine audit of former spouse applicants who have subsequently applied for citizenship in order to gather statistical data on marriage and detect those cases where there may be a report of sham marriage or marriage fraud.
Response:

I question the value of such an audit for a variety of reasons but mainly because the fact that a relationship no longer exists if or when a permanent resident applies for citizenship is no indication that the relationship on which their grant of permanent residence was based was not genuine. Such statistical data would, therefore, be unreliable and of no obvious benefit to the residence sub program.
Recommendation 28.

A provision be incorporated into the Regulations to serve the same purpose as Section 204(a)(2a) of the United States Immigration Marriage Fraud Act, that is that the spouse applicant is not permitted to sponsor another spouse for a specified period unless it can be established by clear and convincing evidence that the prior marriage was not entered into for the purpose of evading any provision of the immigration laws.
Response:

Accepted in principle. However, in my view it is not necessary to provide for penalties of this type, given the structure of the new spouse arrangements. The basic ground on which an application on the basis of a marriage or de facto relationship is approved is that the relationship in question is genuine and continuing.

The assessment of the genuine and continuing nature of the relationship has regard to the full circumstances of the relationship. When an Australian citizen or permanent resident completes the form 887 nomination of a temporary resident on this ground, he/she is required to provide details of any previous nominations for grant of permanent residence. Clearly a nominator with a history of multiple nominations will raise questions in the mind of a decision maker as to the genuineness of the relationship. The information this question gathers serves the same purpose, without the 5 year prohibition, as the US provision.

The two year conditional residence period is a further significant disincentive to "serial" spouse nominators. I am also in the process of introducing a series of firm penalties for fraud pertaining to this category of application.
Recommendation 29.

There be a widespread and effective publicity campaign highlighting the increased surveillance and detection techniques, the increased penalties for fraud and the very real penalties of deportation and restrictions on re-entry.
Response:

Ministerial press release 4/91 announcing the new spouse arrangements covered the range of penalties to be imposed on individuals involved in contriving marriages for the purpose of gaining permanent residence in Australia. The content of this press release attracted wide attention in the electronic and print media.
Recommendation 30.

Where a marriage between an Australian and a non-Australian citizen has broken down and there has been a child of that marriage, that consideration be given to the rights and interests of the child at the time of the application for residence and prior to any deportation action by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; and
Recommendation 31.

Where legal proceedings, including proceedings relating to divorce, settlement or custody, are under way, no action be taken by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs prior to the finalisation of such proceedings, providing there is not unreasonable delays in the pursuit of proceedings by the non-Australian party.
Response:
Accepted. The interests of the child(ren) are certainly an issue of consideration and are catered for in the second phase of the Spouse arrangements.
As I announced in January of this year, the second phase will include provision for applicants to obtain permanent residence where:
the relationship has broken down and there are any children in the custody of the applicant who are subject to access for, or maintenance obligations on, the Australian spouse.

Therefore, where divorce, settlement or custody proceedings are under way and will establish which parent has day-to-day custody of the children, no decision on the case will be made until those proceedings are resolved.

Second phase instructional information to delegated officers includes advice that applications should not be finalised until custody proceedings (or proceedings affecting custody) are completed and the results of those proceedings taken into account. This information will include advice on processing where the applicant is unreasonably delaying such proceedings.

Consideration will be given to amending the Regulations to provide for applicants to obtain permanent residence where the relationship has broken down and there are any children in the custody of the Australian citizen or permanent resident spouse in respect of whom the applicant has access rights. In the meantime, any such cases which arise may be dealt with under s115 and s137 of the Migration Act 1958. Of course, where custody of children is not an issue in divorce or settlement proceedings, delegated officers may continue to process or make a decision on a case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on change of status on grounds of marriage and de facto relationships dealt with a complex and certainly emotional subject. It involved myriad different sham marriage deals; the cultural differences in marriages of different cultures; what is and what is not a true de facto relationship; and, through all that, the lack of decent departmental statistics on the problems that the Committee reviewed. In other words, it was not a simple inquiry.

PARA.TAB: It became a complex report. Today we have received the Government's response to that report, which was presented on 17 May 1991. Therefore, some time has elapsed between the report being tabled and the Government's response today.

If I were asked the best way to describe the Government's response in a sentence, I would say that it had touches of realism and a large dose of half-heartedness. The Government has agreed to act on the recommendation that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs must provide far better statistical data. This is not before time, for there seems little point in attempting to run a successful immigration program without the data to indicate what is and is not a problem. If a problem is to be analysed accurately so that its remedies can be considered, there needs to be a good statistical database upon which to make judgments. That is a good foundation for looking at the problem, reviewing it, making an assessment and proposing alternatives. For example, we do not know how many illegals we have.

The Government has also agreed to establish training programs for officers in the marriage requirements of other cultures. We welcome that. We had a number of examples where officers in many different locations simply did not appreciate the different cultural attitudes to marriage and therefore were making judgments and decisions based on a lack of knowledge of those cultural differences. It is imperative that arranged marriages of many Asian cultures are not taken for sham marriages. Clearly, the basis of any good immigration program is fairness.

There are concerns that the Department is not willing to take action on the specific area of what is and what is not a de facto relationship, and inquire into whether a marriage is considered genuine—it has written these aspects off—whereas the Committee considered they were a vital component of the report. In other words, the Government is making perhaps more band-aid measures and appears unwilling to deal with some of the hard issues of the many couples who use the guise of a de facto relationship to gain the status of marriage and, as a result of that, entry and permanent citizenship in Australia.

We should not allow people to be able to jump the queue, in my view illegally. We should ensure that people overseas who have applied through the appropriate and right channels and undertaken the appropriate and right procedures as laid down by this Parliament, are given fair and equal treatment in relation to the regulations under the Migration Act, so that they are not put at a disadvantage and so that other people do not jump the queue by using a range of mechanisms, one of which is the subject we are talking about today.

The report contains 31 recommendations to which the Government has supplied us with a response. In the short time that the report has been available, it has been nigh on impossible to digest the Government's response in detail to those 31 recommendations. The way it is framed, with many of the Committee's recommendations given half answers or half refusals—that is, `accepted in principle, but', and then about four paragraphs of response to the `but'—it is going to be a matter of some time to digest and assess the Government's response to the recommendations. It will need greater assessment and, therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pig industry has become very important in most of Australia and, in fact, it is one of the rural industries that operates in every State. When we think of the traditional method of pig keeping of years ago and the sorts of animals they were, we can only give great credit to the industry for the magnificent progress it has made. The animal now is an entirely different shape and constituency than it used to be. The keeping of them is so different. The product, as I have said, is now totally different from what it used to be 30 or 40 years ago. This has been done by good research. The high density pig growing that is done now in various places is the result of treating the animals differently now.

PARA.TAB: The report covers a wide range of things that have happened over the years and the sort of research that is currently being done. It also covers the issue of dumping. I am pleased to say it has now been determined that for this particular year under review, the 1991 year, it was not serious because the amount of imports was very low.

This report takes quite a lot of trouble to go over the question of quarantine, particularly transmittable gastroenteritis and the importation of uncooked pig meat from Canada. The Government has to make up its mind on these subjects very soon. We hear officers of the quarantine service talking about `acceptable levels of risk'. They are not talking about an acceptable level of risk as far as the Government and the exporter are concerned, but they certainly are about the industry in Australia. If the Government determines that there is an acceptable level of risk, there can be no alternative to the fact that it must stand the risk. It is not reasonable that the Government should take actions contrary to what has been requested by the industry without being responsible. Whether the pig producers are in Tasmania, Queensland or wherever, this has to be the case.
I am pleased to see that page 12 of the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: To this end, Council submitted that it was the industry-wide view that the Government should—
a) accept responsibility for compensation should an outbreak of TGE occur.
b) establish a monitoring procedure whereby import consignments would be sampled. . .
c) facilitate the training of veterinary staff. . .
d) encourage increased research into the epidemiology of the disease. . .
e) advise on plans that would be implemented to control/eradicate the disease should it be introduced.
These are all very reasonable things and there are others as well.

PARA.TAB: The industry has come such a long way. Its marketing has improved tremendously. Its feeding and breeding are exceptionally good. The industry is an absolute model for other meat industries to follow. No other industry has made the amount of progress that the pig industry has in the production of its stock. It deserves great credit for it and it certainly needs to keep before the Government its position as to the importation of uncooked pig meats and the general development of the industry further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak to this Australian Pig Industry Policy Council Annual Report. In doing so, I want to say that I believe that there are two major issues of outstanding significance to the Australian pig industry at the moment. Both are related to the importation of quantities of Canadian pig meat which I notice is dealt with early in the report.

PARA.TAB: Australian pork producers are vitally concerned that the importation of subsidised Canadian pig meat is undercutting prices and introducing disease into our market. It is producing a situation which gravely threatens to undermine the financial viability of the industry. Earlier today colleagues would have heard Senator O'Chee point out that, in the last six months alone, $5.8m worth of Canadian pork has flooded into Australia. In light of this, it is fascinating to read on page 13 that the Council resolved that:

SPEECH.PARA: no action be taken at this time in respect of formally submitting a countervailing application because of the lack of significant imports and the lack of evidence of material injury during 1990-91.
However, it was sad to read that maybe no action will ever be taken when further on it reports:

While accepting the Governments view that the best recourse for the Australian pig industry was to seek protection from unfair trading practices via the existing Anti-Dumping and Countervailing legislation, Council considered at the time that the legislation and the interpretation thereof by the Australian Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority combined to create a situation, which not only resulted in protracted and very costly cases, but in appearing to favour the exporting country over the importing country, indicated that the chances of a successful application were very remote.

Currently the quality of Australian pork is the highest in the world. We have no disease in it and we want to keep it that way. Only three countries have pork of comparable quality to Australia's—Denmark, New Zealand and Northern Ireland—and Australia is the clear leader. If we continue to import Canadian pig meat, it will be open slather on the Australian market. As far as this Government is concerned, there will be no health inspection except for document checks. It is the same as the strawberry industry. I think we all remember when Californian strawberries were imported, and they turned out to be riddled with disease.

PARA.TAB: When the Government had these concerns raised by pork producers right across the country, all that the Government said was that a limitation would be put on imports. A limitation of 17,000 tonnes was mentioned, but as far as many in the industry are concerned that figure was plucked from the air. That figure would represent imports of select cuts, but what it would really represent is a loss to Australian producers of much more than 17,000 tonnes of pig meat. Traditionally, a processor would have to buy a whole pig in order to obtain select cuts.

Australia has a healthy and viable pig industry which should not be jeopardised by this sort of threat. Indeed, it is already bad enough on the land just trying to make ends meet in the current economic climate. Producers do not need to have their livelihoods threatened with the possibility of increased demand from inferior quality and disease ridden products from overseas. Indeed, Australia exports pork in limited quantities to New Zealand, Japan, the Pacific nations and the United States. However, the major problem the industry faces is that most other overseas pig-producing industries receive the benefit of government subsidies.

Senator O'Chee raised this issue during the matters of public interest discussion earlier. He drew the Senate's attention to the alarming fact that Qantas serves on its menu, printed for every overseas tourist to read, Canadian bacon. I want to know what is wrong with Australian bacon. It is bad enough that Qantas chooses to use it, but it is worse that it promotes it. Qantas is our national carrier and should be supporting our national industries.

As I have said, many other pork-producing nations subsidise their industries. We have seen the situation where the Danes, for example, were landing legs of pork in Singapore for a cheaper price than we could produce pigs here. Even though the United States has proven the Canadian product to be subsidised, the Australian Government chooses to ignore this. Senator Archer told us a little about diseases that pig meat could suffer. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account is a very important document which details the various mining royalty equivalents that are paid into the account each year. I note that in the financial year under consideration it is in the order of $33m. The report addresses the manner in which disbursements are made from that trust account. Some 40 per cent of the annual allocation is made available to the land councils for their administrative purposes, and then there are various other distributions.

PARA.TAB: I address two points. I note that for the first time for a number of years no grants have been made under section 64(7) which, in effect, are the Minister's discretionary grants for additional administrative costs of the land councils. It is pleasing to note that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has not under this report made those additional grants which for many years his predecessor, the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, made from this account direct to the land councils. Under Minister Hand those disbursements were many, many millions of dollars which went in administrative services and not in direct assistance or grants to Aboriginal organisations or for the benefit of Aboriginal people. The disbursements for administration are still very high—$14m in this financial year.

Secondly, an issue about the report that concerns me relates to applications for grant approvals, particularly as they relate to the purchase of pastoral properties. In various tables attached to the report I note significant numbers of applications. The number of applications and from where received are fully detailed on page 8. Only a very small number subsequently eventuated into approved applications for grant funding. They are detailed on page 9. The most significant area that is detailed is that $17m of a total grant funding approval of $20m is for the purchase of pastoral properties.

The report clearly states that in this financial year settlement took place in respect of only one of the four stations acquired, set out on page 10. Fitzroy Station was financed for $2.6m, Muckaty Station for $730,000, Elsey Station for $4.8m and Mistake Creek Station for just over $5m, yet the only settlement was with regard to the $730,000 grant approval for Muckaty. Therefore, some $12m has been transferred into the next financial year for the purchase of the other three Aboriginal pastoral properties.

Such significant grants from this trust account need to be read alongside the other moneys that are made available through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission for the purchase of pastoral properties elsewhere. The land councils have access out of other trust accounts. I have no objection to Aboriginal people owning, running and operating pastoral properties. However, the long term operation and viability of a pastoral property depend on the continuing management plan.

Although this report acknowledges further action must be taken by the land councils in conjunction with ATSIC, I want to see that provision in the forward estimates of ATSIC; I shall be pursuing a number of questions when we get to the Estimates Committee. I want to know what provision the Government has made to ensure that these projects are viable and not just land purchases that cannot be adequately serviced and properly conducted on behalf of the Aboriginal owners.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not noticed any reports having yet been tabled for the Northern or Central Land Councils, and I hope that they will be forthcoming in the near future. The Tiwi Land Council is based on Melville and Bathurst Islands to the north of Darwin. It is an important land council and has attracted the commendation and praise of a number of senators for a number of years because of the competent manner in which it conducts its activities. This report goes a long way in setting out the success of the various business enterprises and community activities that are conducted on behalf of the Tiwi people on both Melville and Bathurst Islands. I commend the report to all senators as illustrating success stories on the manner of conducting Aboriginal businesses and community lifestyles.

PARA.TAB: Together with Senator Michael Baume in his shadow ministry capacity relating to heritage matters and Senator Jocelyn Newman with her shadow portfolio responsibilities relating to women, I visited Melville and Bathurst Islands during the last year. We were very pleased at the response of the people we met and the courtesies that were extended to us by members of the Tiwi Land Council in explaining their various activities. Obviously they have been very successful, whether in pearling, tourism, fishing, arts and crafts or in the provision of many services on behalf of the people of the Tiwi islands.

I wish to highlight some of the comments in the report relating to the mineral exploration projects by Renison Goldfields Consolidated to explore for heavy minerals along the northern coast of Bathurst and Melville Islands. The report draws our attention to those plans for mineral explorations and where they are proceeding. I am aware that since the end of the financial year under consideration in the report the Tiwi Land Council has endorsed and written up agreements with Renison which have been approved and endorsed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, Barry Coulter.

This is an important future long term initiative. When these projects are up and running successfully, there will be employment, investment opportunities and a considerable cash flow. Any major project development always seems to draw the immediate reaction of the radical environmental movements and similar people. This project is now engendering, as have so many other projects on Aboriginal land, controversy in the media. From reading this report and from the discussions I have had with executives of the Tiwi Land Council and the residents of both Melville Island and Bathurst Island, I do not believe it is of the major concern that has been purported and reported in the media.

I hope the Tiwi people will be encouraged to proceed with the sand mining project, naturally subject to all of the appropriate environmental impact statements and provisions that they must make. It will enhance the lifestyle; it will enhance investment; it will enhance the employment opportunities of the Tiwi people to ensure that those major resource projects are not hindered by policies of this Federal Government, as has been evident in so many other Aboriginal projects, such as Coronation Hill. I wish the Tiwi Islanders well in their continuing pursuits.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—On behalf of the President, I present the 1991 supplement to the Register of Senate Committee Reports. On 7 May 1991, the President tabled the Senate Register of Committee Reports 1970-1990. This register was published in order to improve access to the wealth of information contained in almost 400 committee reports. I now table the 1991 supplement to the register. It provides a timely update to the main register, with a similar chronological committees and subject matter breakdown for the 62 reports referred to in it.

I am also pleased to report that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is using the register as a model for a Commonwealth register from which selected entries will be published periodically in the Parliamentarian. All entries will be compiled into a Commonwealth databank of such reports, to which parliamentarians and researchers throughout the Commonwealth will have access through the Commonwealth Parliamentary Information and Reference Centre. This is an important international initiative. The Senate register is a key source document on which it will, in part, depend. I commend the supplement to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks relate to the very important report by the Australian Education Council Review Committee headed by Mr T.B. Finn entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training. At the outset, the Committee notes that there is an urgent need for change in the perception of education in this country. We need to recognise that at present our education system is not addressing the real issues in education today; that is, how to produce the multi-skilled, creative and adaptive work force that is necessary for Australia to progress towards the twenty-first century.

PARA.TAB: International comparisons show that it is vital in our future that we overcome our thinking of education and training as separate concepts in order to achieve this multi-skilling. For many years Germany has given technical education a higher status, particularly emphasising the service sector as opposed to the more traditional trades. This has contributed to the strength of the German economy and made its work force one of the most efficient and productive.

In order to achieve this objective of both a general and vocational education for young people in Australia, both schools in general and the TAFE colleges in particular will have to change the what, the how and the why of what they teach. Schools will have to become concerned with issues of broad future employment prospects and the provision of broad vocational education. TAFE colleges will have to recognise that vocational courses must be more concerned with generalised competencies than the traditional craft-based apprenticeship courses.

The report proposes an entirely different future for young people. It proposes that all young people should undergo sufficient post-compulsory education and training to complete year 12 or some equivalent post-secondary qualification and that at least half should go on to higher levels of education. The report has a very clear set of guidelines to achieve this target. All young people would be guaranteed a place in school or TAFE institutions after year 10 for two years of full time education or three years part time. Next, consideration is given to the essential studies required by all young people in preparation for employment. These key competencies include a range of skills, including not only the traditional disciplines but also cultural, interpersonal and problem solving skills.

Industry is crying out for a more efficient, skilled and knowledgeable work force that will maintain and enhance productivity in the workplace. Young people today are becoming more and more disillusioned with the education system. The relevance of Australia's education system and its ability to satisfy the requirements for the future of this country is addressed in this report and its findings should be very carefully considered by the Senate. Implementation of the report's recommendations will ensure that, whatever educational training is being undertaken, young people will develop these key competencies. Speed and urgency are needed for the implementation of these changes to our education system. It is through our education system that we produce an efficient multi-skilled work force that can lead Australia into the future with a more competitive economy.

Also addressed in this report is the issue of how to fund these changes to the education system. Unless the issue of funding is properly addressed, 100,000 students will continue to be turned away from TAFE colleges. This is yet another report which urgently recommends that the Government rethink the funding procedures for TAFE so that the sector can expand rapidly. The Committee gives the Government of this country a clear choice—educate or perish: ensure the proper education of our young people or let this country slip even further behind the rest of the world in it's people's quality and quantity of knowledge and skills provided.
I commend this report to the Senate, but I especially recommend that the Government begin to take some positive action in implementing the findings of this and other important educational reports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering yet another very valuable report produced by the Industry Commission—Export of Educational Services. The area has already been considered very carefully by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in its own inquiry into education exports. This examination played a very important part in achieving a large number of amendments to an extremely sloppy piece of legislation which the Government attempted to steamroll through the Parliament last year. It is not ideal, even in its current form, but it is, fortunately, vastly improved because of the result of Senate scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: The legislation and this Industry Commission report are a response by the Government to a rapidly growing export market. The number of international students coming to Australia has grown rapidly since 1986. That was the time when public institutions were first permitted to enrol foreign students and to charge fees. Student arrivals more than doubled between 1986 and 1989. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Government regulation of this industry since its beginning in 1986 has been characterised by sudden shifts in policy direction, the effects of which have been made more serious by the way in which decisions were reached and subsequently communicated to those directly affected, in Australia and overseas.

The result of these simplistic knee-jerk reactions by the Government to complex problems has been a significant loss to Australia of large parts of its export education industry as the number of students coming to Australia for English language intensive courses and other short courses fell significantly because of tightened procedures. For instance, there was a dramatic reduction in the number of students from China from 22,000 in 1989 to less than 1,200 in 1990. Under the priority entry requirements, about 5 per cent of applications from China have been rejected, but the rejection rate increased to 95 per cent during 1990.

PARA.TAB: Every effort must now be made to restore our education export industry. There has been an alarming number of closures of private colleges which have previously offered English and business courses for students from overseas. This is extremely damaging to our reputation as an exporter of educational services and is seriously affecting the number of bona fide students coming to Australia to study. Five English language colleges collapsed in Sydney last year, leaving overseas students who had paid their fees in advance without funds and without the means to finish their courses. Last year a private college in Canberra also closed down when staff and students were locked out as a result of the owners failing to pay the rent. Students had already paid their fees for their courses, but they had no prospect of completing the courses or obtaining any qualifications. In this instance, the University of Canberra, fortunately, was able to accommodate all the students without additional cost.

Clearly, the export industry is of cultural and economic importance to Australia. It is important to the international students and it is important to our educational institutions. For some institutions, overseas students have become a significant revenue source. Increased financial returns from education exports can advantage the domestic economy and it can improve the facilities and staff student ratios in institutions. Development of education as an export industry also brings less tangible benefits from the links established with people in geographical regions closest to Australia.

The report itemises the benefits of overseas students to Australia. As in the case of all exports, there are benefits to the balance of payments and, given the present economic situation in Australia, every effort needs to be made to increase exports and remove obstacles which discourage students from seeking educational services.

The Industry Commission notes that many benefits from education exports occur when students return home. The education export industry is valuable, it is important and it must stay. I commend this report to the Senate and I recommend vigilance by the Senate to prevent the uncertainty and embarrassment which result from the closure of colleges experiencing financial difficulties and inappropriate responses such as those attempted by this Labor Government in recent times.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the annual report for the Department of Defence for 1990-91. With the recent rapid changes in world affairs, Australia's regional security climate has never been better, notwithstanding that much movement is needed on confidence building, force reduction, economic cooperation, human rights and environment protection.

PARA.TAB: It is surely self-evident that these developments should have a profound effect on Australia's defence doctrine. Yet the impression gained from this report is that it is business as usual. One exception, which is in tune with our times, is Australia's contribution to the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Cambodia. I commend those now serving in the force, and others yet to join them, for their valuable contribution to regional security and human rights.

However, in most respects, the report looks embarrassingly out of date. We read that the Australian Defence Force promotes `strategic stability and security in our region'. Australian diplomacy surely plays a far more important role, yet the huge imbalance in resources—under which the foreign affairs budget is 5 per cent of the defence vote—is not even questioned. Our security depends much more on economic vitality than military strength, yet huge sums are being poured into increasingly irrelevant capital projects—$4.6 billion for new submarines and $4.3 billion for the Anzac frigates—when our national infrastructure remains run down and under-funded. A dollar invested in upgrading our rail network to fast freight train status would create far more jobs than investing the same dollar in submarine construction, thus strengthening another pillar of our national security—social cohesion.

Repairing the gaping holes in our coastal surveillance and interception system should be a far higher priority in defence activities. Yet the report states that, in 1991-92, our P-3C Orions will spend less than half the time spent on coastal surveillance in 1990-91.

The Democrats have repeatedly called for a total rethink of Australia's defence. I note from the Defence Industry & Aerospace Report of 31 January that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is predisposed to commission another defence White Paper. He should do so urgently, and with comprehensive public involvement.

I now want to raise a specific matter in the report, namely the proposed relocation of Newington armament depot from Sydney to Jervis Bay. The long awaited review of alternative sites to Jervis Bay mentioned in the report remains under wraps, despite Senator Richardson's earlier commitment to release it. I understand that the Minister has no intention of honouring that commitment. This cynicism is compounded by an outrageous piece of Navy disinformation aimed at winning local acceptance of the move. It is a colour map on which the Jervis Bay ammunitioning pipeline is depicted as an innocuous 15 kilometre journey between the proposed depot and the wharf—conveniently omitting the 200 kilometre section between Jervis Bay and the Kingswood armament depot in Penrith, over which 450 truckloads of high explosive missiles and torpedoes would be shipped each year over busy highways and through numerous towns, against the opposition of several local councils.

This issue has dragged on for far too long. It is about time that the Government put the issue to rest by abandoning the relocation and creating a marine and terrestrial national park. This would not only protect a marvellous natural area but would also save the taxpayer $200m, without any loss of defence readiness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In October last year, the Senate agreed to a package of fisheries legislation after a major review by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and many—80—amendments. The new legislation came in response to what can only be described as a disastrous record of Commonwealth fisheries management.

PARA.TAB: In response to the many misgivings expressed about the adequacy of the legislation to improve matters, the Minister agreed that the legislation be referred to the Committee again in a year; that is, in October of this year. By then, AFMA—that is, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority—would be up and running and we would be able to assess the legal framework about which there was much controversy. We would also have the benefit of the Industry Commission's final report on cost recovery for fisheries management. This report is before us today.

I turn now to the state of Australian fisheries. We are all used to the dismal science of the economists at the Industry Commission but the picture painted by this report is more dismal than usual. Most Commonwealth fisheries are over-fished, some to the point of total collapse—for example, the Bass Strait scallops. Others are getting close. The gemfish population has been so depleted that there is real concern as to whether it will recover. The southern shark fishery, the source of flake, is threatened with closure or, at a minimum, drastic reductions in catches until it recovers.

We are all aware of the problems in the south-east trawl fishery, where again huge reductions in catches are necessary. But the report says that it will take an extra $21m in research over the next five years to work out what sustainable catches should be for all the major species involved. Of all the major Commonwealth fisheries, only the northern banana resource is in good shape. It is some consolation, I suppose, to know that our two most valuable export fisheries—prawns and lobsters—are the most robust. The report gives the credit for this to the integration of research and management, putting management of the resource before management of the fishing industry, and close communication and trust between the fishing industry, researchers and managers.

But even in these fisheries, there is substantial over-capacity in the fishing industry. The problem of too many fishermen chasing too few fish is even bigger for those fisheries where catches are plummeting. This problem has actually been exacerbated by inept Commonwealth management in the past. This has spilled over to State managed fisheries as well. Recently, fishermen have been adjusting out of the northern prawn and south-east trawl fisheries into adjacent State fisheries, where the level of effort was already excessive. The result is that fisheries resources throughout the AFZ are being hammered to death, regardless of political boundaries. Urgent reform of Commonwealth-State roles is imperative.

The report highlights the folly of Commonwealth-State jurisdictional divisions within marine ecosystems. I agree with the Commission that urgent action is required by the Commonwealth and the States to rationalise management to ensure that a single agency manages a fishery. Unless this parochialism is overcome, the alternative will be to teach the fish to read the lines painted on the water, but I am afraid there will not be any fish left to teach.

The poor results of past management are made even worse by their high cost. In 1990-91 about $28m was spent by all agencies involved in the management of Commonwealth fisheries. About $15m of this was for research, and about $8m for regulations, administration, licensing and surveillance of the fishing industry. Another $1m or so was spent on management of the commercial fishing industry itself for things like restructuring.

I believe this report is a good report and it goes to the question of good management, not only in terms of the ability of people to catch the fish but also to look after the marine resources as a total resource.
