DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 February 1992, on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that this report applies to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service right throughout Australia but I particularly want to speak about one national park which is fairly close to my home town of Kingaroy. In fact, it is in the Bunya Mountains, part of the Great Dividing Range, between Kingaroy and Dalby. It is about 40 miles from my home.

PARA.TAB: We are privileged indeed to own an area of 12 acres up there. Unfortunately, I do not seem to get very much time to go there, but a lot of our friends and my children seem to find it very useful to be able to go there. As a matter of fact, they are having a `Back to Bunya Mountains' weekend and some of my family want to go up there because they want to be part of it.

My husband, Joh, has actually owned the land for about 45 years. We are very privileged indeed because it is a very lovely national park. Of course, people are learning to appreciate national parks, not only in Queensland but right throughout Australia.

The Bunya Mountains park is so called because of the bunya trees. The bunya trees were there in the days when the Aboriginals were there. They used to climb the trees to get the bunya nuts. People can see all the little marks they have made—I do not presume they had axes in those days—but whatever it was that they had, they made those marks and they climbed the trees to get the bunya nuts.

Mount Mobil is about 3,600 feet high, and in my earlier days I used to get up there quite often, but it is a bit more difficult now that I am getting that bit older. Nevertheless, there are now so many people who appreciate the value of the Bunyas that several people are building homes in the area.

A man by the name of Mr Frank Unwin has turned an area he bought in earlier days into an environment park and is building an environment school so that eventually school children can go up there and learn the value of the mountains and the environment. There are junior rangers in the holiday periods and people willingly give their time to train young people to appreciate the value of the mountains. My own daughter and some of my grandchildren are now working as voluntary rangers up there. I think that that is very important.

On our own block we have many beautiful, big bunya trees. I have often said to Joh, `Wouldn't it be a good idea to sell a few of them?' He just holds his hands up in horror and says, `That's no good!' I can remember that many years ago he decided that we were going to have a reafforestation plant there, and we planted some hundreds of hoop pine trees. My word, I was glad I only had to do one day and not two!

Up there we have beautiful birds—beautiful king parrots—and people feed them. In the holidays there are ever so many people who go up there to feed the king parrots and the other birds. Even now, at home, since my husband has been out of politics, he has taken to feeding the birds. I used to get very cross when people would say that Joh did not look after the environment. I have never seen anybody plant so many trees, feed so many birds and possums, and things like that. I have often wondered whether some of the greenies do those sorts of things.

I do want to congratulate the National Parks and Wildlife Service that looks after the Bunya Mountains area. It does wonderful work keeping the walking tracks in order. There are ever so many lovely walks that you can go on up there. I think, Mr Acting Deputy President, I might even get you to come up from Tasmania so that you can have a look at these beautiful Bunya Mountains.

There is one problem though. The wallabies have come in very, very large numbers, so much so—and I hate to say it—that they have really become a pest because there are so many of them. We have one area of ground on which we cannot really keep any cattle any more because there are so many wallabies that eat up the grass.

Also in Queensland, of course, we have the very important Carnarvon National Park. It is a lot further out but lots and lots of people still go there. The Queensland Government now has also declared a national park at Lawn Hill, right up in the far north of Queensland. It is amazing the number of people who go up there in their four-wheel drive vehicles because they have learned to love these national parks. My eldest daughter, her husband and children love nothing better than to get into their four-wheel drive and go to visit all the national parks in Queensland. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to speak to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service annual report of 1990-91. The report describes the role of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, which includes policy development and planning. The One Nation statement is relevant in this regard because it states new policy concerning the integration of economic and environmental considerations in the process of establishing national parks. The One Nation statement says that `when considering proposals to establish new national parks or marine parks and reserves, and where such action would constrain future access to resources within them, a prior assessment of the economic values and potential of the area will be routinely carried out'.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats totally reject such an approach for reasons which have also been stated clearly as the view of conservation groups at page 146 of the report of the Ecologically Sustainable Development—Mining Working Group. That view is that it is inappropriate to engage in a trade-off between economic and ecological values because, firstly, there is an increasing scarcity of relatively unmodified, natural ecosystems in Australia; secondly, there are always environmental risks associated with resource surveys; thirdly, that if circumstances arise where a protected area contains the only remaining accessible mineral resource, then fundamental questions need to be asked about the sustainability of a society which has, in less than 200 years, driven us to that situation; and finally, the same minerals can often be found and exploited elsewhere.

Minerals exploitation and mining is prohibited in less than 2 1/2 per cent of this country. Exploration and mining should occur, therefore, only in those areas where the conservation values are not sufficiently high to require protection in national parks.

The report also describes the activities carried out under the endangered species program. This program is severely restricted in scope. Mr Kelly's endangered species legislation relates to less than one per cent of the Australian land mass. Indeed, we still have not seen that legislation. As an island continent, Australia's ecosystems and biodiversity need to be managed as a whole. In relation to endangered species, this can best be achieved by the Commonwealth having overriding powers in regard to protection measures for endangered species.

Another matter which is discussed in this report which I wish to raise relates to the Australian biological resources study. ABRS identifies what kinds of plants and animals there are in Australia and where these plants and animals can be found. It has been estimated that, because of the very paltry funding that ABRS receives, at present rates the ABRS will not complete its task of identifying the animals and plants, their relationships and where they are found until the year 3000. By that time, at the rate we are going, most of them will no longer exist.

It is critical to the management of our natural environment that we know what is there and how these species interact. It is important that we discover these things as quickly as possible. The ABRS must therefore be expanded. It must incorporate a program to survey the type and location of all major Australian flora and fauna; incorporate a national land capability assessment program of the Australian continent, Australian ocean, fisheries and all territories; and establish an environmental resource library that provides access to data and modelling capabilities to interested non-government organisations on the same principle as a public library. We believe, therefore, that funding for the ABRS should be substantially upgraded to at least $24m per year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Honeybee and Research Development Council on its annual report for 1991 and for the work it does in helping to increase and promote the honey and beekeeping industries in Australia. I believe that this is a very important matter because in the year 1991 the honey industry, like so many others, experienced many challenges and changes. Indeed, the Chairman of the Council noted in the report that:

Like many other rural industries, the honey industry has experienced challenges to its viability, ranging from resource security through to a sensible price for honey and other bee products on the domestic and international markets.
These challenges include not only the domestic and international environment, but also the legislative changes made by the Government. On page 3 of the report, the Chairman noted:
The Council is in discussion with the industry over the ramifications of the decision by Mr Kerin (when he was Minister for Primary Industry) to terminate the Australian Honey Board.

Further reading of this report identifies that the key to successful beekeeping is effective hive and business management. However, the degree of success varies significantly as there is a wide range in the yield per hive which apiarists achieve within the same area. This difference indicates that there are benefits to be gained from extension which promotes more efficient beekeeping practices.

PARA.TAB: I note on page 16 of the report that one means by which the Council is promoting more efficient beekeeping practices is by recording and disseminating the sound beekeeping practices of successful beekeepers. This has been brought about by the recognition that many successful beekeepers throughout Australia have acquired a wealth of knowledge and understanding of beekeeping practices that lead to profitable enterprise. With the retirement of some of the older beekeepers, there is considerable danger that much of this valuable information will be lost unless it is documented. The Council believes that efforts should be made to capture this knowledge for the benefit of other beekeepers who are presently in the industry and for the benefit of those who enter the profession in years to come.

One successful company which should be used as a fine example in this industry is one from my home State of Queensland. The Brisbane-based Honey Corporation of Australia, producer of the Capilano brand, is a low-profile company with high-profile brands. This 43-year-old company's products sit on the shelves of virtually every supermarket and grocery store in Australia and are significantly represented overseas. I want to say that I regularly buy Capilano honey; the clover honey. It is a lovely gold coloured, light, beautiful tasting honey. I can recommend it to Senator Brownhill as a very special honey.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have bees on our property at home.
—Sometimes the honey from private hives is not quite as nice as Capilano honey. I know; we have hives at home.
—Ours is better.

—Ours might not come from the best types of plants. Senator Parer might have clover honey in his hives. Capilano is the largest honey producer in Australia and turns over $11m a year in export alone, with the product being sent to 32 countries. It manages honey manufacturing and bottling plants in three States.

PARA.TAB: A recent article on the company in my home newspaper, the Courier-Mail, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the effects of the prolonged drought have pushed the honey yield down, there are compensations for exporters in a low Australian dollar.
It also said:
In almost 40 years of exporting, Capilano has sold product overseas in US dollars in a period when the Australian currency has fluctuated between US60c and US90c.

Monitoring the Australian dollar is an important job and the general manager, Mr Lloyd Smith, says that the firm has become quite skilled at foreign exchange management. Perhaps the Government could take a few hints from what Mr Lloyd Smith says. The honey from Capilano is very nice and I think people overseas should be able to enjoy it as I do. I keep a good supply of Capilano clover honey in my cupboard at home.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not need sweetening.

—Senator Coulter thinks it helps to sweeten me up. I thank him for saying so. Certainly it is a very important industry as far as I am concerned. The bees are only small but they are very big workers. There cannot be too many drones; there have to be plenty of workers to get good honey. That probably applies to every walk of life. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of seeming to speak too much in the Senate this afternoon, I wish to speak to the motion concerning the Family Court of Australia annual report 1990-91. The Family Court of Australia exists because, increasingly, Australian men and women do not hesitate to tear up marital commitments, to shirk marital obligations and to abuse their former spouses and, in particular, their children either by neglect or by physical abuse.

PARA.TAB: This situation is best illustrated when we read that approximately one marriage in three ends in divorce and that each year there are 2.5 divorces for every 1,000 people. Each year, the Family Court deals with over 100,000 adult litigants, more than 150,000 children and many more people who are involved without being litigants. No other court has anything like this volume of business or contact with the Australian public.
On page 23 of the report, we read that:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of 42,635 divorces were granted by the Family Courts of Australia and Western Australia in 1990.
The report also says:
That figure represents a 3 per cent increase over 1989 and a rate of 2.5 divorces per 1,000 persons.

It is 16 years since the Family Law Act came onto the Australian legal landscape. Divorce is a dreadfully sad thing, but what we have to remember is that when there is a divorce it represents the breakdown of another family unit. Ultimately, the health of society depends on the stability, well-being and harmonious functioning of the family.

PARA.TAB: It was once said that civilisation can be lost in a single generation if the value systems are not preserved and passed on through the family. The Family Law Act in its entirety has led to a disintegration of many of those value systems. It was one of the most discriminatory, ill-considered and badly drafted Bills to be ever introduced into the Australian Parliament. It discriminated against those who do not want their marriages to be dissolved at the whim of the other party.

It is a fact of life that in marriage the longer it lasts, the woman's independence and her main economic ability to fend for herself become less. Women are not given the protection and support to which they are entitled as wives and mothers of the future generations of Australians. It takes away from women security and legal safeguards and, in the guise of enabling marriages to be dissolved with dignity, enables all marriages to be dissolved on the unilateral decision of either party on short notice. In other words, it reduces marriage to a purely temporary union with little or no protection for women and children.

It turns marriage into a cheap, temporary union which may be dissolved on the unilateral decision of one party. It creates a climate which leads to a light-hearted approach to marriage. Frank Stewart, who was a Minister in the Whitlam Government at the time the legislation was introduced, was a fierce opponent of it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the cloak of removing injustice, humiliation and indignity from divorce, new injustices, new humiliations and new indignities are created.

What could be more humiliating, more unjust, or cause greater distress and hurt to a spouse than to be abandoned without cause by his or her partner merely at the whim of such partner as a matter of convenience on 12 months notice?
This is not divorce because the marriage has irretrievably or otherwise broken down; it is the destruction of marriage by abandonment.
Another speaker, Kevin Cairns, said:

The powerhouse clauses (of the Act). . . concern the nature of the marriage itself, and make it clear that the package no fault is not a package that has any truth; that the so-called relegation of indignity and bitterness is not relegated.

All that is done is that it is swept under the carpet and allowed to fester in the hearts, minds, activities and feelings of those who have been wronged, which in most cases is the dependent partner in a marriage. It certainly is not a Bill which has anything to do with the rights or equality of women in that situation.

Many honourable senators would be aware of the high number of constituents who have come to them with complaints. Let us ask ourselves: what have been the social and economic consequences for the community of this Act? As I said earlier, it has been an increase in the number of divorces in the community. That is one of the problems. Children have suffered the psychological damage of family collapse, the loss of security, torn affections and both emotional and material disturbance. The Bishop of Toowoomba wrote to the Australian newspaper:
I believe that the Family Law Act which made divorce available to either party after 12 months separation struck a heavy blow at marriage and the family. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)that the Senate disapproves of the action of the Western Australian Government for failing to appoint Christabel Chamarette as a Senator for Western Australia, condemns the Western Australian Government for denying electors of that State their rightful representation in the Senate, and condemns the Western Australian Government for the disrespect it has shown to the Senate.

I move only the first part of the motion as printed on the Notice Paper. The reason is that I have realised that since submitting that motion the second part, which refers to forwarding the resolution to the Presiding Officers, is really not appropriate. So I am moving the first part of this motion only, and I express the hope that we may not debate this motion too long because I believe that there is support for it.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, dealing with the chronology of the matters in Western Australia, it is worth noting that the Western Australian Government was advised in November 1991 that the then senator Jo Vallentine would resign on 31 January 1992 and that the Greens in Western Australia had nominated Christabel Chamarette as her replacement. So there was plenty of foreknowledge by the Government of Western Australia—indeed, by this chamber and everybody else—as to what was intended.

On 31 January, Senator Vallentine resigned, with notification being received by the Western Australian Legislative Council President on Monday, 3 February. On Wednesday, 5 February, the Western Australia Parliament began a special sitting to pass the juvenile justice legislation and both Houses were notified of the vacancy in the Senate.

On Thursday, 6 February, the Legislative Assembly adjourned without any joint sitting being held or asked for to appoint Christabel Chamarette to the vacant position, and on 7 February the Legislative Council adjourned. On Tuesday, 11 February, the Western Australian Premier advised Ms Chamarette that the Solicitor-General had confirmed that the appointment must be made by a joint sitting of the Western Australian Parliament. The Premier also stated that this would be done when Parliament resumed on or after 12 March. In other words, in that brief chronology we see that notification was received in time for the joint sitting, which was held on 5 February, to adequately discharge its responsibility with respect to making the appointment.

The only other points I wish to make have adequately been made in the past in relation to similar situations which have arisen where vacancies have occurred either by death or resignation. I point particularly to the circumstances in 1970 when, upon the death of Senator McKellar—and I am reading from Hansard of 17 June 1970—Senator Greenwood said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . upon the death of Senator McKellar on 13th April, a letter was forwarded in the usual form to the Governor of New South Wales by the President of the Senate on 14th April. On 16th April a reply from the Governor of New South Wales indicated his acknowledgment of receipt of that letter and his indication that he would bring it to the attention of his Ministers. Nothing has occurred since 16th April.
He went on to say:
. . . I believe that this is a matter that affects the Senate and that a situation such as has developed ought not to be allowed to develop without something being said about it in the Senate.
He then drew attention to the Constitution. Senator Greenwood, quoted Quick and Garran:

It is a principle of the Constitution that the representation of States in the Senate should be maintained, as far as possible, with unbroken continuity, and that no State should be, for any time longer than absolutely necessary, short in its representation and consequently deficient in its political strength in the Council of States.

That really only needs to be put into the record again because I wholeheartedly agree with those sentiments. In the same debate, Senator Murphy supported the concern being expressed at the lack of alacrity, or the slowness, with which the New South Wales Government had discharged its responsibility in filling the vacancy. He said, amongst other things:

PARA.TAB: I think it is extremely dangerous that a place should be left unfilled. It is obvious that if it were to be accepted that a place could be left unfilled, it might be suggested that this was being done for improper motives. It could be suggested that a State was being deprived of its true representation so that a party political advantage could be achieved. That would be an abuse of the Constitution. So I entirely agree with what has been said.

SPEECH.PARA: That is, he agreed with what had been said by Senator Greenwood. He went on:
May I also say that from the expressions I hear around me this would appear to be the opinion of the whole Senate.
Senator Byrne said:
I agree that this is a very serious intrusion into the functioning of federal government and, at the extremity, could completely frustrate it.

That seems to me to sum up the matter. Here we have an opportunity by the Western Australian Government to fill this casual vacancy; the opportunity was there and it was not taken. That has indeed frustrated the proper functioning of this Senate in that the people of Western Australia have not had representation from somebody who at the relevant time—at the election—was elected a member of the Greens to represent one part of that electorate in this place. Accordingly, everybody in this chamber should agree with the motion as I have now amended it:
That the Senate disapproves of the action of the Western Australian Government for failing to appoint Christabel Chamarette—
the properly and duly nominated person by her Party—

as a Senator for Western Australia, condemns the Western Australian Government for denying electors of that State their rightful representation in the Senate, and condemns the Western Australian Government for the disrespect it has shown to the Senate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Government received legal advice from the Solicitor-General that it would be improper for the Governor-General in Council to appoint a replacement senator for Western Australia. The State Government decided to act in accordance with that advice. It is true that there was a one-day sitting of the State Parliament. That was a sitting called for a special purpose; it was not the joint sitting which is required for the purpose of replacing a senator.

PARA.TAB: However, if people think that Western Australia is being unjustly or unnecessarily deprived of its full Senate representation in the Federal Parliament, the finger should be pointed not at the State Government but at Senator Vallentine, who resigned her position on 31 January. As she left the Senate, she gave three reasons, one of which was ill health. No doubt she was tired, having travelled incessantly around the country delivering sanctimonious sermons on the professional protest circuit and seeing how often she could get herself arrested within range of a television camera. People do not usually give six months notice of health enforced retirement, as Senator Vallentine did, let alone forecast the precise day on which their health would deteriorate to the point where there was no option other than retirement, even though she had still been playing on the protest circuit a week or two before.

The second reason Senator Vallentine gave was a desire to spend more time with her family—a common enough desire but not highly developed enough in March of 1990, less than two years before her retirement, when she sought re-election to the Senate. The third reason—and we are getting into the nitty-gritty here—was that she retired, to use her own words, `in accordance with the Green principle of rotating jobs'. For four years, Senator Vallentine—ex-Country Party, ex-Nuclear Disarmament Party, ex-Independent—sat in the Senate as a Western Australian Green senator. She preached the abstemious Green doctrine of self-denial and forgone consumption, lower real incomes and lower levels of material consumption. She then, with breathtaking hypocrisy, tried to pull the big financial scam to convert the $85,000 lump sum superannuation payment—to which she was, by the relevant Act of Parliament, entitled—into a $165,000 lump sum payment, plus a lifetime indexed pension of $16,500. I think the hypocrisy of that is so great that I do not really need to say any more about it.

However, I make one related observation. More than 30.4 per cent of the Green candidates in the recent Tasmanian election were school teachers, who therefore, as Greens, preach the same doctrine of self-denial, forgone material consumption and so on. I have not noticed any resistance within the teachers union to the demands for continuing increases in teachers' real incomes. While they preach the doctrine of self-denial in public fora and in the Parliament, they obviously do not preach it within the teachers union, otherwise some countervailing power would have developed.

Senator Vallentine, having conformed, as she put it, to the Green principle of rotating jobs and having established the precedent of doing that, and trying to pull the big financial scam while she did it, poses two question for Senator-elect Chamarette when she finally takes her seat in the Parliament. Does she too subscribe to the Green principle of rotating jobs and, if so, will she after serving six years in the Parliament also resign and then follow the precedent established by Senator Vallentine of trying to pull the big financial scam?

For the reasons that I have gone into already, Senator-elect Chamarette is not yet in the Senate. I hope as soon as she is here that she will make it very clear whether she intends to repeat what Senator Vallentine has done; that is, resign after six years—assuming she has not lost an election in the meantime—and then try to pull the same financial scam. I certainly look forward to hearing her tell us what she plans to do when she does take her seat. Of course, I will not be voting for this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make some remarks relating to the motion moved by Senator Coulter. I do so because it was only 18 or so months ago when I was in the same boat as Senator-elect Chamarette, sitting up there in the gallery looking down waiting to make it onto the floor of this hallowed chamber, and very keen to do so. Of course, the Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, obviously had the same high esteem for my political ambitions as she does for Christabel's ambition to actually make it down onto the red carpet and take up her seat.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that all of what Senator Walsh said should be supported. Senator Vallentine's spot should be filled quickly and I certainly hope that Senator-elect Chamarette makes a more reasoned, rational contribution to the chamber than at times we saw Senator Vallentine make. I came into this place late in the last sitting to listen to Senator Vallentine's valedictory speech for light entertainment. I did walk out because I thought it was such a rambling, raving contribution. It certainly showed that she had learnt very little in her time in this place, and perhaps it was a sign of the sickness that afflicted her.

One of the issues that this motion raises is the history of replacing casual vacancies in the Senate and, as was referred to briefly by Senator Coulter, it has been politicised by both sides of politics in Australia's history. It is something that should not be politicised; it is something that brings the role of the Senate into sharp focus. That is an issue always close to my heart. No matter what happens in Australian politics, no matter what political observers say about the Senate, it should have a role in sticking up for States interests and States rights. It is no longer politically popular to talk about States rights, but we have seen here in Canberra in the past week a very good example of how honourable senators can make a difference for their State and their States interests. At the Labor Party's caucus meeting, none other than Senator Colston ensured that the Bill on daylight saving put forward by the honourable member for Stirling, Ronald Edwards, was defeated in the Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with a lot of help from his friends.

—I am sure that was true, Senator Collins. Senator Colston had a very good run in the Western Australian press recently which said that he was a great defender of States rights; and that is fantastic to see. But the Senate does have a role to play in sticking up for States rights and the interests of States. If Western Australia does not have full representation in this place, it has been let down.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the delay in installing Senator Vallentine's replacement. We should bear in mind a lot of what Senator Walsh and Senator Coulter said about the notice we were given. The notice that the Western Australian Parliament and the Western Australian Government were given makes it even more of a disgrace.

The Solicitor-General's advice that Senator Walsh referred to is just that—advice. There are many examples of Governors making an appointment in council in order to fill casual vacancies and having it ratified by the parliament at a later date. But even if the Solicitor-General and the Premier are right in accepting that advice, there was no reason why, when the Western Australian Parliament got together for a two-day special sitting to debate the juvenile justice legislation, it could not have called the two Houses together for two or three minutes to confirm the nomination of Senator-elect Chamarette to represent Western Australia.

I reiterate my sense of empathy with Senator Chamarette. I am sure that we will have very many differences on political matters when she actually makes it into this hallowed chamber. But in relation to the frustration of having to sit up in the gallery, look down on this chamber and not be able to interject or have any of the great fun that we have here in the chamber from time to time, I do empathise with her.

I conclude by saying that there is a very recent example—in fact, this happened no later than yesterday—involving probably a friend of Senator McKiernan named Jim Brown, MLC, who has retired from the State Legislative Council—

TALK.START.PARA: —The south-east region.
—He is either from the south-east region or the agricultural region.
—The agricultural region.

—It is the agricultural region. There was a lovely picture in yesterday's West Australian of Jim Brown showing Kim Chance, who is his replacement, around the hallowed chambers of the august body, the Legislative Council in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I would put it to the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, that had the boot been on the other foot—had the Australian Government decided to wait around for a few months and a few sitting days before the House of Representatives and the Senate had a joint sitting to confirm the appointment of Mr Chance, MLC-elect, to his seat in the upper House—people would have been jumping up and down, screaming and shrieking about how we were stopping the proper representation of the people of Western Australia in the upper House of that State. It would be a disgrace if we had not acted. This is a parallel that should be drawn. Of course, Kim Chance will have no such troubles in taking his seat in the upper House.

So we are left with a situation where Christabel Chamarette will not be able to take her seat in this chamber. She has already lost seven sitting days as a result of either mismanagement, bloody-minded obstruction or purely a total disrespect for Western Australia's electoral representation in this place.

Exactly the same thing occurred to me. I had the Library pull out some statistics of previous fillings of casual vacancies. Due to the mismanagement of Carmen Lawrence's Government 18 months ago, I missed out on seven sitting days. The Western Australian people missed the representation that they should have had. I know that when I got here they were so much more pleased that they had full representation.

Let us look at some other replacements since 1987. Senator McClelland was replaced by Senator West in 1987; Senator McMullan replaced Senator Susan Ryan in 1988; and Senator Faulkner, who is in the chamber, replaced former Senator Gietzelt in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —All great senators.

—They were all great senators. Honourable senators might not agree with the next one—Senator Sanders being replaced by Senator Bell in 1990. Also, Senator Lees replaced Senator Haines. All of them were replaced very efficiently by the State parliaments or the Governors-in-Council of State governments all around Australia of different political persuasions with no loss of parliamentary time, except in Senator Faulkner's case where there was an eight-day delay. I am sure that the people of New South Wales felt robbed by not having Senator Faulkner in the chamber sticking up for them and carrying on with a continual verbal diatribe of interjections day after day.

PARA.TAB: In recent history, the actions of the Lawrence Labor Government in delaying the full representation of Western Australia stand out.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Faulkner will refer to other matters in other States if he makes a contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that there are only three possible motivations: first, bloody-minded obstruction; secondly, mismanagement and disorganisation of the sort that was shown recently in relation to the sewerage plant under the One Nation program; or, thirdly, a total disrespect for the Senate and the people of Western Australia and their representation in this place. I join Senator Coulter in condemning the actions of the Premier of Western Australia and call on her to call the chambers together to expedite the appointment of Senator-elect Chamarette to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I missed Senator Coulter's speech and part of Senator Walsh's contribution to the debate. I welcome this debate because it impacts upon both this place and my constituents in the State that I represent in this place.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that circumstances have arisen whereby the State of Western Australia has not had its full representation in this chamber over the last seven days. Only 11 senators from Western Australia have been present. That scenario is not the fault of the Western Australian Government. Mind you, the vast majority of senators in this place would not have noticed a great deal of difference because very rarely did we have in this place the presence of Senator Vallentine.

Senator Vallentine, in her time in this place as an elected representative of the State of Western Australia—which was a total of six years and seven months—only participated in this place on very rare occasions. When she did, she spoke from prepared material. It was just rote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which she read at a thousand miles an hour.

—As Senator Collins said, it was material which was read at a thousand miles an hour. Quite honestly, I do not think it helped the running of this place. Even though there is some argy-bargy across the chamber from time to time, Senator Vallentine did not make an enormous contribution.

PARA.TAB: I put Senator Vallentine's record in front of both the chamber and the Western Australian electorate. Indeed, I encourage Ms Chamarette to take great notice of it because it is truly an appalling record. Certainly the attendance of the former senator in the chamber was not quite so bad. Out of a total of 530 days over that six years and seven months that she was a senator for the State of Western Australia, Senator Vallentine came to this place on 471 occasions.

However, the work of the chamber is a different matter. The work of the chamber can be measured by divisions which are held within the chamber. In Senator Vallentine's first six months as a member of this place she participated in seven out of 53 divisions. In the next 12 months—January to December 1986—there were 189 divisions. The bells rang 189 times and the then Senator Vallentine attended here on one occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —She didn't have much interest in legislation, did she?

—It was alleged that she was interested in certain legislation. She went on the public record on many occasions saying that she had a great and deep interest in the nuclear disarmament and peace field. Indeed she had, and I will not take that away from her. I certainly commend her in that respect, even though I did not on every occasion agree with her, either through my public actions or in private.

PARA.TAB: I know of one very important particular piece of legislation when, at the time of its debate in the Senate chamber, Senator Vallentine was on a plane to Perth. That was the—

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Pacific—
—South Pacific Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Treaty. Nothing is happening between Senator Knowles and me; we have not shared notes on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I will carry on with the statistics. From January to December 1987, there were 168 Senate divisions and Senator Vallentine attended on 53 occasions; in 1988, 159 divisions and 37 attendances by Senator Vallentine; 1989, 197 divisions and she attended 58; 1990, 107 divisions and on 40 occasions she attended; and last year, 1991, 150 divisions and she attended 50. Of a total of 1,023 divisions which were called for over those six years and seven months, we were blessed with the presence of Senator Vallentine on 246 occasions. That is a 24 per cent attendance rate which is outrageous in my opinion.

I think it is worthy of note—and I noted it in a publication that I distributed earlier this year—that the Senator participated for 25 per cent of her time here, she was paid 100 per cent of her salary and, even though she does not have to participate any further, she is still hoping for an honorary 50 per cent salary. I seek leave to have those figures incorporated in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

in Senate during her political career—July 1985 to January 1992 (6 years 7 months)
