TALK.START.PARA: —I commenced my comments this afternoon by saying that it was not the fault of the Western Australian State Government that Christabel Chamarette is not sitting in this place now as a senator, a political representative for the State of Western Australia. Standing order 156 of the Standing Orders of the Western Australian Legislative Council states:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Whenever Parliament has been informed by Message from His Excellency the Governor that the place of a Senator for the State of Western Australia has become vacant under section 15 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act, a motion shall be made that the President and Speaker do fix a day and a place whereon and whereat the Council and Assembly, sitting and voting together, may choose a person to hold the place of the Senator whose place has become vacant as aforesaid. Such day shall be not be more than 14 days after the date of such motion.
2.The President and Speaker shall, as soon as practicable, inform the Council and Assembly respectively of the date and place so fixed.
3.At the date and place so fixed the Members of the Council and Assembly shall sit together and proceed to the election of a Senator.
At such sitting the President of the Council, or, in his absence, the Speaker of the Assembly, shall preside.

It is the first part of that standing order that is of note. There has been publicity in Western Australia about the fact that the State Government knew well in advance when Senator Vallentine was going to retire—and I am not going to resile from that. Notice was given in September last year that Senator Vallentine was going to get a headache on 31 January and would not be able to continue in this place as a representative of the people of Western Australia. That is certainly on the record.

PARA.TAB: However, the rules of the Parliament of Western Australia state that it is not the retiring senator who has to give notice. The senator gives notice to the Governor of the State, or the Governor of the State is informed, and then the machinery of the Western Australian legislature turns into action after the Governor advises the President of the Western Australian Legislative Council and the Speaker of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly. That could not happen until after Senator Vallentine had presented her resignation to the President of this place, Senator Sibraa. That happened on 31 January this year.

The machinery started, and I understand that notice was given by the Governor of Western Australia to the Parliamentary Officers in Western Australia in the first week in February. I understand that because of the unique situation in Western Australia, the Parliament is technically still in session—it has not been prorogued—and that no date for a joint sitting of that Parliament could be arranged until, as I understand is going to happen, on the seventeenth day of this month. That is Saint Patrick's Day, and it is probably appropriate that a Green senator should be elected in the State of Western Australia on St Patrick's Day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, very good!

—Senator Collins liked that one. It is worth while giving a bit of notice of these things. I dare say other people will claim different things on St Patrick's Day itself. The date has now been set because the wheels have been set in motion and the lack of full representation from the State will indeed be remedied on 17 March this year.

PARA.TAB: I want to move on to another constitutional difficulty which arises out of the imbroglio that we are part of. Section 15 of the Australian Constitution, a constitution which we in this place are governed by, states how the State Houses have to go about electing their representatives. I will not take the time of the Senate by quoting the matter in full, but it gives the option for the Executive Council to appoint a senator if the Parliament is not in session—and, indeed, it is not at the moment in Western Australia.

This has happened on three occasions in the past: in 1952, Senator Cooke; in 1966, Senator Withers; and in 1974, Senator Reid. Appointment was made by the Governor to fill the vacancy in each case. The Parliament was merely adjourned but not prorogued at the time the vacancy was notified. In 1952 and 1966 a joint sitting of the Parliament later purported to confirm the appointments, but in 1974 there was no joint sitting to confirm that appointment. However, no challenge was made to any of the three appointments. There is advice from the Solicitor-General in Western Australia that if the State Government had had to proceed with the appointment through Executive Council, it was open to legal challenge. Constitutional lawyers would be much better and much more able to address this point than I am. I understand Senator Walsh made some reference to the fact that the Western Australian Solicitor-General did make some comment on that.

The parliaments of Australia do go on convention, practice and a form of common law which has been established over the years, and we set our rules by them. In many cases and at many times in this place we have heard quotes from Odgers' Australian Senate Practice. Odgers notes it is an undesirable practice that, unless parliament is specifically recalled, a casual vacancy may exist for a long time. This is not the first occasion on which there have been casual vacancies in this place and that those vacancies have existed for some period of time.

Some mention was made of my colleague Senator Faulkner, the person who holds the position I used to hold as Deputy Government Whip in this chamber. I must say that he is doing the job a lot better than I used to do it and he should reign in that position for many, many years to come. His position was vacant for some nine days, I believe.

The longest period that we had a vacancy in this place was in respect of Senator Devereux. He was elected constitutionally within his political party to fill the vacancy created by Senator Grimes, but the Tasmanian State Government deliberately would not take steps to confirm Senator Devereux's appointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a few things to say about that, too.

—Indeed you did, Senator Coulter. If one is looking for disgraceful acts, that was a disgraceful act at the time. Without wishing to point the finger around the chamber, I note, as the record will show, that on every occasion a division occurred at that time there was always a pair from the Opposition side of the chamber to Senator Devereux. It was a State problem that kept John Devereux out of this chamber until the election in 1987. It was not as a result of anything that happened in this place.

PARA.TAB: I put these things on the record because Senator Campbell referred to the fact that Western Australians are perhaps seen to be a little disadvantaged. I know that there were some colleagues on the Opposition benches who felt that not only was this side disadvantaged by Senator Devereux's long absence from this place, but that the Senate chamber itself was disadvantaged because it did not have its full quota of senators to call upon.

As I said in my opening remarks, I do not think the Senate chamber has been all that disadvantaged on this occasion because the State of Western Australia is one representative short. On that topic, I earlier received leave to incorporate in Hansard statistics I have collected on the attendance and record of the previous incumbent in the twelfth position on the Western Australian Senate ticket.

I conclude by saying that the situation is unfortunate, but these circumstances could have been overcome if the previous incumbent, Senator Vallentine as she was, had given notice of the fact that she was too ill to continue in this place. I wish her very good health for the future and my wishes are extended to her family, but if she knew that she was too ill to continue, she could have taken steps—between September, through October, November and the early part of December—to ensure that her resignation was received in this place so that the message could have been conveyed to the authorities in Western Australia. That should have been done in plenty of time to ensure that the State was in no way disadvantaged by the fact that at the moment we do not have our full quota of senators. The timing of the resignation was not in the hands of the Government of Western Australia, and I believe that the State Government is not in any way manipulating the system to disadvantage the elected person who will succeed Senator Vallentine.

I hope that my comments will be conveyed to Ms Chamarette and that she will put on a much more sterling performance in the representation of the electorate of Western Australia in this place than the previous incumbent did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the motion moved by Senator Coulter that expresses disapproval of the action of the Western Australia Government for failing to appoint Christabel Chamarette as a senator for Western Australia and condemns the Western Australian Government for denying electors of that State their rightful representation in the Senate. I want to address that issue in my remarks. The Labor Government of Western Australia has shown no respect for the Senate and the Federal Parliament in its delay in appointing a twelfth senator from my State in succession to Senator Vallentine. As a convinced federalist, it is my firm belief that our system can endure only if there is mutual respect between the two different levels of government. I think that is where the State Government is failing at this stage.

PARA.TAB: There are firm precedents for the appointment of senators to such casual vacancies by the State Governor in Council on occasions when State Parliaments are not sitting. I am aware that some of the cases have been referred to today by previous speakers. This is an essential practice, given the long recesses that occur at State level. It would have assisted had Senator McKiernan mentioned actual incidents and the way in which these replacements have taken place in the past. In Western Australia the Parliament does not normally sit between the first week in December and the middle of March.

Senator Bell's name was mentioned earlier. I point out that on 7 March 1990 Senator Bell was appointed by the Executive Council in Tasmania. More particularly, in Western Australia on 11 March 1981 former Senator Martyr was appointed by the Governor in succession to former Senator Rocher to represent the Liberal Party, and was confirmed when State Parliament met on 25 March. Therefore, I believe that the precedent is obvious.

On 16 January 1974 there is an even more telling precedent because, under the Tonkin Labor Government of Western Australia, Senator David Reid was appointed by the Governor on the resignation of Country Party Senator Prowse. Senator Reid was defeated at the May 1974 elections before State Parliament next met, but the Executive Council approved his appointment at that stage.

Furthermore, former Senator Reg Withers was appointed by the Governor of Western Australia to succeed former Senator Sir Shane Paltridge on 17 February 1966, and that was not confirmed by the State Parliament until 9 August that year. That was a period from February to August, and it makes a mockery of statements to the effect that the Government has not had an opportunity to put senator-elect Chamarette into the Senate. I could quote further precedents, but the point has been squarely made that the Lawrence Labor Government has defied convention, and that is the sad part about the matter. Surely if that Government had been troubled by genuine legal doubt, the proper course would have been to make the appointment, as appointments have been made in the past, and deal with any challenge later.

Since 1977 there has been a very clear imperative for all State governments to honour the wishes of the electors of their State and to fill any Senate vacancy without delay. This was the effect of one of the few successful amendments to the Constitution in recent years, namely, section 15. That move won overwhelming support from Australian electors, who insisted that Senate vacancies be filled by a nominee of the same party. Although that amendment was sponsored by the coalition Government, it had the fervent support of the ALP, whose members waxed indignant over the actions of the Askin and Bjelke-Petersen State governments in refusing to replace resigning and deceased Labor senators with Labor nominees. The fact that those members performed like trained seals at that time highlights the fact that they should come to grips with the situation and act according to the spirit of those amendments as well as the letter to ensure that they are carried out.

The electors of Western Australia who voted for an independent Green in 1990 are fully entitled to continued representation. Every Western Australian, whoever we voted for, is entitled to be represented by 12 rather than 11 senators. It is a long bow for Senator McKiernan to draw in seeking to compare what Senator Vallentine did with what it is hoped senator-elect Chamarette will or will not be doing. It is sad that a State is being denied that representation purely based on the fact that Senator Vallentine was a poor attendee in this place.

The Labor Party, which is supposedly very sensitive to the rights of employees, should have some concern for the staff members who are waiting for their new employment, who have effectively been employed by Christabel Chamarette, who cannot be paid and, I understand, cannot be paid retrospectively either.

The Lawrence Labor Government can hardly claim to have been taken by surprise in this matter, as has been clearly outlined here today. Former Senator Vallentine announced her resignation in September and said that it would take effect on 31 January. I agree with Senator McKiernan that the Western Australian Government could not have taken any initiative in making a formal replacement until after that date, until the letter had been received by the President of the Senate, but that does not alter the fact that there is another course which can be taken and, on this occasion, should be taken.

While I was certainly not impressed at the casual and leisurely pace of former Senator Vallentine's departure, particularly as health reasons were given, the point remains that the State Government knew precisely what the situation would be and when it would arise. In January the State Government decided to have a special sitting of Parliament in February. It could at least have said, `Here is an opportunity where we can agree to this and have a joint sitting', so that Senator-elect Chamarette could take her place here when the Senate resumed later that month. Seldom has a State government been given more notice of a Senate vacancy, and I think it should have acted accordingly.

The precedent that the Carmen Lawrence Labor Government has created not only is an insult to the Senate and the electors of Western Australia but also has very dangerous implications. The next time there is a Senate vacancy may well not be a time that is chosen by a retiring senator—it could be due to ill health, death or a number of other reasons. On that occasion, it may be politically convenient for a State government to leave a Federal Government or, in fact, a Federal Opposition short of a senator for as long as possible when contentious legislation is before the Senate.

Senator McKiernan mentioned the problem we had with respect to Senator Devereux. In that case, the Opposition extended a pair so that the balance in the Senate remained the same. On this occasion, particularly with an independent to whom pairs are not granted, that position does not apply. It shows that at a time when there may be highly contentious legislation before the Senate a State government could take the Lawrence Government lead and manipulate it to the point that it could have very serious implications for a government or an opposition.

While I am sure that I would disagree profoundly with the views Christabel Chamarette may put forward—for example, with respect to the Forests Protection Bill—I consider it grossly wrong and unfair that her Party should be unrepresented in such a debate that has been scheduled for the Senate this week. Okay, it has not come up this week, but it was scheduled by the Government for debate this week. I believe that the State Government should not have denied Christabel Chamarette the right to put her position, and the position of the people whom she represents, in that debate. It is ironic that a prospective senator who may take a greater interest in the work of the Senate than did her predecessor—it is certainly hoped that she does—is denied her seat because of the actions of a State Labor Government.

We should not, in any case, be surprised at the actions of Premier Lawrence and her Cabinet, who have to be dragged kicking and screaming into holding a royal commission; a Premier who, 12 months ago, tried to sabotage inconvenient select committees of her own upper House by artificially proroguing Parliament because they happened to have references before them which she disagreed with; a Government with a senior Minister now facing a contempt of court charge. Moreover, the Lawrence Government apparently doctored a Public Service Commission report into the relationship between a government agency and a failed financial group by removing the reference to a senior Minister's intervention on its behalf.

This Government is not clean; it is not lily white, pure and with nothing to hide. This Government had to be pushed into every action about all of the grubby little deals that it has done, yet here it is now trying to take the high moral road and saying, `We have to approve Senator-elect Chamarette to come to the Federal Senate'. That is not so. It can be done; it has been done. Why is it not being done on this occasion? The improprieties of a scandal-ridden Labor Government are a matter of shame for the people of Western Australia. Now this habitual impropriety has spilled over to an insult to the Senate, a denial of representation to all Western Australians, injustice to certain individuals and a sinister precedent in defiance of the Constitution. I think this motion deserves support for the variety of reasons that I have outlined to the Senate this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Senator Coulter's motion with respect to the delay by the Western Australian Government in appointing a replacement for former Senator Vallentine. I wish to pick up a point which was made by a speaker on the other side without getting into a debate about precedent. In my mind there is a clear distinction between a State government which ultimately has the right in respect of an appointment, which chooses not to make a certain appointment, and a State government which simply delays the appointment. One is an overt deliberate act, in the sense of making a determination in respect of candidates, and the other is in many respects more Machiavellian and political. The Constitution is now substantially changed so the activities that took place in the past are no longer available to State governments.

PARA.TAB: In my view, this debate is not about partisan politics, it is about what the right and proper thing is and what the right and proper thing ought to be. What gives this chamber and this institution its very real strength is that there are so many different points of view. Nobody disagreed more than I did with former Senator Vallentine, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—Absolutely, but what gives democracy its full voice in this chamber are those disagreements. If the State Government of Western Australia is held to be corrupt and not incompetent, that is not an unreasonable assessment that the public or members of this chamber might be inclined to make, particularly with respect to the revelations which thus far have prevailed in the royal commission in that State.

PARA.TAB: This is the second occasion on which the Western Australian Labor State Government has failed, in proper and reasonable time, to replace a senator or fulfil a casual vacancy. We were reminded by Senator Campbell that the last occasion was his case in May 1990 when he was preselected by the Liberal Party to replace Mr Fred Chaney, who thought at that time that he was going to bigger and greater things.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was wrong.
—He went downhill.

—I think any step from here into the other chamber is inevitably bound to lead downhill. Senator Campbell was preselected by the Liberal Party, in all its wisdom, on 30 April 1990. The State Parliament of Western Australia met between 1 May and 17 May. During that period, it failed the test of competence and integrity. During that time it failed to have a joint sitting, a process which takes but five minutes. Whether that was incompetence, Machiavellian politics or just pure corruption, I do not know. Ultimately, it had the effect of denying Senator Campbell the opportunity to represent the Liberal Party and Western Australia in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: We now have the circumstance where Senator Vallentine resigned from the Senate on 31 January having notified the Western Australian Government and the Premier of that State on 1 November of her intention to do so, as I understand it. Thirty-four days after her official formal resignation, Ms Chamarette has not yet been sworn in. It is not as if the State Government has not been meeting. The Parliament of Western Australia met on both 5 and 6 February. It met for political reasons, granted, but it was consequential enough for Premier Carmen Lawrence to come scurrying back from Italy to Perth. It seems to me that that would have been an ideal and practical opportunity to have addressed the matter of the appointment of Ms Chamarette. However, it seemed that the Government was more interested in locking up 14-year-old Aboriginal children—children who had not yet reached the period of wisdom and knowledge—than it was in appointing a representative of that State to this chamber. There seems to be no reason that I can detect why that appointment could not have been made on that occasion.

When it comes to political stunts, political grandstanding, political populism and the hard reality of politics, the State Labor Government can very quickly call the Parliament together for the purpose it chooses. On that occasion it considered one piece of legislation that was so serious that it brought back various members of parliament from their junkets around the world. Having done that, it did not have the commonsense or the decency or the integrity to make the appointment it should have made at that time. It took no more than a rally, an uprising from the people of Western Australia about the abysmal record of that Government in law and order for the Government to decide overnight that the legislation was a matter of urgency and that it would recall the Parliament to jam through legislation designed to placate the vocal members of the Western Australian public.

Senator Knowles made the point that there is a clear distinction between denying a voice to an independent and denying a voice to a member of a major political party. The Labor Government of Western Australia is denying all Western Australians a voice in this chamber. More particularly, I remind the Senate that there were 14,521 first votes—that is not very many in a Senate election—for Senator Vallentine. In other words, 14,521 people put their No. 1 vote alongside Senator Vallentine's name. It was their intention that she be their representative. In total votes, the Greens in Western Australian attracted 60,923 votes—6.7 per cent of the vote. That group of people whose intention it was to be represented by Senator Vallentine, whatever shade of politics she was embracing at that time—whether it be anti-nuclear, Greens or whatever—chose her as their duly elected representative.

The Constitution provides that in the event that there is a vacancy created by the departure of a senator such as Senator Vallentine, those people shall be represented in this chamber by a person selected by her political party. Those people are being denied representation in the Federal Parliament. In the case of independents, it is a greater aberration than if the senator happens to be from either the Labor Party or the Liberal Party because there are others there who can articulate and express and represent the point of view of the people of Western Australia. There is no substitute voice in this chamber for the Green party. There is no member of the House of Representatives who can express the point of view that Ms Chamarette will no doubt expound when she is sworn into this chamber in due course.

What is intrinsic about Ms Chamarette's appointment and election to this chamber is that the Senate is meant to be the House of second deliberation. More particularly, it is meant to be the States' house, with equal representation. The purpose of equal representation was deliberately designed to ensure that the less populous States such as Western Australia had the same voice as New South Wales and Victoria. To the extent that there is one vacancy in this chamber at present, the people of Western Australia are being denied that voice. The point has been made that it is not possible to create a pair.

My understanding is that Senator Vallentine contacted the Premier and deliberately chose 31 January as her date of resignation to ensure ample time for the Parliament of Western Australia to swear in her replacement. She was given an undertaking that the timing would be such that it would assume that Ms Chamarette would be sworn in for the beginning of that session. In fact, the correspondence I have seen confirms that. Senator Vallentine was informally told on the telephone that it was a five-minute exercise, a formality, and there would be no problem. That was not to be the case.

I do not know whether this problem is the result of the bumbling incompetence of the Labor Government. Senator Robert Ray always says that when trying to decide whether it is a stuff-up or a conspiracy, go for a stuff-up every time. If it were not for the revelations of the Royal Commission, I would be inclined to that view, although when we see the way the Government has gone about things over there, we find it has even stuffed up its corruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't even do that properly.

—That is right. There is nothing worse than a rotten crook. I conclude by saying that the circumstance that this chamber finds itself in is absolutely intolerable. I understand that the Western Australian Parliament, in its casual laid back way, will be meeting on 15 March. I have looked at the number of sitting days it has—it is not an occasion to have a debate about that. We are lucky to find a date when it is sitting so Ms Chamarette can get appointed any time. I understand it is now to be 15 March. I do not know whether we are sitting during that week.
—No, we sit on 24 March.

—Senator Reid kindly informs me that we are not sitting until 24 March, so Ms Chamarette cannot take up her seat in this chamber until that date. I think that is a very poor record. There seems to be no reasonable excuse for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate will be brief. I simply wish to point out one thing: how often it is that the Senate Hansard and the Journals of the Senate turn senators on all sides of the House who reach for the high moral ground, as two of the speakers have done this afternoon, into people with feet of clay. The Democrats come out okay on this exercise, I might add.

PARA.TAB: I recall the occasion when the Liberal conservative Premier of Tasmania refused to appoint a nominee of a party—that was Senator Devereux—to this Senate. There was a prolonged debate in the Senate on a two-part motion. The first part confirmed that political parties of the same complexion should be able to appoint replacements. The second part condemned the conservative government of Tasmania for not doing so. A motion was moved by the Democrats on 19 March 1987 condemning the Tasmanian Government for so doing.

We have had statements made in here this afternoon by Senator Knowles, who described herself as a confirmed federalist, condemning this action of the Western Australian Government. She condemned the action; she condemned the Labor Party for voting on party lines on these issues and said, `Labor performed like trained seals to this insult to the Senate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, it is always interesting, when honourable senators on all sides of the chamber—and I am quite happy once again to confirm that—reach for the high moral ground, to see how they turn out to have feet of clay when one refers either to the Hansards or the Journals of the Senate. Senator Knowles, in her contribution prior to dinner, took the high moral ground in condemning the Western Australian Labor Government. She described herself as `a confirmed federalist'. She condemned the actions of the Western Australian Government as an insult to the Senate. She accused the Western Australian Government of taking the high moral road, and then attacked the Labor Party for voting on party lines on these issues on previous occasions, saying, `Labor performed like trained seals'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crichton-Browne, who also reached for the high moral ground on this issue prior to the dinner break when he attacked the Western Australian State Government, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: This is not about partisan politics; it is about doing the right thing.

The last occasion that I recall an extremely difficult situation for the Labor Party arising in this regard was when the conservative leader of Tasmania, Mr Gray, would not appoint Senator Devereux. I actually took the trouble to have a look and as a result found some very interesting material in the Journals of the Senate of 19 March 1987 concerning a motion similar to the one moved by the Democrats today. On that occasion it was moved by Senator Haines, who was the then Democrat leader. The motion was in two parts, the first part confirming that a replacement senator should be the person duly nominated by the political party. Of course, no-one opposed that. The second part, which was similar to the motion we have here tonight, condemned the conservative Gray Government of Tasmania for not appointing the appointee—that is, Senator Devereux as he now is—of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: These two senators who spoke just before dinner, these confirmed federalists who said that this should not be a partisan matter and that we should not perform as trained seals and vote on party lines, voted on that issue. Of course, I expected to find the motion fully supported. But, in the Journals of the Senate of 19 March 1987, we see that Senator Durack moved an amendment to this motion to remove the criticism of the Gray conservative Government in Tasmania. Naturally, one would expect to find that Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Knowles, consistent with what they said earlier this evening—and Senator McKiernan will attest to this; he was here—voted with the Labor Party on this non-partisan issue to oppose the deletion of any criticism of the conservative Government. The division was recorded at the bottom of page 1699 of the Journals of the Senate of 19 March 1987. Among the honourable senators who opposed any mention of any criticism of the conservative Government and voted to delete these offensive words against the conservative Government of Tasmania, we find listed the names of Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Knowles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprise, surprise!

—Indeed. I conclude by saying, as I did before dinner—and I must concede this—that the one group of people in this chamber who are moving in a way totally consistent with the way they moved in 1987 are the Australian Democrats.

—As Senator Collins has pointed out, this is not the first time such an issue has come before the Senate. In fact, to my knowledge this issue has been floating around for 20 or 30 years. I refer to the situation of different State governments getting different legal opinions as to their entitlement. We have seen two practices, of course, in the replacement of senators. The first one, and the most normal one, is where a combined meeting—if the State has two houses—chooses a candidate. That is very inconvenient when a candidate resigns and the State parliament is not in session. I guess on this occasion I am not sure what influenced the timing of the resignation. It is somewhat regrettable that the resignation did not coincide with the sittings of the State Parliament of Western Australia—other than, as I understand it, one extraordinary sitting to pass the very controversial Juveniles Act. I do not think this was a case where another month or two either side would have hurt in terms of the resignation. We all knew from November at least about Senator Vallentine's impending resignation.
—September.
—From September, Senator McKiernan tells me. So she could well have resigned and met the requirement.

PARA.TAB: There is, of course, an alternative method, which I think has been used on several occasions, whereby an appointment can be made by the Executive Council, I think it is, of whatever State it is and, in turn, that appointment is later confirmed by State parliament. But it also has to be said, in some defence of the Western Australian Government, that it has to act on the legal advice that it has been given, and I understand that that is what is really motivating this agenda. There are no political agendas in this case. There is no advantage to be derived for the Labor Party generally from not having the senator-designate here at the moment. I think it is not surprising that the Western Australian Government, having obtained that legal advice, is now abiding by it.

I am not saying, however, that that legal advice is valid, and I do not know that it can be tested. It is just a pity that this country did not, a few years ago, support the referendum proposal for advisory opinions in the High Court. We could well have taken this particular issue to the High Court for an advisory opinion, without a large and expensive legal case, and got a view on it which would clean it up once and for all. But, not only in this case but also in every other case like this, we run the danger of a State Attorney-General's office coming forward with advice that this matter is not without doubt, and that is the problem in this case.

Regrettably, I was in Cabinet when Senator Coulter was speaking on this question so I do not know which particular line he took or whether he accused us simply of political bloody-mindedness or stupidity. I tend to think that the latter would probably be more appropriate in these sorts of cases.

Like Senator Collins, I also want to note for the record what is a growing hypocrisy in the Opposition. This Opposition is starting to act like an entrenched Opposition—like it has been there forever and will be there forever. Its previous actions in government are constantly now forgotten and buried in the mists of time. As Senator Collins pointed out, the Liberal Party on other occasions has not supported these sorts of motions but rather has voted in the opposite manner. And that is just becoming replicated right throughout the procedures of this place.

When I had the great honour of walking into this place last year and guillotining 62 Bills, one would not believe the squawks out of those opposite. Yet, when one went back through the record, all the recidivists there had voted for similar motions; not only for guillotines, but for gagging the guillotine debate as well. We are seeing another example of that here today; we are seeing it time and time again. The Opposition here does not fully understand the role of an opposition. It is not to oppose everything. It is not to be political on everything. But, if honourable senators opposite are going to do that, at least let us see some consistency from them. Senator Collins, I understand, praised the Democrats for being consistent on this. That is fair enough. Apparently, they are the only ones who have been consistent in this particular case.

In summary, it is regrettable that our seventy-sixth senator is not with us today. I do not believe the Western Australian Government acted maliciously on this particular point. I think, having got the legal advice from the Attorney-General, it would have had some problems with proceeding on another course. On the question of whether this chamber has been bitterly deprived of a senator, I will reserve judgment until I see that honourable senator's ability. I do not think there has been a division in this chamber that has been as close as one vote—honourable senators may correct me if I am wrong. But this is a matter that should be dispatched as quickly as possible. Again, I do not know the date when the State Parliament is resuming. I assume it is within a week or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next Thursday.

—So next Thursday the matter will be resolved. If this motion is carried, it will just go into the rubbish bin of history, of course. As we can see, a couple of people are listening to the debate, if I have not put them to sleep yet. It will be recorded in the Journals of the Senate. So I suppose Senator Coulter will be recorded in some place in history over the matter. But I think the honourable senator has made many other contributions that are of much higher significance.

—in reply—I will just take a few minutes to express my appreciation to Senator Knowles and Senator Campbell for their remarks in relation to this motion, and to deprecate the remarks of Senator Walsh, most of which were quite irrelevant. I can understand Senator Walsh not particularly liking Senator Vallentine or what she stood for, but the fact is that she was elected by the people of Western Australia and she had a legitimate place in this chamber. That is really the point; that her replacement, equally, has a legitimate place in this chamber, irrespective of what Senator Walsh might think of her views.

PARA.TAB: The other point I would make in this connection—and this was picked up by Senator McKiernan—is that she was elected by the electors of Western Australia to fill a particular role as they saw it. That is the democratic principle. It does not matter what we think of our fellow senators in terms of how many times they come into the chamber or what issues they vote upon. That is not the point. The point is that with her particular views, she was elected to represent the electors of Western Australia and to express those views in this chamber. If she chose to express those views on a limited range of issues because they were the issues that concerned the electors who put her here, she was in fact fulfilling her proper function.

If we look at the number of times Senator Vallentine spoke, we find that the statistics are rather interesting. In the Weekly Senate Hansard we find that Senator Vallentine spoke on 259 occasions, whereas Senator McKiernan spoke on 128 occasions. In the Historic Senate Hansard we find that Senator Vallentine spoke on 180 occasions and Senator McKiernan on 98 occasions. So, in terms of the actual issues that she chose to take up—presumably because she was elected to take up those issues—she clearly performed her function. I think that is further indicated by the fact that she was not elected only once—the electors of Western Australia elected her again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Always on our preferences, and knocking off your candidate.
—Yes, very regrettable for us. Very regrettable.
—But at least she sent her preferences to us and not to you.

—In fact our candidate received more primary votes. It was very much to be regretted by us. Nevertheless, under the system that we have, the system of proportional representation and transferable votes, Senator Vallentine finished up with sufficient votes to get the quota and she was elected to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I think the real point is this: that the Western Australian Parliament met on 5 February. It was a sitting at which both Houses were present. A joint sitting could have been arranged, quite contrary to what Senator Walsh seemed to imply. It probably would have taken a little longer than the two or three minutes that some senators have suggested, but certainly no more than 10 minutes. I seem to recall that Senator Lees was processed through the South Australian Parliament in about 10 minutes from beginning to end. I believe, therefore, that this motion should be supported and that the Western Australian Government has been lax in simply not taking the opportunity presented to it to fill that vacancy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate endorses moving the Australian economy toward a pattern of ecologically sustainable development, recognising that such movement is consistent with a substantial reduction in unemployment and an attack on the growing foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion now before us is one which I believe the Senate can also support because it expresses a view which has been widely endorsed, both by the Government and also by the Opposition, that the Australian economy, in moving towards an ecologically sustainable pattern of development can, at the same time, substantially address the problem of unemployment and make a substantial attack on foreign debt.

PARA.TAB: The definition of `sustainable development' which is often used—I know that former Senator Chaney, now Mr Chaney, has quoted it in the House of Representatives—is that contained in the Brundtland Report entitled `Our Common Future'. The definition given there describes sustainable development as development which meets the needs of the present generation without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

Quite clearly, what one has here is a definition which accepts not only the principle of equity within a particular generation, but also takes as quite fundamental that there should be equity between the generations. In other words, the present generation should not so use or abuse the resources which are available to it that succeeding generations do not have available to them at least the resources of an equivalent nature to meet their own needs.

We are all aware that the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, introduced a number of committees to research the ESD program, and those committees have now reported. However, in speaking to the three chairs of the ESD working groups, he outlined four fundamental goals. The first was the improvement of individual and community well-being and welfare by following the path of economic progress that did not impair the welfare of future generations. There again one has an expression of the principle of inter-generational equity. The second was the provision of equity within and between generations, and there it is made quite explicit. The third was the recognition of the global dimension, and there one has a broader recognition of equity within the present generation. The final goal was the protection of biological diversity and the maintenance of ecological processes and systems. One has a recognition there of the fundamental nature of ecological systems and the role which those systems play in maintaining an on-going, viable economy in this or any other country.

It seems rather strange that when one looks at many of the debates which have arisen around this general theme, one finds that the protection of the environment and job growth are often seen as mutually exclusive or even as contradictory goals. Despite the fact that industry was involved in the Hawke Government's ESD process, and contributed very extensively to the reports of those various committees, some parts of industry in Australia have quite strongly expressed the view that it is either the environment and sustainability or jobs and economic prosperity.

The Government's definition directly links employment and the improvement of individual and community well-being and welfare, and the provision of equity within and between generations with the principle of sustainability. High levels of unemployment contravene this principle of equity. I think we all believe in inter-generational equity because we all believe in a fair go. This principle says that a fair go, a level playing field, should be extended beyond the present generation to future generations. It is based on the general idea of equality of opportunity and extending that idea to later generations.

Quite clearly, the use of non-renewable resources cannot form part of a pattern of sustainability and of sustainable development unless part of those resources is devoted to the materialisation—and I use that word quite deliberately and advisedly—of alternatives.

For example, there is no way in which one can use coal in a renewable way. It is a non-renewable resource. But a society which is committed to sustainability must quite clearly devote sufficient of the resources which come from the economic benefit of burning the coal so that the next generation will have at least the same amount of energy available to it. In other words, there must be the actualisation of technologies which will provide the energy for the future generation if this present generation chooses to use coal. Similarly, in relation to so-called renewable resources, a society cannot be said to be sustainable if indeed it uses those non-renewable resources in non-sustainable ways. The rate at which renewable resources are used must clearly be in strict proportion to the rate at which those resources such as forests or other natural systems can renew themselves.

Much has been given in recent times to the notion of the market and the fundamental nature which the market should play in a modern industrial society. Great emphasis is given to this by both the Government and the Opposition. One of the fundamental principles which underlies the market and is linked to the idea of fairness—fairness between individuals in the present generation and future generations—is the idea of a level playing field; that those who operate in the market are indeed given equal opportunities to participate in that market system. Of course, when one starts looking at markets, one finds that very often those playing fields are anything but level. The area in which they are most unlevel is in relation to internalising what economists call externalities.

One of the principal externalities is the idea of bringing into present prices a representation which future generations may make on those markets if they were present here to make those demands. Clearly, if one is to use the market system and one is given to the principle of level playing fields, one is therefore committed to the notion of internalising externalities and one should be attempting to write into present prices those demands which future generations will make on those resources.

As I mentioned earlier, coal is principally burnt for the making of electricity. In Australia coal is the principal source of our electricity. Since 1983 the Labor Government has devoted certain funds to energy research. But one finds that only one-tenth of the amount of money put into energy research has actually gone into providing those alternatives which will address the problems of the next generation, while in California one has seen the development of a number of technologies which are currently competitive—even if one does not internalise those externalities.

One finds among those technologies the development of wind generation of electricity and solar thermal generation of electricity in which the costs, even without the internalisation of those externalities, are still reasonably competitive. So a sensible development in this country of sustainability would be to move towards those technologies, recognising that they move us towards greater sustainability.

At the same time—and here I make very strongly the point which lies at the heart of this motion—we must realise that those technologies will provide a great deal more employment than the use of coal burning technology in large central power stations. Moreover, because we do not make any heavy generating equipment in this country, the use of those technologies also involves the use of equipment which can be totally manufactured in this country. Therefore, the use of this technology can at the same time address this very serious and growing problem of the large foreign debt. So in the area of electricity and energy use through the use of electricity we have a key example of the way in which the problems of unemployment, the problems of foreign debt and the problems of moving towards a sustainable pattern of development can be married together.

As I say, one finds that the Government has not pursued that sort of path. Indeed, in the One Nation statement, one finds that the Government is to reduce the sales tax on cars—not in any way which would move us towards greater sustainability but simply across the board. If the Government—and I make this criticism in that the Government has passed up a marvellous opportunity here—had chosen to remove the sales tax on a sliding scale which related to the fuel efficiency of the car, then indeed employment in the car industry may have been stimulated at the same time as moving towards sustainability.

One of our principal criticisms of the Opposition in relation to its goods and services tax bears precisely on this point. When a 15 per cent single tax is fixed and the sales tax regime is removed the opportunity is denied through the tax system of internalising those externalities which relate to the use of non-renewable resources and the need to address the problem of making those resources available to the next generation.

One could develop other alternatives in relation to other industries in Australia. One of those industries, of course, is the paper industry which is very much to the fore in debates at the present time in relation to northern Tasmania. There are other ways of meeting the $1.6 billion worth of paper imports into this country—again addressing the problem of the foreign debt—without building large pulp mills based on old growth forests and causing the non-sustainable environmental damage that that involves. The alternatives depend upon annual crops, which again can be grown much more effectively, can produce much greater amounts of fibre per hectare and can provide much greater local employment, thus stimulating and supporting local industry. At the same time it addresses the problem of foreign indebtedness.

The points that really stand out in this debate, with which I hope both the old parties will agree, is that ecologically sustainable development is about Australia becoming a clever country. To be clever, we have to expand and create value added industries in rural and manufacturing sectors, and that cleverness also requires the protection of our environment.

Ecologically sustainable development will become the mainstream economic approach of our future. It is already becoming the mainstream approach of many other nations. In those nations there is a growing recognition with many of our trading partners that sustainable development makes good economic sense. We will be left behind unless we work seriously at moving towards ecologically sustainable development. To put ESD on the back-burner—which seems to be the practice, if not the preferred attitude, of both Labor and the coalition parties—is not very clever. It will not produce a clever country; nor will it provide a viable future for our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this motion moved by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate endorse moving the Australian economy toward a pattern of ecologically sustainable development, recognising that such movement is consistent with a substantial reduction in unemployment and an attack on the growing foreign debt.

While listening to Senator Coulter, albeit for only the last half of his contribution—I was unable to be here earlier—I detected a note of complaint. I noted that Senator Coulter did not think the Government was serious about ecologically sustainable development.

PARA.TAB: If the number of pages of reports under the heading of ecologically sustainable development is any measure, the Government is certainly serious. More important is a united front in moving to make ESD very much a central part of the Government's program. I have no trouble at all in saying that, at least for a large part of the sentiment expressed in the motion, I am happy to stand up and support it. That is because, amongst other reasons, however we want to emphasise questions of ecologically sustainable development; they are vitally important. If it takes that set of words and a series of inquiries to make our governments and business and industry leaders in this country, to say nothing of other planners, take seriously questions of the contribution of this generation's production to the next, then we would have to say, `Hear, hear'.

I make a couple of comments on the specifics about the ESD argument. Earlier, when some of the draft documents on the ESD debate were proposed and circulated, it was drawn to my attention by a colleague in South Australia that the word `health' had never been mentioned in the whole debate. I was very pleased on his behalf to put his letter of concern into the pipeline so that health considerations could get onto the ESD agenda. Indeed, those considerations are now on both the agenda and in this intersectoral issues report. In that report there is a page of recommendations addressing health questions through occupational health and safety and the impact of environmental concerns on health.

One of the reasons I am principally concerned about this is because of the economics. What is the point of trying to cure people downstream at a considerable outlay of health dollars when, with some appropriate thinking and planning, those diseases could be avoided? The example that springs to mind most readily is that of the Wittenoom asbestos mine in Western Australia. As early as 1946, one of the duties of Dr—later Professor—Saint from the Western Australian Department of Health was to visit and inspect that mine. He made recommendations about the amount of dust and the way that dust should have been dampened down. Those recommendations were ignored.

Now, nearly 50 years later, we are seeing very high pay-outs in the courts to people who have been found to have mesothelioma, which is judged to have been caused by their life in the mine or nearby; that is, the families of miners were also at risk and indeed suffered mesothelioma. Millions of dollars in compensation are being paid when a large amount of that illness, and certainly that pay-out, could have been avoided by practising the appropriate ecologically sustainable course way back then. So even in straight efficiencies the economies of good practice and prevention in the outlay of introducing dust absorption or dampening down equipment would have played a large part in preventing the illness. In this instance we can actually put a figure on how much it will cost this many years later. That, of course, is a dollar cost and it does not measure the cost of human misery, pain and suffering and the loss to families of the breadwinner or other members who have died as a result of that disease.

There are many examples in the history of industrial development of diseases and extraordinarily expensive clean-ups necessary because of poor industrial practice. Even if we did not become positively committed to the future developments or benefits from ESD, we could at least be committed to ecologically sustainable development through the good practices of the systems we currently know, as in good occupational health and safety. In industry there are many examples over the years of the extraordinary cost, damage and death as a result of very poor industrial practice.

There are obvious examples of air pollution through the number of people who have suffered disease and illness as a consequence of it. It is interesting that the people who suffer chest diseases, asthma and so on from air pollution do not really capture the hearts and minds of governments as much as the cost of having to clean up. It seems that the dollar costs impacted more than the health of the citizens of any country. That is very regrettable, but I am pleased that the dollar debate is now on the side of the angels.

The other great example of poor industrial practice that has led, and continues to lead, to unnecessary outlays as a consequence of ill-health has been water pollution, in particular through chemically laden industrial waste run-off from various factories around the place. We could even talk about the environmental and water pollution from the disposal of sewage. We have seen some fairly stunning reports of that over the past few years.

It was not until the tourists visiting Bondi Beach were upset that governments acted. For many years Australian citizens suffered the indignity of sewage pollution on their beaches. But when it finally impacted on the dollar benefits of the tourist industry governments acted. If this sounds too cynical, I make no apologies at all.

For many people who fought for the issues that are now collectively called ecologically sustainable development, what might in the past have been called decent, appropriate, good practice, and has been ignored over the years, it is now some comfort to find these issues being taken seriously. But it is also a mite annoying that it was not the rightness of the cause that won the debate but the dollar cost.

The reports that have emerged over the past month or so from the ecologically sustainable development working groups deserve our serious consideration, or at least the consideration of anybody who is interested in the ESD process. The intersectoral report and the reports from each of the subsets on specific areas provide considerable beneficial information. But I would strongly support any moves to reduce the number of words said or written and to dramatically increase the number of policies and practices that start implementing these very significant changes.

I am currently chairing the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into tourism. Some of the matters in the tourist paper are of particular interest to our Committee as we come to the conclusion of our report. Many of these arguments or debates, whether it is called ESD, managing the environment or being a clever country, as Senator Coulter puts it, are running more or less in tandem. It is time to bring together the reports and it is time government had the political will to act on them. The time for this debate is almost at hand. I support the motion moved by Senator Coulter.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The time for consideration of this motion has expired.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.
The Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated my amendments to a number of honourable senators who wanted to look at them earlier. The final copies are now being circulated in the chamber. I thank the Senate for its indulgence in that respect. I will be moving two sets of amendments, both dealing with the same problem. That is, in the targeting of this one-off payment, we have managed to miss out on a number of farming families. These are the families who, when changes were made to the family allowance last year, found that their assets and a small income removed them from eligibility for the family allowance. Indeed, they no longer received the family allowance.

PARA.TAB: The exact number of people so affected is rather difficult to ascertain. Some have put the figure in the area of a few hundred and some have put it in the thousands. There was some suggestion today that it could be up to 50,000, depending on how we count those who have dropped out. It is a matter of whether we take into consideration those who simply do not apply again, in other words, those who were receiving family allowance prior to the assets testing; or whether we just count those who have now applied for the family allowance but have been refused, even under the hardship provisions.

One set of amendments we will be moving is trying to do the same thing we have tried to do on many occasions, that is, change the assets testing provisions for the family allowance to exclude the tools of trade. I think those amendments are just being circulated; they are the ones I have attempted to move on a number of occasions. We have discussed the first set of amendments with honourable senators from other parties and we believe that they will be unsuccessful.

The second set of amendments is far more specific. If passed, they will ensure that those young people covered by the assistance for isolated children's bonus scheme are covered by this one-off payment. It does not mean that they will actually be able to get family allowance in the long term. They will not get onto the family allowance list. However, when it comes to this one-off payment, we believe that it is essential that these children be included.

One of the criticisms that has already been made is that we have not had this proposal fully costed. As I said previously, it is extremely difficult to know exactly how many young people are now missing out on family allowance. Even if every child under the isolated children's assistance scheme—and there are some 100,000—received it, it would amount to a sum of $12m. It seems far more likely that there are only a handful of children—in the thousands, or even in the tens of thousands—who are going to be able to get this. As I said, the numbers are not certain, and I apologise for the lack of costing. I would imagine that the absolute maximum figure is around $6m. When we consider that over $300m is being given out in this one-off payment, an additional $6m is not excessive.
I am not sure whether the amendments are before the Chair as yet. There should be two pages of requests and two pages of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to indicate that we are not in a position to support these amendments. As I understand it, what Senator Lees has in mind is that the provision of the one-off bonus to family allowance recipients should also be extended to cover isolated children. That would seem to be without regard to assets or means test and to cost something of the order of $5m. Whilst we certainly have a great deal of sympathy for isolated children and the parents who have to maintain them, in view of the fact that we regard this whole exercise as gimmickry, throwing money at one particular group, we do not think it solves any more problems to throw money at another group. There may well be other ways and means of providing effective assistance for parents of isolated children, but we do not think that one-off handouts—especially to people who do not live in Wills—make any great sense. Therefore, I indicate that we will not be supporting these amendments.

—The Government is not minded to accept these amendments. The Minister representing the Minister for Social Security has not yet arrived in the chamber. I do not know whether Senator Lees wants to proceed with any further argument on this matter or to pursue it any further, pending his arrival.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I simply wish to proceed with this, considering the hour. However, I wish to answer a comment made by Senator Alston with regard to gimmickry. We would make this payment far more realistic if we start targeting those who need it. I would argue very strongly that isolated children are far more in need than some of the families in suburbia that will get it, who have houses with a value perhaps as high as half a million dollars plus the other $600,000-odd in assets and a $62,000 income.

—As Senator Alston quite rightly points out, families with more children can have a $75,000 income. I can assure this chamber that there are no isolated children living in families at this time with those sorts of incomes.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether the parents representing this group were able to speak to any other honourable senators over this week. We have heard stories from them of their having to withdraw their children from school, and boarding facilities closing in a number of Australian cities. Surely everyone would realise that this is a quite reasonable measure. If I wish to agree with Senator Alston, we can settle on $5m. When we are looking at over $300m, I do not think that $5m is too much, and I believe that it should be extended to isolated children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally Senator Lees is one of the best people in this chamber for keeping us informed of amendments and whatever. I apologise that I have only just been able to see this amendment. It may well have been circulated before. I have a great deal of sympathy with the amendment that was outlined concerning isolated children. It is my view that the parents of isolated children ought to be in receipt of family allowances.

PARA.TAB: I am a little surprised—and I keep hearing it from those opposite in the debate—that they now seem to have distanced themselves from the principle upon which family allowances were established. It is a principle which was accepted by the then Minister in the Fraser Government and the then Opposition spokesman on social security, Senator the Hon. Don Grimes. The principle is that family allowances are really part of the tax transfer system and part of the taxation system, recognising that at any level of income a family with children has greater expenditure on necessities and other things and greater tax burdens than a family without children. That was the principle upon which family allowances were established. I can recall persons getting up in this chamber at that time saying that that was the principle. Indeed, Senator Grimes made a point of it at the economic summit, and it is mentioned in the documents of the economic summit.

I do not know what Opposition senators are doing, but I hear them continually complaining that the Government is not targeting family allowances to those in need. It is part of the tax system. The Government is targeting certain measures to poorer families by way of a family assistance supplement. I am often critical of the Government because it did not ensure that family allowances kept pace with inflation. Two years ago the Government introduced and passed legislation, which we all supported, for the indexation of family allowances, but it was from a low base and that was one of the problems.

I thought that I should raise that point because I hear not only Senator Alston but also a number of others in the Opposition really striking at the very heart of what family allowances are all about. They should reconsider that, particularly in the light of their Fightback package.I am sorry for digressing a little, but I believe that it was apt and appropriate to make those comments in the light of what was said in response to the amendment moved by Senator Lees. As far as it is concerned—from quickly running my eye over it—I would agree with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I have to claim that I have been provoked into responding. I cannot really let those remarks pass, 95 per cent of them being directed not at the amendment but to what Senator Harradine describes as our lack of wholehearted support for the family allowance system, which was introduced by the Fraser Government, and which I think we have reiterated in no uncertain terms in our Fightback package. No-one could seriously contest that we do not regard family allowances with the utmost importance and accord them a very high priority by virtue of the fact that we have undertaken to double them for families earning under $30,000, and to increase them by 50 per cent for families with incomes up to $40,000 and 6 per cent above that.

PARA.TAB: We have also always stood for the notion of means testing transfer payments under the social security system. That is not to say for one moment that we regard family allowances as welfare, or that they are not to be seen as a recognition of the additional cost burdens on families. Indeed, if they are not seen in that light, there is no justification for paying them at all, unless families just happen to be group that is passing by that you want to throw some money at.

The whole purpose of paying extra money to families with children is an explicit recognition that it costs more to raise children than to do without them. That is a different thing altogether from talking about un-means tested payments and it is a different thing again from talking about the effectiveness of a one-off payment. I do not recall, certainly not in my time, a government ever proposing a one-off payment of this or any other order. I have the gravest doubts about the effectiveness of it. Indeed, it is not even put forward as a welfare alleviation measure or as an assistance to families.

Senator McMullan justified it in terms of demand stimulation and quarrelled with the proposition that tax cuts might do the job, presumably because they are permanent and therefore cost a lot more; I suspect that that is really why he was quibbling about it. He did not for a moment try to say that this is being done because there is now a recognition that at this point in time, 2 April 1992, families suddenly need another $125, or even $250 if they have five children or more; he did not put it forward in those terms. This is just a one-off payment. I have the greatest difficulty in appreciating its virtues, but that is not for one moment to derogate from the principle that underlies family allowances.

I simply cannot have it said that we are in any way walking away from our commitment to the notion of family allowances. We would claim that we invented the concept. We deplore the fact that they were allowed to fall behind inflation rates for a number of years, and that all the Government did was lock them in at a low level. All the Government is doing now is throwing $125 at one section of the community.

It does not seem that that will do anything at all to alleviate poverty or provide tangible assistance other than in the most transient manner. I do not regard that as targeting. Targeting is to look at who is suffering and find out who needs the assistance. It is a different proposition altogether to argue that families per se, because one has children, entitles one to have a higher ongoing permanent payment. What Senator Harradine presumably would argue for is that we ought to give more recognition than we do at the moment to the additional costs borne by families.

Those costs do not occur on one day—2 April. They occur every week of the year, every day of the year. The only way we can sensibly acknowledge the proposition that Senator Harradine would argue for is to give a permanent increase, as indeed the Government has done in relation to family allowance supplements. But when it comes to family allowances, all it has done is spray around a bit of confetti. We might not like the proposition that it has been done for the benefit of those in the electorate of Wills. I do not know why it has been done. I suppose the Government thinks it has some merit, but it certainly escapes me and I just do not think it meets any of those objectives that we are concerned about—and certainly not what Senator Harradine would argue for.

So do not confuse my great lack of support or enthusiasm for this proposition with any suggestion that somehow we are weakening in our support of family allowances. One only has to look at Fightback! to see that we are proposing to do a great deal more than the Government in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for rising again, but my fears have only become entrenched from the last response by Senator Alston. I think he ought to have a look at the history of this particular question. For him to indicate that this really is a social security payment flies in the face of the principle upon which the family allowances were based.
—These are social security transfer payments. You can't quarrel with that.
—It is not a social security transfer payment.
—It's not welfare.

—I am talking about the principle upon which family allowances were based in 1976. If Senator Alston is saying, as he appears to be saying, that they are not targeted properly, that they should be means tested, then he is ignoring what occurred in 1976. In 1976, as Senator Alston knows, the tax rebate system was abolished for children and this was then cashed up and paid to the parent of the children, normally the mother. That was not means tested. The tax rebate system actually applied to everybody.

PARA.TAB: One of the difficulties with the tax rebate system, and particularly the difficulty with the tax concession for children, was that it was not obtainable by a significant group of families on low income. That was another reason to welcome the abolition of the rebate system and the transfer of the money directly to the mother. There were a number of reasons. That had been argued by Albert Monk back in 1943, if Senator Alston wants to go back that far.

I feel that it is important not to consider family allowances as a social security measure but to consider—as Senator Alston's Government considered in 1976; as this Government considered over a period of time; and as did Senator Grimes, the then Minister, when the economic summit was about—them as a tax transfer system.

If one adopts the attitude Senator Alston is adopting, one will say, `Any business will have its taxation provisions relate to its income'. For example, every company can claim depreciation against machinery and so on. That does not apply other than on the basis of horizontal equity.

There are two aspects here: horizontal equity and vertical equity. The vertical equity aspect is covered to a certain extent by the taxation system and the different rates of taxation. The horizontal equity in this particular area should apply across the board. It always did apply across the board until such time as people then looked upon the family allowance as a social welfare payment. I think it is essential at some stage for the Committee to be reminded of those salient facts.

I come to the point, finally, that it is not fair to suggest that I am agreeing wholeheartedly with just the one-off payment. I said this afternoon—and I draw Senator Alston's attention to the speech I made this afternoon—that I welcomed the decision of the Government because it was an acknowledgment of the fact that the burden of the recession was being borne very heavily by families. But I also indicated and quoted from the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) that he regarded this as being a kick-start to the economy. I indicated with the assistance of tables that really what should be done—and I invite the Minister at some stage to look at what I said—is to give a permanent and appropriate increase to family allowances. I also welcomed the permanent weekly increase given in the family assistance supplement. That is simply what I wished to say. I thank you, Mr Chairman, because this is relevant to the amendment that is before the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that Senator Lees had a discussion today with Minister Blewett on this question and that he assured her that he would consider her concerns outside of the context of this Bill; that is, those concerns relating to farmers. I understand that Senator Lees had a discussion with Minister Blewett. I think it is appropriate for me to repeat that assurance, because the Minister is keen to consider the problem which he believes Senator Lees has rightly raised but perhaps not so rightly put into the form of the amendment that we see here tonight. So, while the Government cannot support that amendment, it can support the idea of looking at this problem outside of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Obviously the legislation and its speedy passage is important because it delivers hundreds of millions of dollars to Australian families. I would have thought, particularly at this time, that it was appropriate that that be done very soon. A commencement date has been set only two or three weeks off, so I do not believe it is possible to even contemplate any kind of delay.

In terms of the discussion that took place between Senator Harradine and Senator Alston, obviously it was said in the chamber many times by Senator Grimes when he was a member of this place, and by myself when I had the job, that family allowances are not meant to be targeted social welfare payments, but rather recognition of the extra costs and burdens involved in raising children. I believe that very much still to be the case.

When Senator Alston talks about targeting, I think that what the Government has made fairly clear about this measure is its importance to the economy at large. Having said that, I think that there are 1.9 million Australian families who will be pretty happy about receiving the payment. A lot of them will have delayed small purchases for their children, and I think they will be delighted to receive that payment, get on with those purchases, and in so doing help out the economy. In fact, this is a highly targeted way of helping with one part of an overall package in getting the economy moving.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not believe that.
—I believe it absolutely. The problem for Senator Patterson is that so does Australia. I strongly support doing that.

PARA.TAB: In regard to Senator Harradine's comments about a permanent increase in family allowance, it is a matter that I will certainly take up with the Minister. I shall happily lend whatever voice I can in government to such a cause. This legislation also involves a substantial increase in family allowance supplement for low income families, which I hope everyone in the chamber will support. The rent assistance measures are ones that Senator Lees has raised in the chamber on a number of occasions in the past few years. I am sure that she realises they are worthy of support as well. In fact, this legislation does exactly what she asks should have been done well over a year ago. I hope the Australian Democrats in particular can consider that position and contribute to this legislation's passing as quickly as possible.
Question put:
That the requests (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
