Mr President, this Bill will give effect to the Prime Minister's announcement made in One Nation of a reduction in the rate of sales tax on passenger motor vehicles. The reduction will be from 20% to 15% and will apply to vehicles that have a wholesale sale value of $30,505 or less.

SPEECH.PARA: The reduced rate of sales tax for these vehicles will apply to all taxable dealings with passenger motor vehicles that occur on or after 27 February 1992.

The passenger motor vehicles that will qualify for the lower rate of tax will be those vehicles that, if imported, attract customs duty of 35% under the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The 15% rate will also apply to Australian-manufactured vehicles which, if imported, would qualify.

Sales of passenger motor vehicles have suffered heavily in the economic downturn. This has had adverse employment effects throughout the economy, for domestic manufacturers, retailers and importers. The reduction in the rate of sales tax for passenger motor vehicles (other than luxury vehicles) will help to stimulate demand for these vehicles.

Depending on pricing behaviour in the industry, the tax reduction should reduce the price of an average sedan by a little over 3%, or about $800. The CPI could be reduced by about 0.2 percentage points by the measure.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Australian Capital Territory

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory proposes that the name of the Committee be changed. I have already spoken to this report briefly—as I always seem to do on ACT reports. In order to change the name of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory to something that is more appropriate, we have to define the actual area in which the Commonwealth has an interest now that the Australian Capital Territory has self-government. There has been a delay of three years. Until the plan is settled, and areas which were clearly the responsibility of the Federal Government and the Territory Government are defined, there is reason for the Committee to continue under its present name.

PARA.TAB: The Committee is still working under its old name. It is now inquiring into the open spaces which are still the Commonwealth's responsibility. There will be work for the Committee to do in the future. I suggest that there may be a time when it will be appropriate for the Committee and the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Zone to be incorporated into one committee.

I mention the demise of the Australian Capital Territory Committee because it is, if not the oldest, one of the oldest joint committees of this Parliament. The Committee was established in 1957 at a time when, following the Menzies decision that Australia should have a national capital of which the nation would be proud, it was clearly appropriate and necessary for the Parliament to take a more active role. It was not sufficient to merely leave it to government to run the national capital.

Indeed, over the years the Parliament has shown very clearly that it is interested in the national capital. One might say that it has been ambivalent: on the one hand, Federal parliamentarians are inclined to knock Canberra and, on the other hand, when there are issues about its planning they have always taken a great interest. For the most part, the work of the Committee over the years has related to variations of the city plan, changes in the roads and the lay out of Canberra and approving the subdivisions of the new suburbs as they were built.

Honourable senators will recall that the ACT was represented in the House of Representatives for a number of years by Mr Jim Fraser, a Labor member who had voting rights only in respect of issues directly affecting the ACT. Subsequently, the ACT gained full representation. It had one Federal member, then two Federal members and then two senators. Who knows where it will end—around about there I should imagine for some time. After senators for the Territory were first elected at the end of 1975, the Committee undertook more work in the nature of normal committee inquiries into matters affecting the Territory.

My predecessor, John Knight, was the Chairman of that Committee. I became the Chairman after he died—which was 11 years ago yesterday. John Knight prepared a document on the history of the Committee from 1957 until 1980. That document contains a very valuable history not only of a parliamentary committee but the Committee's relationship with the Territory which it served.

With the ACT having its own government, the scope of the previous Committee is no longer appropriate. More than 100 senators and members served on it over its lifetime. I think there were 12 different chairmen. For a long time the chairman was always a member of the Senate. A lot of people have taken an active part in the work of the Committee. I certainly support the change of name because it reflects what has happened in the Australian Capital Territory.

I shall be pleased to continue to be on the Committee which remains to look after the Parliament's interests in this Territory, as I have an interest from both points of view. It is a time to mark the passing of that Committee and to recognise the work done by those who have been on it over the years. We will continue to get on with the job of looking after what is left of the Territory as a Commonwealth issue. I hope that the Commonwealth will always continue to fund that portion of its interest in a proper and appropriate manner befitting the status of the national capital.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Senator Burns:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for making your time available to allow me to make a few comments on the Government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. As you would realise, the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee came into being as a result of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, which selectively reported for eight years. Through our actions and those of the Government and the Democrats, we realised that there was not a Senate standing committee that reflected the portfolio of primary industry. I believe there had not been one in existence since about 1945.

PARA.TAB: This Committee came into being late in December last year. Because of the horrific drought problem around Australia, our first reference was to look at the effects of the national drought policy, the drought task force recommendations, and the practical effect they would have on the farmers of Australia, who were trying to come to terms with probably the most horrific drought since 1983. As you would remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, the drought broke in 1983 at about the time our former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, came to power. Travelling around the country, and as a farmer myself—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hobby farmer?

—No, I am not a hobby farmer, although Senator Panizza might consider me to be a hobby farmer compared with himself. As a farmer, I have never before experienced so much devastation and hopelessness among the farmers we met. The only other time I had experienced this sort of feeling was in 1967, after the horrific bushfires in Tasmania, when farmers were burnt out and left with nothing. Some of the people the Committee spoke to were fourth and fifth generation farmers—from the western region of New South Wales, from the Eyre Peninsula and from places such as Jerdacuttup or Ravensthorpe, where my colleague Senator Crane comes from. They have never before experienced such conditions. They have had to cope with droughts and dry spells and all the rest of it, but they have never had this combination of drought, recession, banks screwing them to the floor, and all the other things that go with it.

PARA.TAB: In a baptism of fire, our Committee had to experience the traumas and dramas of what is happening around the rural communities of Australia. Whilst members of the Government have taken some note of what is happening in rural Australia—in fact, this applies to people on our side of politics too—I do not think they fully understand what goes on. People such as Senator Panizza, Senator Crane and Senator Brownhill and I know because we actually live this sort of life and mix with people who have to put up with these things.

The Committee had to front up to third and fourth generation farmers who had had 20,000 sheep and ask, `How is the drought affecting you?' We would be told, `We might have 2,000 sheep left but we cannot tell because we are too frightened to start looking for them. They are in such poor condition that if we stir them up they might fall over and die anyway'. Those were the sorts of comments made to us during our public hearings. I know Senator Crane would support my comments.

The Government has been slow in reacting to rural counselling needs, but I notice that in One Nation, the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), he put forward proposals for funding for rural counsellors through to 1995. I have to ask: if Mr Keating and the Government feel that there is a need for rural counsellors through to 1995, what sort of projections do they have for the rural community? The only reason we have rural counsellors is to counsel rural people. It was apparent from evidence given to the Committee that there has been a huge increase in suicides, particularly among young people. We had evidence that even bank managers were committing suicide. They were obviously involved with their clients and the desperation of the rural community has forced them into taking their own lives, which is unbelievable in this day and age.

One thing that was apparent to me and to other Committee members is how serious this matter is. The drought, the recession, the high interest rates, the low commodity prices and so on are catastrophic and have compounded to force our once proud rural community into despair. Governments of whatever political persuasion used to say that Australia rides on the sheep's back. The people who in the past have been such big producers of wealth for Australia have been badly affected by the drought. We had the opportunity of seeing the sorts of things they are concerned about. They do not want to rely on handouts; they believe that the IED scheme put forward by the Government was reasonably successful, but the changes made were not successful. In other words, they would like to go back to the old IED scheme or an IED scheme that they would be interested in investing in.

According to our evidence, there is no doubt that the assistance given by the New South Wales and Queensland governments in the form of transport subsidies has been most effective, and this goes back to previous droughts. Some of the most effective things on the ground have been transport subsidies that allow farmers to move stock out or move fodder in. They are the sorts of subsidies that farmers look for. Repeatedly, the farmers said, `We are not looking for handouts; we are looking for the most effective way of coping with what to us are natural disasters'.

That brings me to my main point. The Government and the task force have said that droughts should not be considered natural disasters. No matter where one lives or farms, when one gets conditions severe enough to create problems that one has not experienced for 20, 30 or 40 years, if that is not a natural disaster, I do not know what is. When one has a flood, immediately the Government says it is a natural disaster. That is a point that has been put to us in just about every place we went; that the Government should think again about changing its position on the question of droughts not being considered natural disasters.

There are many other aspects of drought that have been put to us. The main things, however, relate to the rural adjustment scheme and the sorts of assistance that help to move stock in and out. With those few words, I will complete my small contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I rise to make some comments on this report and on the current situation with regard to drought in Australia, particularly the effects of the most recent drought over much of Australia. I support the comments of my colleague Senator Calvert and also those of the other Committee members who spoke, the Chairman, Senator West and Senator Brownhill.

PARA.TAB: I am also particularly pleased to see Senator Cook here tonight in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. We have a major task in terms of bringing about an attitudinal change with respect to extreme drought, not only as far as the Government is concerned but also in respect of some members of the Opposition. I have to say that I have a personal vested interest in the outcome of this report because my own property, which my son is on now, is probably in the worst hit drought area in Western Australia. Certainly the situation is equal to that in the pastoral areas up in the Pilbara, Ashburton and Murchison.

On that matter, when we went to the Jerdacuttup-Munglinup district, evidence was given to us by a number of people that the properties, over the last 2 1/2 years, had been destocked by over 70 per cent, which has an enormous impact on people's ability to cope in these particular circumstances. Even if we were in good times, which we are not, it would make it very difficult. One of the tasks we have in terms of defining drought and looking at its impact is to recognise that, in terms of extreme drought, there must come a time—for example, I suggest when one starts getting into one's third year, particularly in those districts that have not experienced continuous drought—when there is a role for the Federal Government alongside the State governments.

The point that I particularly want to raise with regard to this inquiry is that we have effectively been without a drought policy in this country since prior to May 1990. In fact, it goes back some six or nine months before that, before the National Drought Policy Review Committee made its report. That report has been with us since May 1990. It is now March 1992, and we still do not have a drought policy.

Very few people argued with us about the principle or the philosophy behind people preparing themselves for drought or, for that matter, any natural disaster. They did not have a problem, in principle, with the term `self-reliance' which has become, I guess, the vogue term as far as drought is concerned. But they were highly critical of the situation that has developed here; firstly, because of the inconsistency between States in terms of what was being done, and, secondly, in terms of that movement to self-reliance. People have not been given a period in which to do that.

As one individual said to us, `We can put away a haystack of hay', which has a minimal life; `we can put away a silo of grain', which, once again, with the impact of weevils and other things, has a minimal life; `but we do not have a mechanism whereby we can put away a haystack of money'. I believe that the decision of the Federal Government some time ago to change very significantly the IED scheme that we have in place and, in effect, render it useless was a very poor policy decision.

I will not argue against the fact that some people abused it. But what I would say to the Government—in fact, to all people in the House of Representatives and the Senate—is that the policy position should not be, because some people abuse something, to remove it; it should be to fix up the abuses that were occurring. Of course, now, in terms of a drought policy, we find that there is not an effective IED scheme; there is no way that individual producers can protect themselves against the ravages of drought and the subsequent drop in income. I would urge the Government very strongly, and the various State agriculture Ministers who are dealing with this, to act on this aspect of the matter very quickly.

One thing we saw was that the effects of drought differ very significantly from district to district and from State to State. In some areas of Australia the problem was water. In other areas one of the biggest single factors which exacerbated the drought situation was feral animals and kangaroos, particularly goats and rabbits. In other areas we found that the impacts on the grain industry were quite different from the impacts on the stock industry. In some areas we found the problem of woody weeds and we also ran into the situation of wind erosion, which creates another set of problems. So we cannot have just a single mechanism or way of dealing with the particular problem. In terms of the definition, I think that it is very important that a clear indication of what constitutes an extreme drought be given to the industry. Of course, tied in with this is rainfall distribution.

I have already mentioned the IEDs. The other matter that I must raise is the taxation arrangements that need to be in place to assist, encourage and provide an incentive for individual producers to drought-proof themselves in terms of water measures and protection against a drop-off in feed in terms of the storage of hay and grain. In one particular area we saw—I think it was Bourke—a particular producer had puts oats under the ground. The oats had been there for nine years before he pulled them out. Yet that particular producer at that particular time could get no technical advice in terms of what to do and where to store the oats. So there is much that can be done in terms of providing incentives and information to assist the producers.

The question is—and my colleague, Senator Calvert, touched on this—whether or not drought should be included as part of the natural disaster relief arrangements. I quote one witness who said, `It is totally illogical to include flood—too much rain—under natural disaster relief arrangements and exclude drought—too little rain.' I find it very difficult to mount a sustainable argument against that, just as I find it very difficult to mount a sustainable argument against severe cyclone damage qualifying as a natural disaster.

I think this report shows that there is need for a reassessment by Parliament of what constitutes `drought' and what role Commonwealth and States should play in drought relief. Further, the Commonwealth and State Ministers for agriculture should spell out clearly and quickly—because, after all, they have had nearly two years to consider it—what the drought policy in this country is to be. I also reiterate the point that Senator Calvert made in relation to rural counsellors.

One concern which came up quite consistently in a number of areas was the role of the Rural Adjustment Authority, how it operated and how it was administered. It is a reflection on government policy that producer after producer said to us, `The last thing we need at this time is to have more money thrown at us. We have no income. We have no capacity to meet our current debt. To give us more money is to throw good money after bad.' There needs to be a reassessment of the transitional assistance that has been given in the past with respect to the cartage of stock and fodder, and more consideration must be given to taxation arrangements, such as IEDs and taxation incentives to invest in drought-proofing measures, such as water and fodder conservation.We should be looking very closely at the role of tax credits and how they can impact on the overall capacity of producers to make themselves self reliant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I also support you and Senator Crane in moving that the Senate take note of the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—A National Drought Policy—Appropriate Government Responses to the Recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee which you and Senator Crane were part of was set the task of looking at some 58 recommendations of the National Drought Policy Review Task Force. We were told in some of our submissions that the task force was not in total agreement and this was confirmed by a couple of people on the task force who said that they disagreed with some of the findings. Two of those people are, I believe, quite eminent members of the rural community who understand what happens out in the real world, out in the bush, where people have to battle Dorothea Mackellar-type `droughts and flooding rains'.

PARA.TAB: As a Committee we looked at the 58 recommendations to see whether they were relevant and whether they were couched in the right terms. The first recommendation concerned the natural disaster relief arrangements. The Drought Policy Review Task Force was opposed to the reinstatement of drought within those arrangements. When speaking on this matter the other day, I said that it did not really matter whether drought fell within the natural disaster relief arrangements or not, as long as the Commonwealth Government realised that it had to give some assistance once the economic capabilities of individuals and the State were unable to cope with a drought.

We also looked at the recommendation of the Policy Review Task Force relating to self-reliance. From the 67 submissions that we received, and from the nearly 170 witnesses who appeared before the Committee, it was overwhelmingly clear that the farming community wants to be self-reliant in times of drought, but that they cannot become self-reliant unless the Government of the day sets the parameters for them to be so.

I think it is interesting that one of the first references to self-reliance was made by the National Farmers Federation when it said that we should encourage self-reliance in managing drought, facilitate the early recovery of industry from drought, ensure adequate protection of livestock and other resources, and minimise the loss of high-value international markets. As a Committee, we agreed with that because that is basically what the farming community is on about.
One of the witnesses, rural counsellor Mrs Kathleen Sims, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In general—and this includes right down to the hardest battler and one who is leaving his property—I have not found a farmer who would say that the philosophy of self reliance is wrong. I think farmers are basically looking to be self reliant. They are not looking for any handouts. However, in reality, in Australia's climate, drought hits hard, and without some form of assistance, of whatever kind, they feel they are not going to be able to make it through.

Here was someone who was out in the community, talking to the farming community and actually finding out what real farmers thought about things. This was not some bureaucrat in Canberra saying what he thought was good for the farming community, but a person of great character who was out there actually talking to people in the community.

PARA.TAB: In this report the Committee definitely endorsed the concept of self reliance in relation to drought management. However, the Committee also subscribed to the view that there is a need for effective depreciation and other tax measures to provide incentive to farmers and graziers to become self reliant. We advised farmers at the time that we had yet to prepare a further report on this matter, but even at this stage it is clear that we must devise a way of helping people to look after themselves. Surely, that is what life is about. Take IEDs as an example. As Senator Cook would know, since he represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in this place, there are no big cash flows at the moment to enable people to make use of income equalisation deposits.

As I said the other day—and as Senator Crane pointed out many times in the inquiry—it may be that we need a mechanism such as tax credits as an interim measure until such time that people are again able to put money aside in income equalisation deposits.

I say to the people on the Government side of the chamber, the people who took away the value of income equalisation deposits, the people who actually castrated—that would be a good description, because they have made them impotent—the way they handle the income equalisation deposits, that income equalisation deposits now are not serving the purpose they served leading up to the 1982-83 drought period. There is no doubt that if we can get back income equalisation deposits whereby people have the incentive to put money away in good times, get the carrot given to them to put money away so that when the bad periods come they can withdraw that money and pay tax at the ruling rate at that time on the amount of income they receive in that bad year, we will achieve something for the communities.

I do not think people in this chamber—I know the Committee does now because it has been out having a look at what was happening out in the communities—realise the hardship and heartbreak that has really hit people in the rural communities. Only today, for example, the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs had the Isolated Children's Parents Association come before it to talk about the hardship associated with people in isolated areas.

It is very easy for us to all walk back to our offices here tonight, lift the telephone and ring up whomever we want to ring up. The Committee was given instances today—and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, were at the meeting—of people being told that, due to the mail run and the isolation they did not get the notice, their telephones had been cut off. Solely because those people were so isolated, Telecom very unfeelingly cut their telephones off without really even thinking about the consequences of their actions on people living out in those isolated areas.

I reckon a fair go for people in the rural communities is what everyone is on about in this place. I think even people on the other side of the chamber would agree. Unless people in the farming communities who are out there earning export income can receive assistance, help, support and incentive in the good times so that when the bad times come they can look after themselves, we will not have those export industries producing the income that gives the people that are sitting at the table here, the people that are sitting on the other side, the standard of living that we all have had in the past. This inquiry is basically about trying to get a decent national drought policy so that when we have a drought we do not find the farmers falling off the twig. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate tonight with a certain amount of apprehension, having experienced what drought is all about. I had some notes when I first read this report. Not only can I not find the notes but I cannot find the report. However, there are many people in this chamber that know what drought is all about. Senator Brownhill is of the opinion that maybe there are not quite enough people who know about drought, but I think, for the times that Senator Crane, myself, Senator Brownhill and the National Party of Australia have told the Senate about drought, people should understand what it is to experience it.

PARA.TAB: Drought is like death; it is almost as certain as death. One can expect a drought every four to five years in New South Wales; in Western Australia we expect a drought every six to seven years. The east has not had a drought since that disastrous drought of 1982. That is the drought that elected this Government. This Government ran its election campaign on the recession that came out of that drought. That is how it got elected. When the rain came the next year it claimed credit for having broken the drought and for having turned the recession around.

The only way to beat drought is to conserve three things. In addition to conserving one's energy, people should conserve fodder, water and cash. To conserve fodder, people should not really need any incentive, although they should know that they can lose stock very quickly once drought comes in and the feed runs out. I think that governments of all colours and persuasions should provide a certain amount of incentive for fodder by depreciation of plant—maybe accelerated depreciation—and of course of the buildings into which the hay or whatever they use for fodder is put. At present, I understand that people write off hay sheds over 30 years; so there is not much incentive there. Plant for haymaking does not have a motor, so people probably write that plant off over about 10 years. More incentive has to be put their way.

The conservation of water is very important, especially in the vast areas of the eastern States as well as in Western Australia which does not have scheme water. Even if one has scheme water on one's property, it is very costly. The way to get over this problem for stock is to build bigger dams.

As generations pass, the dams seem to get bigger. I can remember when I was young a water dam of, say, 3,000 cubic metres being large. Ten or 15 years down the track anything of that size was very minimal and the going rate was 6,000 or 7,000 cubic metres. The dams have now been enlarged to about 10,000 cubic metres. If we have dams of that size, when these floods come such as the recent ones in the east—we also get them in the west—or when the normal winter rains fall and the dams fill up, we will be able to last for at least four years before water becomes scarce. Surely, we have good rains every four years with which to fill the dams. Unfortunately, for those who need an incentive to build earth dams, the depreciation is not enough. The time during which it is written off is far too long. In the good seasons, when farmers and pastoral people could be encouraged to put money back into dams, not enough is done.

The third area is the conservation of cash in good years. It all depends where one is in the farming game. People in areas on which nature smiles kindly such as New Zealand, Tasmania and certain parts of Victoria know that they will get a good season every year. But where I come from, a 13-inch rainfall district, people are always looking over their shoulders at drought. Mr Acting Deputy President, you were there many years ago when we were both young fellows. People in that area tend to conserve a little more than they do in the areas that the good Lord looks after every year.

It is in this situation that the IEDs come in. IEDs have been laboured a fair bit in this chamber, but I do not think it hurts to run through the history of IEDs again. We used to have a good system, probably kicked off by Doug Anthony, who was an honourable member in the other place many years ago. I do not give much credit very often to the National Party, but Doug Anthony was a great fellow who represented the bush of Australia. IEDs were introduced while he was Minister and we had a pretty good system for quite a few years. But when my friend from Doodlakine in Western Australia, Senator Walsh, came along—and I tell him this every day—he said, `There is a rort in them. There has to be a rort. There is too much money in them. It is a rort for taxation'. Senator Walsh fiddled with IEDs and the Government threw them out. He then fiddled with them again, and we now have a system that does not work.

The other day I read out to the Senate a table to illustrate that IEDs almost disappeared when these measures were applied. I do not know how many millions of dollars were in the deposits—I think $168m at its height—but within two or three years they had disappeared. At that time we had a very poor season and a downturn in wheat and wool prices and the deposits disappeared altogether. Of course, in government, we will restore the IEDs to the sorts of levels that existed previously; it is very important.

The rural adjustment scheme has played its part in Australia. Unfortunately, the Federal Government distributes finance to the various State organisations and that is where the whole scheme falls down. The assistance comes in three parts: farm build-up, carry on finance and household support. However, even though a lot of these officers are farmers or ex-farmers, they turn into bureaucrats overnight.

Senator West will know how it goes because even in New South Wales the money does not go out too fast, especially when it is needed to plant crops. It is pointless getting that money when the opportune time for planting the crop has gone. In my own farming situation the ideal time to plant a crop is between 1 May—if the good Lord sends us rain—and 10 June. If farmers do not start to plant crops until the last week in June or early July, they will be locked in and will not get a very good season at all. In that situation, if they have borrowed money and are paying interest, it puts them further behind the black ball and they would be better off not planting the crop.

This scheme has been going in Western Australia and, no doubt, in all of Australia, for many years, but it does not matter, they have not learned how to get on. The reason is that it is too centralised. If the decisions for loaning money were left with the bank branches out in the country, it would be far better. That is how money should be distributed. In the One Nation package a certain amount of money is allocated to wheat planting. I hope that decisions on that will be left to the bank managers out in the bush who know their customers on a one-to-one basis. They will be able to make quick decisions and if farmers want to borrow money to plant crops, it can be done nice and early to get the best sorts of crops.

Tonight I saw a news item on the National Bank of Australia. Although I have never dealt with that bank, I have a certain amount of admiration for it. That bank will provide more funds this year for the Australian rural scene and, hopefully, get the crop planting up.

I also saw a report that wheat planting should go up by 35 per cent in Australia this year, which will make up for the big downturn we had last year, especially on this side of the country. The downturn in Western Australia was nowhere as bad because we had a one-off GMP put in place by Premier Lawrence which gave people who were thinking of cropping the confidence to plant their crops. We had a fantastic season in Western Australia and a lot of farmers have done better than they would have done, so I have always commended Premier Lawrence for that, although I do not commend her for very much else. All in all, this report is a fair one that reflects—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this debate but I have heard a few things tonight that have prompted me to do so. It is important to remind people that last week the One Nation policy was handed down. There are a couple of things in it that answer the demands and requests of many of the people that the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs heard evidence from. As Senator Panizza said, it includes the acceleration of depreciation allowances for plant and machinery. It might not be to the extent that some people would wish, but it is certainly a significant acceleration of the depreciation allowance, and that needs to be remembered.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is that the rural adjustment scheme part B has been extended. The Commonwealth Government will be expending $20m on that purely for financing of crops, which is another issue that came before the Committee. Once the drought has broken and there has been some rain, people who are in dire financial straits and unable to borrow from other sources would not be able to get money to put their crops in and start their cash flow. It is the actual harvesting of the crop that starts the cash flow, but they have to be able to afford to buy seed. This $20m for RAS Part B will help these people.

It is very important that we do not lose sight of the fact that the Government has already started to look at a number of the issues that were raised. Maybe it did not even read the Committee's report—I do not know—but in those two examples the Government has started to look at and answer our requests.

We have also had the Australian Agricultural Council. The Ministers have at least reached an agreement to work towards a national drought policy, and that has to be commended. For once we are getting this group of Ministers to agree to a national policy. It has never been very easy in this country to get Ministers from the States and Territories to agree that we are one country and need national policies. I have been through it with education and transport in other areas. It is very pleasing to see that, in the agricultural area, the State, Federal and Territorial Ministers now agree that they need a national policy. They are working towards that and will, hopefully, be able to bring down a national policy when they meet in July.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Queensland has experienced very severe and quite wide-ranging droughts in recent times. Some people have failed to understand the scope and the enormity of the droughts which we have suffered in my home State of Queensland. The following example illustrates the point very clearly. In some areas of the Burnett around Proston even in the bad droughts of the 1970s and 1980s they managed to keep the stock alive and in vaguely decent condition. We have had stock in those areas dying in massive numbers, which is an indication that even in the better rainfall areas of our State, over the last six to 12 months we have suffered incredibly severe conditions and it has been extremely hard for many farmers to remain viable.

PARA.TAB: Some people might be tempted to say,`What does it matter that we lose one or two farmers here or there? They will be replaced'. The problem is that they will not be replaced. When these people leave the industry we not only lose farmers and a commitment to the maintenance of those farms and the earning of export dollars for this nation, but, more importantly, we also lose the skills of those farmers; sometimes skills that have taken 20 or 30 years to build up. These are things that are not easily replaced.So it is difficult to measure the real cost of drought simply in monetary terms. The impact of the drought is much more wide ranging than many people have recognised to date.

I turn to this report and start by looking at the submission of the United Graziers Association of Queensland to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. Bill Bonthrone, who is the head of the UGA, is a tireless worker for farming families and communities throughout Queensland, and the UGA does a great deal of good work. He noted in the submission the workings of the RAS scheme at the moment and he pointed out the obligation of the States to help administer RAS and the money that is made available. He talked about RAS Part B and said that a lot of the money has gone into fodder and water freight subsidies and restocking subsidies. That is quite good for those who are involved principally in the grazing industries.

Without any disrespect to Mr Bonthrone or the UGA, I say to the Government that the number of people who are affected by drought is far greater than those who are merely graziers. For example, on the Darling Downs in Queensland during this recent drought we had a major problem. Many of the grain crops failed and, as a consequence, not only was income lost there but it added a higher cost to other primary industries, for example, the feedlot industry. The feedlot industry in the Darling Downs had to go as far as South Australia to find fodder. It cost farmers $60 per tonne to bring that fodder up to Brisbane and then they had to meet the additional cost of transport from Brisbane to the Darling Downs.

That affects the viability of the feedlot industry. It also affects the viability of industries such as the pork industry, which is very important. I have touched on that industry a number of times in this place and probably do not need to go any further. We need a comprehensive solution to drought. It is a major problem that faces this nation. I believe very strongly that self-reliance is the best policy but people must have the ability to become self-reliant.

One of the problems at the moment is that when farmers make provision for storage of fodder or storage of water they cannot write off the cost in the same year in which they expend the money. If they had a reasonably stable environment and an assured income, it would be fine to say, `We will depreciate this over 20 or 30 years', or whatever it is. But, of course, the problem is that they make this expenditure and they set aside this plant and equipment because they cannot rely on next year's income.

So it seems totally ludicrous to say to farmers, `Go and become self-reliant, go and store fodder or make water storage facilities available on your farm, but you are going to have to write off the cost over a protracted number of years'. It may be, for example, that a farmer puts up a hay shed and the very next year there is a drought, he has a negative income, and that depreciation arrangement is of no use at all. We should be encouraging farmers to become self-reliant and that means that they have to have a sufficient incentive to do so. I do not believe that the system we have at the moment is at all adequate. I believe that accelerated depreciation of the necessary precautions against a drought in terms of fodder and water conservation are absolutely critical.

Farmers from one end of Queensland to the other say to me that they need a fair dinkum IED scheme. We did have a fair dinkum IED scheme under the last coalition government; it was an excellent scheme. I repeat the comment of Mr James O'Shannessy, Deputy Chairman of the Bourke Rural Lands Protection Board, who told the Committee:
The income equalisation scheme—

SPEECH.PARA: I assume he means the old one—

was a great system, I thought and I think most graziers will agree with me. It allowed self-help. It allowed people to make provisions for the next drought. I would strongly recommend. . . that it be changed back to what it was. . .

The problem with the IED scheme as it exists at the moment is that there is a big tax penalty on money that farmers put away in the scheme. Farmers say, `Why should we put money away? The first $39,000 of that is going to be subject to taxation, yet I am not really getting the benefit of it in this year or any of the years in which it has been put in the IED'. It should not be taxed in that fashion. I do not think that that is a reasonable thing. The farmer is being told, `Put the money away, but pay us tax on it out of your other money anyway. We believe that is sufficient incentive for you to put that money away to protect against drought'. Of course it is not, and it never will be. We need much more flexibility and an understanding of the real financial pressure that many farm families are under at the moment—not just now but for many years to come—because of the high interest rates and low rainfall that they have suffered. It will take our farming community many years to get out of their current difficulties, and I think the Government has to recognise this.

PARA.TAB: In other countries, as honourable senators would know, governments are much more generous. We have a lot of competition with Canada in the areas of wheat, beef, pork production and so on. Farmers there have a marvellous scheme where they can basically quarantine in a very generous IED scheme a portion of their income every year and the Canadian Government matches it dollar for dollar. So for every $1 they put in the scheme the Canadian Government matches it with another $1, and when their income falls below a certain level they can draw down on all of those funds. We are not asking the Australian Government to be as generous as that, and I do not think many farmers in this country really want to receive subsidies and handouts—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have said that.

—As Senator Calvert has said, they have said that. They do not want to receive subsidies and handouts, but what they do want is a fair go. This Government has to recognise that this penny pinching in the taxation of the IED scheme does the farmers no good at all. In fact, because it degrades the long term viability of the farm sector, it impedes farmers from earning a generous income in the good years. It lowers the tax revenue to the Commonwealth by doing the things that it has done. We do not support tax evasion, but we do support giving industries an incentive to look after themselves.

PARA.TAB: The final point I make is that, no matter how self-reliant people become, there will always be exceedingly bad years. We believe that, just as flood is provided for in the national disaster relief arrangements, so too should drought be provided for. It is the opposite side of the coin: a flood is too much water, a drought is not enough water, and they should be treated equally. Unless the Government embarks on widespread irrigation programs—for example, the Bradford scheme in north Queensland to take the water across to the northern Downs—and provides that infrastructure, which will mean that people will not be affected by drought, severe drought will be a problem, no matter how self-reliant people try to become. Therefore, it stands to reason that the Government has a very clear obligation to make provision for that under the national disaster relief arrangements.

These matters are of considerable significance. I am grateful to the Senate for making time available to address these matters tonight. The Government and the Senate need to take a long, hard look at drought and not just assume that it can be solved in a matter of months, or even a matter of years.
