TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give a brief report to the Senate on a recent trip I took on behalf of the Government to Africa. I was asked to lead the Australian Government delegation to SADCC, the Southern African Development Coordination Conference, that was this year held in Maputo, Mozambique. I had the opportunity to give the speech on behalf of Australia at that conference. I make three points. The first is that the Australian Government supported SADCC and congratulated it on its achievements so far towards the integration of the 10 countries that now constitute SADCC for the purposes of trading as a bloc and developing more efficient and rational transport arrangements, energy supply, and also the preparation for the acceptance of the membership of South Africa once full democracy and the end of apartheid is achieved in that country.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, we were very much in sympathy with the SADCC countries as a trading bloc because they, as has Australia, have suffered the effects of trade subsidies imposed by the European Community, Japan and the USA. Thirdly, I stress the point that continuing to ignore the particular poverty that is the lot of women is unjust. It is also economically unsound to leave women in a state of illiteracy, with poor health and insufficient provision for care during pregnancy and childbirth. It is a matter of absolute profligacy to waste all that talent. To chase good money after bad in a catch-up program of a minimum sort seemed to me to be worthy of comment.

Our report was favourably received and we had a number of people from other countries wanting to speak to our delegation about assistance that Australia might offer. It is important to note for the record that Australia is very well received in Africa, certainly in all the countries to which I have ever been—and this time around in Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa around Johannesburg and Pretoria where they thought Australia was a good country to come from. They liked Australia and appreciated very much our contribution there. However, there was some qualification to that praise when it came to South Africa.

I was able to visit aid projects that Australia and World Vision are implementing in Zimbabwe. In particular, I was interested in them both from the position of being a member of a government that has aid projects there and because of my background as a doctor. Those projects are providing primary health care in community health centres of a sort that most Australians would not recognise, although perhaps some Aboriginal communities would feel that the circumstances were somewhat similar.

I was particularly interested to note that, when it came to weighing babies, scales were tied to a tree. Babies were then placed in a sling which was hung from a hook on the scales. Older children were taught the trick of holding on to the hook underneath the scales and taking their feet off the ground. So the primary health care is certainly primary. But, of course, it provided the necessary information about weight gain in little babes.

The health workers are trained to help mothers to record the weights, to see that the babies are adequately nourished. They were also taught how to hydrate babies, particularly the simple method of using hydration fluid. Babies received their inoculations against childhood diseases and the mothers received contraception advice, a supply of the pill if they needed it or injections of depo-provera if they chose it. Condoms were available, but there was not a very large demand for them.

I mention these things because they relate to two of the major problems confronting Africa and the challenges that country has in dealing with them. Firstly, countries that are very poor and are struggling to feed their people need to look seriously at population control programs. But this is a very awkward and difficult area. So by and large these matters are left to health care workers and, in particular, to the mothers themselves. Therefore, this leads to an insufficient provision of care and service in that area.

In particular, the mothers who are choosing contraception from either the pill or the depo-provera injection are not being provided with the contraceptive cover that allows them to practise safe sex. So the very benefits of contraception are also contributing to the potential for the spread of AIDS. In Africa, AIDS is a very major problem.

The figures that I was given on AIDS in Africa are not just frightening; they are devastating. As I recollect, 10 million people of a population of some 500 million people in south Saharan Africa are HIV positive. One person in 50 of the population is HIV positive. The rest of the world has not quite grasped the consequences of those figures.

Today I spoke with some representatives from World Vision who have also worked in Africa. They spoke of communities and villages that are now abandoned. The only people left alive in them are grandparents and tiny babes. The generations in between are now all dead. They are not just sick; they have already died and are wiped out. We have not begun to understand just how devastating this huge disease is in Africa. It will only get worse and it will only spread further.

The problem of AIDS in Africa is different from country to country. The figures are very horrific and very large. When I visited the Deputy Minister for Health in Mozambique I was told that there are 1,200 new cases of AIDS per annum per one million of the population in Uganda compared with 1,000 in Kenya and about 1,000 in Malawi. Curiously, 200 is the comparable figure in Mozambique. The figure is low in Mozambique because of the bizarre benefit of war. The chronic war in Mozambique has prevented the ordinary communication, relationships and travel of people, so the number of AIDS cases there is actually lower at the moment.

But 1.2 million Mozambique people are living across the border in Malawi, which has a very high percentage of the population with AIDS. Many of those people are said to be HIV positive and, when the war is over, they will return to Mozambique. So the effect there will also be very devastating.

In Johannesburg I met some health officials and discovered that AIDS is a very significant problem in South Africa. In the black community it is a heterosexual disease; in the white community it is a homosexual disease. This means that we do not yet know a sufficient amount about the spread of the HIV disease. We do know that it is transmitted by sex, be it by homosexual or heterosexual practitioners; that it is spread by blood transfusion; and that it is spread by the use of shared needles. Also, rather horrifically, it is spread during pregnancy from parent to child.

All those means of transmission are significant in Africa. It is something that is beginning to be treated as seriously as those numbers indicate it ought be. In fact, one thing that is most impressive is the effectiveness of the Australian treatment and management of AIDS. There is no cure for this disease. The only way it can be managed is by proper community education and the proper living practices so that its spread is minimised.

The Australian experience is now recognised worldwide for the effective program that it is. Indeed, we have been able to offer that kind of information and assistance to other countries. One aid program that I was told about but was not able to visit was in Zambia where Australians are working with the Salvation Army in a very successful AIDS program.

I was very shocked the other day to read the remarks of Professor Hollows. He mentioned the word `quarantine'. He suggested that, as a means of protecting people who are at the moment free of the disease, we should quarantine them. It is far more important to give people information than to isolate them.

A Ugandan woman called Noerine Kaleeba has written a very beautiful book, entitled We Miss You All, about the effect of AIDS in Uganda and what happens to families when two, three, four or five members die of AIDS. We are now not talking about an isolated case here or there or a small pocket of the community but rather a very devastating epidemic. The cry from her book and the people who spoke to me is, `Please do not isolate people. Give us the information so that we can use it to live safely and constructively with AIDS or with HIV positive people so that they are not isolated'.

The very worst thing she says in her book—and others have told me this—is that people who are HIV positive or who are suffering from AIDS find themselves isolated and abandoned by their communities. Certainly for those who are HIV positive and certainly for those with AIDS, and also for people who are at risk but are not yet HIV positive, it is far more important that we do not practice the ostrich syndrome of putting our head in the sand and isolating or quarantining people. It is far more important that we learn the facts about the spread of AIDS and learn to live successfully with it so that it is not spread.

That is the evidence one can take from Australia. We are one of the most successful countries in restricting the spread and the increased number of cases. Africa is very interested in our successes and has made its own plea for information.

The visit to Mozambique also gave me the opportunity of seeing the variety of ways in which Australian aid is provided. Some of it is development aid very much at the grassroots level. For example, I visited a covered well of clean water that Australian aid has provided in a Julius Nyerere village in Xaixai, a northern province. It was very pleasing to visit that community and see how appreciated something as small as a covered well water supply was by the community and what assistance it provided.

I also visited Mozambique Telecommunications which is working with Australian Telecom to provide telecommunications in the northern province. Commodities assistance is a very successful different type of aid exchange program whereby expertise and equipment from Australian Telecom is being provided to Mozambique Telecommunications, which is very much appreciative of that effort. It is also interesting because Australia has to deal with exactly the same sorts of problems of great distance, significant temperature differences, drought, flood and fire—the sorts of things that make for specific requirements even in a telecommunications system.

In all three countries I was delighted to meet at every opportunity with women's organisations and appreciate the hunger of women for information and their appreciation of support, wherever it may come from, but particularly their appreciation of belonging to an international network of women—women who are aware of the problems that are specific to countries and those that are general. I found myself made very welcome amongst the groups of women and I was very appreciative of their hospitality. People who have nothing often have a great generosity and certainly these folk made me very welcome indeed.

One of the projects that I found interesting was a kind of aid project. I am not exactly sure of the channels by which the money gets there, but I think the Australian Commonwealth is providing assistance for the new multi-party elections in Mozambique. I believe Mr Colin Ball from Tasmania is in Mozambique at the moment assisting with this stage of preparing for the multi-party election—looking at the requirements in terms of cubicles, the ways in which to get the names of people, identifying who the people in the community are, how many there are, and so on, and what will be the cost of that.

I subsequently met a very new women's group called Women in Law and Development. While I wanted to ask them all sorts of things about what life was like for them in Mozambique, I found that they really wanted to ask me many questions about what it is like to be in a parliament that has more than one party. In particular, I was rather charmed by these questions: how do you all get on in the one room? What does an opposition do to the government?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very little of any value.

—I think they were more concerned at the way people who have been at war might actually co-exist in the same room. It is very interesting to meet people who are asking questions that level: please tell us what it would be like? How do you have a for and against in the one room?

PARA.TAB: The women were concerned, too, because of the massive problem of illiteracy amongst women. How on earth can one talk about having an election when people in huge numbers are unable to read? In what way does one guarantee that those people have their rights? Again, they were very interested to hear from me what little I could tell them of the experience we have had of trying to inform Aboriginal people in this community—the Electoral Commission's efforts to send teams out to Aboriginal communities to tell them what their rights are and how to be involved in elections; what that power means to them, and so on.

Finally, I simply say a few words about the time in South Africa. It is sobering to go to Johannesburg and Pretoria or, more particularly, to leave the white cities and go to the townships. I spent some time in Soweto, in Katlahong and Soshanguve. The townships were shocking in the mile upon mile of grossly insufficient housing. We were able, after we had asked whether we could, to visit with a family in what most of us would call an insufficient description of a garage: a galvanised iron shed, the roof held on by rocks and the ceiling but six feet high. If one put two single beds in the room, one would be out the front door. The place was immaculately clean. Each day this lady made sure that her house was tidy and in order. There was no water; standpipes were some many yards or kilometres away; water has to be carried, as African women are good at doing, on their heads; and of course there was no sewerage. This, for mile after mile.

In Johannesburg and Soweto there were huge slag heaps within cooee of the townships. I was interested, when visiting the hospital nearby, to ask the doctors what was in the dust. One doctor said, `It's just dust, you don't have to worry about it'. Another doctor said, with remarkable honesty, `It's from the mines; it's full of cyanide'. That dust blows so that we could hardly see trees across the ground—dust which is full of cyanide that was falling on those people day after day. It is just a little extra that they had added to their lives.

The poverty there was extraordinary. Another reason why I was pleased to go was because there are a number of APHEDA projects funded to some of those townships. One was a creche and another a pre-school centre that was going to open the next day. The walls were built and the ceiling was being put on that afternoon or evening. Again, apart from water, housing and sewerage, the principal request for black people in South Africa was for education—education that has been denied them under the Bantu education system. I was advised that that Bantu education system will ensure that whenever democracy comes to South Africa apartheid will continue for at least 20 years but, more realistically, 40 years, as the people who are insufficiently educated wash through the system and a new generation of people, hopefully better educated, come into the system. The need for education is critical at all levels. The programs are aimed at the moment to start the education system with children at the beginning of school, so that they at least can expect to leave school with an adequate and comprehensive education.

The other APHEDA project was to provide assistance for sport, particularly the representation of women's and girls' sport, and to bring sport to people who have insufficient opportunity to practice it. That fits very nicely alongside a recent allocation of $100,000 from the Australian Government to the Australian Embassy in South Africa also to assist with sport. I was able to meet with the officials who have been negotiating the re-emergence of sporting teams into the international arena now that their overarching committees are no longer segregated.

Every time I have visited Africa I have found that I could certainly leave a large part of my heart there. I do not quite know what it is about Africa that captures my sympathy and imagination, but I certainly have to report that it does. It is a country that faces enormous challenges. The women I met certainly indicate that, despite those crushing burdens of poverty and chronic insufficient services, care, food, et cetera, they still have an optimism, they still have an energy and they are still prepared to keep trying. I am very pleased that I can be part of an Australian Government that continues to provide support and aid to the many countries in Africa and, of course, to be part of the world push to see the removal of apartheid in South Africa.

I was able to meet with Albertina Sisulu and the African National Congress women's organisation. They had the same appreciation of Australia's concern for and interest in what the challenges were for them. I am also happy to put on the record that when I met Walter Sisulu, amongst other things that we talked about were, of course—from my point of view—women. I was somewhat surprised when Walter Sisulu said to me, `You know, you are the first politician, Senator, who's ever raised the question of women with me'. I believe that that is something I will want to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) about so that again and again we will see that women are legitimately part of any international discussions and that they are on the agenda. To come back to where I started, the overlooking of the rights of women is not only unjust, it is bad economics.

Finally, I wish to place on the record my appreciation of Colin Lonergan and Bruce May from AIDAB, who escorted me on this delegation, and also my thanks for the assistance I received from the High Commissioner in Zimbabwe, Joe Thwaites, who when he went into Mozambique became an ambassador. It was interesting to discover his changed status. Joe Thwaites and his wife Anne Lorne were both of great assistance. I also thank the second secretary, Dr Neshateckle, an extraordinary woman with her capacity not only to speak the languages of the country, in particular Portuguese, which is of great help in Mozambique, but her huge network of contacts. I was able to visit hospitals, women's organisations, projects and so on in a way that may not otherwise have been possible. I give thanks to all those people who assisted me. I also thank the people in the Australian Embassy in South Africa—Colin McDonald, David Sprott, and Peter Smith from the AIDAB section there.

It was a very worthwhile visit. It was very constructive for Australia to be part of the Southern Africa Development Coordination Conference, SADCC, through its aid contribution there. It was an enriching experience for me personally, not only in terms of the general understanding of health issues and the information I received, but also in being able to make contact with that network of women who I find wherever I go in the world are worthy of meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise tonight a very real case that is of concern to me because it relates to a farming family, a family of sugarcane farmers in Queensland. I draw attention to the difficulties they face, not just as a result of the poor state of the economy and of the sugar industry, but as a result of problems that have been exacerbated by their difficulties with our Federal bureaucracy.

PARA.TAB: At this point, for the elucidation of the Senate, I think it would be best if I seek leave to table a number of documents. There is a letter from the Department of Social Security dated 22 November 1971; a letter from the Queensland Industry Development Corporation dated 17 October 1971; a letter written by constituents to the Department of Social Security dated 14 January 1992, with an enclosure; and finally a letter from the Department of Social Security dated 28 October 1991.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. My concern is that for real people the Government, probably through the work of the bureaucracy, has lost sight of the problem. Too often policies are devised to fit a particular monetary or fiscal result and do not really address the problems of people. The policy is program driven and not needs driven. That would be all right if it were not for the enormous human cost of running programs in that way. Senator Button made some comments about the dangers of being enmeshed in the Canberra bureaucracy. I think we have a problem in that respect.

PARA.TAB: If people are struggling under a financial disability as a result of the legacy of the Government's high interest policy, the recession, commodity price crashes or drought, they need help. The problem is that they do not get it. Instead, they are thrown into bureaucratic red tape, frustration and ultimately humiliation.

I shall take the case of Mr and Mrs N, as I shall refer to them, who are cane farmers on the mid-north coast of Queensland in Mr Courtice's electorate of Hinkler. Mrs N is on the old age pension, which on 10 October 1991 was assessed at $131.60 a week. Like many cane farmers in Queensland, they are suffering severe financial problems.

For the financial year ending June 1992, according to an estimated profit and loss statement from their accountants which has been submitted to the Department of Social Security, there will be a total income for the year of $5,892. The problem is that of that income of $5,892 their farming enterprise shows a loss of $1,573. There is $300 in bank interest, wages of $500, an accident insurance claim of $1,250, and most significantly a QIDC household support assistance payment from 1 October 1991 to 30 June 1992 of $5,415, making a grand total of $5,892. That is all the money the couple will have for this financial year.

Mr and Mrs N sought financial assistance through the QIDC, and on 17 October 1991 the QIDC advised Mr and Mrs N that $1,805 was approved for household assistance support to cover the period from 1 October 1991 to 31 December 1991. It advised that the assistance was available in quarterly advances for an initial period of six months. I make it clear that this funding is provided to alleviate financial hardship while the people concerned face the decision of whether to adjust out of primary production and sell their property. After this period, if the people decide to retain their property, the assistance provided converts to a loan, with interest charged at commercial rates repayable over seven years. Therefore, there is no guarantee that it is income; it could be a loan if they decide to stay on.

Meanwhile, back at the Department of Social Security, Mrs N, as is required, has advised the Department that they will be receiving $1,805 in household support assistance and that the support was available for six months—they had received it for a period of three months. The Department of Social Security got out its calculator and worked out that Mr and Mrs N would receive income of $1,805 multiplied by four—a sum of $7,220 until June 1992. Clearly that cannot be the case because even if the assistance were to run for the whole period through to the end of June 1992, they could still get only three quarters of that, but that is the Department's logic.
On 22 November Mr N received a letter from the Department of Social Security saying in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Due to a change in your circumstances your pension has been reviewed and altered. . . Your fortnightly rate will be. . . $19.00. . .

That represents a fall of 85 per cent, or $112 a fortnight, which is really quite shocking for people who are in a grave financial position. I cannot understand, and would be grateful if someone could tell me, how the Department of Social Security can arrive at an 85 per cent cut in pension for people who almost literally have the backside out of their trousers.

PARA.TAB: The DSS decided that the QIDC household support would be to June 1992—$1,805 multiplied by four, or, as I said, $7,220. The Department said that interest would be $108 and—I ask the Senate to listen to this—that Mr and Mrs N would have a farm income of $20,020. The reality is that they will have a farm loss of $1,573, which is the estimated figure. The Department also estimated that accident insurance would be worth $1,440 and wages $500, making a total of $29,288. In the words of the Dickensian character Mr Micawber, that result would be bliss if it were true. If it were true, these people would not be bothered with the Department of Social Security in the first place. Something is severely wrong. As the Senate will recall, Mr and Mrs N's accountant estimated their annual income for this financial year to be $5,892, made up of $5,415 principally of QIDC household support. Again in the words of Mr Micawber, the result is penury.

Mrs N talked to the Department of Social Security about this, but to no avail. Therefore, on 14 January 1991 their accountant wrote to the regional manager pointing out that the purpose of the QIDC assistance was to tide them over until their farm was sold or, if it were not sold within two years, the money advanced would be regarded as a loan. There are clear grounds for making some sort of adjustment.

SPEECH.PARA: The accountant explained that this assistance was not income and submitted Mr and Mrs N's estimated profit and loss statement.

PARA.TAB: To cut a long story short, seven weeks later the Department of Social Security regional office has not responded, the result being that out there is one very unhappy and financially stressed couple, one of whom is on an old age pension, trying to battle red tape, bureaucrats and government policy, trying to make a living and adjust their lifestyle and their farm. The question I ask is simply this: why is this office taking such a long time to reply? Why are people being put through financial agony by the Department of Social Security for seven weeks? It seems to me that it is all too hard, that it has gone into the too-hard basket because it would appear that there is no policy to cover it. If that is the case, that is unsatisfactory.

There are thousands of Mr and Mrs Ns in Australia at the moment who are being crushed into the ground by just such uncaring policies. There is either no heart left in the Government or there is no heart left in the bureaucracy. The Government is turning into a giant machine which is crushing the spirit out of people. It draws its harvest from ruthless plantings of policy, recession and high interest rates. Unfortunately, the crop from those plantings is far too good.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak this evening on a matter that took up some of Question Time and some period after Question Time. This issue is of considerable concern to me and, I am sure, to a number of other senators. I refer to the naming in this place of people who do not have the opportunity to respond.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon Senator Parer, in a statement, referred to Mr Mike Reynolds—I point out that he is no relation of mine, despite a similarity of surname—and to another person. I believe that both gentlemen were seriously misrepresented by Senator Parer. It is quite normal for us, in the normal cut and thrust of politics, to say things about each other that cannot be justified and certainly cannot be validated. Certain things were said this afternoon about me and one of my colleagues, Ted Lindsay. I accept that because I can respond on my own behalf in the Senate and Mr Lindsay can respond on his behalf in the House of Representatives.

I do object to the maligning of individuals who do not have the facility to answer in this place. I believe that both Mr Reynolds and Mr Parker, as members of the Townsville Harbour Board, have been misrepresented by Senator Parer in the debate this afternoon. Senator Parer is entitled to his views. He believes that money should be spent in north Queensland—his State, I remind people; anyone listening might not realise, from the way he was talking this afternoon, that he is a Queensland senator. Senator Parer is entitled to his views, but he is not entitled to misrepresent the character and motives of two people he has probably never met. He is probably not interested in meeting them because he has already formed an opinion about them.

I believe that that kind of approach in this place, and in the other place, is doing a grave disservice to all of us as representatives of the people. As we all know, politicians have a pretty poor reputation in the community. I believe that one of the reasons for that is that we abuse the position of trust and the opportunity we have to say as we please under privilege in this place.

I am speaking this evening not to score even further political points—that was done most effectively this afternoon by my colleague Senator Collins—but simply to speak up for two people. I am glad that Senator Parer has come into the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have told me you were going to speak.

—I know the honourable senator will say that it is the custom to advise a person if one is about to speak about that person, but I do not think Senator Parer paid that courtesy to me or, indeed, to Mr Reynolds or Mr Parker in his remarks this afternoon, so I did not feel it was necessary to reciprocate.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to restate the arguments of this afternoon about whether or not spending $20m in north Queensland is a good thing. It seems to me to be a perfectly ludicrous argument for a Queensland senator to make. But that is something for the Liberal Party. I do wish to make the point that I think all of us should avoid naming people who cannot defend themselves unless they take advantage of referral through the Standing Committee on Privileges. But that is not easy for many ordinary Australian citizens unless they know that that procedure is available. I will certainly be advising Mr Reynolds and Mr Parker that that facility is available, but whether or not they take action on it is entirely up to them.

My purpose in speaking tonight is to defend both of them. I have worked closely with Mr Mike Reynolds, who is a former long-serving Mayor of Townsville. He has an outstanding reputation in that community. I do not know Mr Parker nearly as well, but I have no doubt that he has not earned the comment that was made about him by Senator Parer.

It is important this evening to put on the record the fact that honourable senators should think very carefully before they name people in this place. We can name each other; we can say what we like about each other because we can all come back in and argue the point. We are part of this process; but innocent bystanders do not deserve to be named in this place, unless it is in the context of some absolutely extraordinary allegation that is in the public interest and there is full documentation of that circumstance.

I leave that with you, Mr Deputy President, and I hope with honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. We have all been tempted or have done it in the past. It is a practice that I think lowers the standing of parliamentarians. The community sees that it is a double standard and, sadly, parliamentarians are often accused of having too many double standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to Senator Reynolds, who acknowledged that she did not inform me she was about to make those remarks. I remind Senator Reynolds that the remarks I made followed a question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins). The reason they followed that question is that I moved a motion that the Senate take note of the Minister's reply. The reply he gave me was unsatisfactory and not in keeping with the facts I obtained upon doing a thorough search on what this $20m was to be spent on.

PARA.TAB: Let me make this point clear: I would be at the forefront of supporting expenditure on infrastructure—and I made that point clear—where that expenditure resulted in either increased exports and increased import replacement or increased tourism. If anything is needed in this country today, in view of our current account deficit and in view of the number of people unemployed, it is a real stimulus for real jobs.

On investigation of the remarks that had been made by the Chairman of the Port Authority in the Townsville newspaper, what I said was quite correct. The old board was basically thrown out and he was appointed chairman by his mate. It was a mate's job for the boys. I know that he was mayor for many years. In fact, he extended many courtesies to me on the trips I made to Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you prepared to repeat this outside the House?
—What have I said?
—Are you prepared to repeat this outside the chamber?
—Repeat what? Senator Cook should tell me what he wants me to repeat.
—Answer the question.

—The last point I made was that the Chairman of the Port Authority was mayor for many years and had extended courtesies to me during my trips to Townsville. That was not the point. The point I was making was that he was gung ho about a project, which apparently the Government accepted without thorough investigation, to spend $20m of taxpayers' money on the first stage of the building of an outer harbour which the users do not want and which has no potential. There is nothing at the end of the horizon. The argument can be put—
—Thank you for your private view. We don't need it, but thank you for it.

—This is not a private view; this was done after investigation. The argument can be put that if we provide certain infrastructure we may attract certain business into an area. In my view, particularly in the current economic climate, with our Budget blowing out the way it is, that is not good enough. It is like putting the cart before the horse. We need to see the demand before we spend taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: It was difficult to ascertain what the money was going to be spent on, hence the first question I asked of Senator Collins. When he responded and said that it was to ensure the continued jobs of 900 people at Yabulu, that was clearly wrong. The expenditure of that money on the outer harbour had nothing whatsoever to do with the continued existence of Greenvale Nickel. In fact, Greenvale Nickel distanced itself from this expenditure because the initial expenditure was no good unless there were further contributions of another $60m-odd to complete the project.

When Senator Collins responded to me this afternoon, he said, `Well, we are continuing negotiations'. In other words, $20m was thrown into the Keating `Kickback' package simply as a throwaway to Townsville, without determining what it was to be spent on. That is my problem, and it should be a problem for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We recognise you have a problem.

—Senator Cook is the problem. Senator Cook and his Government are not just a problem to me, they are a problem to the whole of Australia. Who brought on this recession? Who caused one million people to be out of work? Who is responsible for record bankruptcies? We cannot blame the Poms for that.
—They will give it a try.

—Of course. Where there is an obvious discrepancy, where taxpayers' money has been expended, we in this Parliament have an obligation to question the Government on how it intends to expend that money. Again, I repeat: I would support any expenditure which clearly shows that it will result in an improvement in the economy of this country. I mean in the long term; I mean to create real jobs. Where money is thrown at something that has been explained to me by all the users as something they have no interest in, there is clearly something wrong.

PARA.TAB: There are many other projects in the Townsville area that need money. It seems that the Government has put together a package very quickly to respond somehow to the Hewson Fightback package, and in the process it has not done its homework. In all the remarks I have heard today—whether from Senator Collins or Senator Reynolds—I have yet to hear any justification for throwing money at a rail loop where there is already a perfectly good rail loop, and for spending money on land reclamation and dredging of an outer harbour where there is no demand for that port facility. If there was a demand, I would agree with Senator Reynolds, but she knows and I know that Greenvale would prefer to use Halifax Bay, although at this stage it is prevented from doing so. Using Halifax Bay prevents double handling and would enable them to be viable, and there is an appeal going on in relation to that.

The alternative is something they are already doing. They are using a berth that belongs to Mt Isa Mines, and they can continue to use that berth with some very minimal capital outlay. It was either Senator Button or Senator Collins who interjected when I was speaking and said, `We know they have a cheaper alternative, but we will keep pursuing this'.

That brings me to the point: Senator Collins did not know what he was talking about—I will not say he misled the Parliament—when he said, `The reason we are doing this is to save the jobs of 900 workers at Yabulu'. That is clearly not right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days we have seen the Government solving the crisis in youth unemployment by pretending that there is not one. It has been coming out with invented figures which, as has been pointed out in this place, are totally mischievous, totally dishonest and totally deceptive—claiming, for example, that the real measure of youth unemployment is not as a percentage of the work force but as a percentage of the population. We all know that is absolute nonsense. The real measure is the number of people looking for jobs. If the Government is going to apply this new criteria, I wonder why it has not applied that percentage to the adult unemployed. There is exactly the same proportion of adults out of the work force as there are 15- to 19-year-old young people out of the work force. The percentage for adults is about 52 per cent and for 15- to 19-year-olds it is about 60 per cent. That dishonesty is exposed as absolute total nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the adult work force, it would be just as rational to include in the work force as the measure all retired people and all wives who do not work if you are going to include all young people who are at school and not seeking a job. The irrationality of the Government's position is self-evident. But now we come to a greater dishonesty in the Government's position. Mr Beazley, who is now Minister for Employment, Education and Training, is so ill-informed in this matter that he said on the Richard Palfreyman radio program `The World Today':

SPEECH.PARA: Youth rates of unemployment are high, that is true, but compared to the 1982-83 recession there are far fewer young people actually looking for work; about 450,000 back in 1982-83. The number is now 290,000.

In other words, he was suggesting to the listeners that there had been a dramatic cut of 145,200 in the number of young Australians looking for jobs. That is totally false. Maybe it is only incompetence that led him to that because the figures he quoted are exactly the figures of the number of young Australians in full time work. It is true that back in 1983 in that recession there were 450,000 young Australians in full time jobs. There are now only 290,000 in full time jobs. His figures are exactly right for the wrong matter.

PARA.TAB: Those figures reflect the number of jobs wiped out. One in every three full time youth jobs has been wiped out since the 1983-84 recession. Yet Mr Beazley got on radio and quoted those figures of the jobs wiped out. Wrongly and incompetently, he referred to them as the number of young people actually looking for work. For his information, let us get the facts straight—and let us hear him apologise.

The facts are that the total number of 15- to 19-year-olds unemployed—that includes people looking for full time and part time jobs—in January 1984, at the peak of the recession, was 222,100. It is now 218,100—roughly in line, except that there were more people in the work force then. So the unemployment rate among 15- to 19-year-olds in 1984 was 26.9 per cent and the unemployment rate now is 27.3 per cent, the worst on record. They are the actual figures, if Mr Beazley wants to know the facts, and that is taking part timers as well as full timers. Of course, if we take the proper measure of youth unemployment, which is the full time unemployment rate, it is now 34.8 per cent compared to 30 per cent.

On every honest measure, youth unemployment now is worse than it was in the last recession, and for Mr Beazley to come out pretending that there had been a drop of 150,000 in the number of young people looking for work when in fact it was a drop of 150,000 in the number of young people at work indicates either a massive desire to pretend that the problem does not exist, to talk it out of existence, or a massive incompetence in being able to read the unemployment statistics. Whatever it is, it explains clearly why this Government has done absolutely nothing to resolve the crisis of youth unemployment. All it has done is try to invent figures to pretend that the problem does not exist.

That is why the young people of Australia received nothing in this One Nation program—nothing but an admission that the job training schemes had been failures. Three of them are being quietly closed down and the funds diverted into a repackaged version of the same sort of thing. This Government has the hide to come into this chamber and accuse me of retailing misleading statistics when they are in fact from the Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force survey. The only people misleading the Parliament and Australia on the level of youth unemployment are in this Government. If they are going to do anything about it, it would be a nice idea if they tried to fix the problem, not just fiddle the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We have had a number of speakers on the adjournment tonight. Senator Crowley spoke about her experiences in Africa, which was informative. Senator O'Chee raised a matter in the nature of a grievance. Senator Reynolds did the same about the naming of people who are not members of this place and are unable to defend themselves when they and their reputations are criticised. Senator Parer replied to those allegations, although, I might say, quite limply and ineffectually. Senator Michael Baume rose on the subject of youth unemployment. I do not intend to comment on all of the speakers, but I cannot allow the adjournment debate to be completed without a remark or two in reply to what Senator Michael Baume has said.

PARA.TAB: The first thing that might be said about Senator Baume's remarks is: why does he bother? Why does he bother to propound a fallacy so consistently unless he believes that by continuous repetition he can sometimes change reality? What Senator Baume has done here tonight is what he has done on a number of other occasions. Words like `dishonesty' and `misleading' trip very lightly and easily from his tongue. I suggest anyone interested in this subject should in fact look at the truth of the circumstances and come to a conclusion. Senator Baume put out a press release the other week in which he said that one in three young Australians was unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were too crooked to read the next paragraph.

—Senator Baume put the headline on this press release. It was meant to be eye-catching, it was meant to be used by subeditors to headline newspaper articles about the matter, and his defence is, `You ought to read the rest of the press release because I actually explain in some way or other how I can justify that proposition'.
—In detail. You were too crooked to read them into the record.

—There is no explanation because the proposition is patently nonsense. The reason Senator Baume is so sensitive about the matter is that he knows that in his heart of hearts, and he resents the idea that someone has identified that he has been caught out on this.

PARA.TAB: The situation with youth unemployment is of course different from the situation of adult unemployment. The reason for that is that the labour market for young people is a different labour market in character and nature than the adult labour market. Young people are traditionally between the ages of 15 and 19 and are not married with families; therefore, one does not find the lack of participation in the work force that there is amongst adults because they have family responsibilities or other duties. So the test about family or domestic responsibilities does not apply to this group in the work force.

The other notable thing that does not apply to this group in the work force is that a huge number of people in this age group are in education or training. In fact, the most significant element of education and training is that in the nine years of this Government—and today I think is the celebration of the ninth year of the election of the Hawke Labor Government in 1983—the retention rate for year 12 students has doubled. That is quite a significant achievement. It is also true that during this time in approximate terms real expenditure has increased in real terms. I cannot be absolutely sure about this figure, but the figure I have in mind—

TALK.START.PARA: —Invent one; you always do.

—No, I will not invent one. It is about 40 per cent or more; I am being modest. It represents a huge commitment to education under this Government and a huge boost in opportunity for young people to remain in the education system. If one looks at the youth labor market, in rough order the figure is one in 10. About seven of the 10 young people are in education or training of some sort; the other three are in the labour market. One of those three is unemployed. That is the true context in which this occurs. To run around with headlines about one in three is, of course, ridiculous.

PARA.TAB: The other characteristic about youth unemployment is that there is a tendency in this age structure for young people to dip in and out of the labour force, to transfer between working and training and back again. Another feature about this age group is that these people tend to be placed much quicker than other age groups. So we are not looking here at an in-built group which is long term unemployed; we are looking at a group of people who move around in employment much more quickly. The great feature of what this Government has done is its commitment to training and education.

The huge feature of the One Nation statement is, of course, the commitment of an extra $720m towards TAFE training. This Government is concerned that the funds spent on education have meant that the technical training and TAFE sector is out of balance with the tertiary and education sector and that there is now a need to commit funds to that area.

The innovation in the One Nation statement is to do this in cooperation with the States on a national scale in order to bring opportunities for technical training back into focus. That is, I think, one of the most positive commitments any government can make to the question of employment opportunities for young people. Those who have the better skills are the ones who are likely to be placed. As the recovery takes place with greater force during the course of this year, employment opportunities in real careers will be opened for them. This training that they now have access to will stand them in good stead for those careers.

That commitment ought to be compared with the proposition in the so-called Fightback! document, the Hewson consumption tax package, which alters some of the labour market programs in a way in which the victims get blamed and the cost is borne by them. In fact, Austrain, which is supposed to be a labour market support program under the Hewson consumption tax package, is best named, as it has been called now, `Austslave'. It means that people who are employed under this program, should it ever take root, will work at 80 per cent of the award rate. That means that a pool of low-wage labour, able to displace existing labour without creating additional spots, will be created. The cost of bidding wages down across the board will be borne by those people who are wage earners.

I think all of those features are enough for any reasonable person to conclude that if it comes to a debate about youth unemployment in this country and a credential contest to see who has the right to claim the mantle as the party of greater concern, that mantle unquestionably and undoubtedly goes to the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: ``With reference to an article in the Age on 8 November 1991 entitled, "PS payouts overtaxed by millions" and to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 27 November 1991 entitled, "Redundancy payouts hit by Tax Act's low blow":

(1) Is it true, as the article alleges, that an employee, aged under 55, of the Public Transport Corporation of Victoria (PTC) received favourable tax treatment on his early retirement that the entire early retirement payment, which included a pro-rata long service leave component, was taxed at 5 per cent.

(2) Did this occur as a result of a change in a ruling issued by the Australian Taxation Office to the effect that the long service leave component would not have accrued if he had voluntarily resigned.

(3) Are there many other employees in other industries who have availed themselves of redundancy packages and who have had the pro-rata long service leave component of their payment taxed at 30 per cent, even though they would not have received long service had they left voluntarily.

(4) Why should taxpayers receiving a redundancy package, which includes a pro-rata long service leave component, and which they would not have received if they had left voluntarily, be taxed at the 30 per cent rate while the long service leave component of the sum paid to early retirees, aged under 55, and therefore in reality employees taking redundancy from the Public Transport Corporation of Victoria, was taxed at 5 per cent.''

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: ``The Commissioner of Taxation advised that the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent him from specifically answering questions (1), (2) and (3).

However, Taxation Ruling IT 2255, which issued on 27 February 1986, explains the Commissioner's view of the law in this area. A specific provision (section 26AD) of the income tax law includes in a taxpayer's assessable income amounts paid in respect of accrued and pro-rata long service leave to which a taxpayer is entitled. Such income is subject to a maximum rate of tax of 30%.

The provisions, however, only apply to pro rata long service leave payments if there is some formal arrangement for the making of the payment. A gratuitous payment to a terminating employee, calculated on a basis similar to that for ordinary long service leave entitlements, is not sufficient. That is the case whether the payment is a payment to an employee who has not qualified for any long service leave entitlement or is an additional payment calculated by reference to the employee's ordinary long service leave entitlements.

Such a gratuitous termination payment is an eligible termination payment. Where such a payment is an approved early retirement scheme payment or a bona fide redundancy payment it may qualify for concessional taxing treatment. That is, only 5 per cent of any amount (not including forgone superannuation benefits) in excess of what the taxpayer would have been entitled to on voluntary retirement is included in assessable income and taxed at marginal rates. The tax law does not discriminate in this respect between a taxpayer receiving a redundancy package or a taxpayer retiring early under an approved early retirement scheme.''

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 6 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) visited Singapore over the past two years in her role as a Government Minister; if so, what was the purpose and duration of such visit(s).
(2) Did the Minister stay at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore on official Government business to that country.
(3) What was the cost of the suite occupied by the Minister during that visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In my role as a Government Minister I visited Singapore from 9 to 11 December 1991, for discussions with Government Ministers, on a range of environmental issues emerging from an OECD Ministerial meeting which I had attended in Paris. Furthermore, these discussions were of particular value in formulating a South East Asian-Australian regional view on these issues in advance of important international meetings, which are to take place later this year, within the framework of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED).
I met with:
(a) Professor Tommy Koh, Chairman of the UNCED Preparatory Committee to discuss:
OECD Ministerial meeting I attended in Paris prior to arriving in Singapore;
United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED).
(b) Dr Ahmed Mattar, Minister for the Environment, to discuss:
OECD Ministerial meeting I attended in Paris prior to arriving in Singapore;
United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED);
urban environment issues;
Australia Singapore agreement on the environment.
(c) Brig Gen Yeo, Minister for Information and the Arts and Second Foreign Minister to discuss:
issues related to international efforts to negotiate conventions on climate change and biodiversity;
issues relating to the preparation of text for an agreement by Heads of Government at the UNCED Summit.
(d) representatives of Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority to discuss:
Singapore's experience of urban redevelopment and planning;
how Singapore deals with urban pollution;
economic measures used by Singapore to achieve planning objectives;
effects on business of stricter standards for pollution.
Whilst in Singapore, I was able to inspect Singapore's Waste Incinerator and deliver an address to the Singapore Australia Business Council.
(2) Yes.
(3) $A499.14 per night ($A1,496 for accommodation costs for the duration of my stay).
